DOCS_modelChunkLoadStart = new Date().getTime(); _getTimingInstance().incrementTime('mp', DOCS_modelChunkLoadStart - DOCS_modelChunkParseStart); DOCS_warmStartDocumentLoader.loadModelChunk(DOCS_modelChunk); DOCS_modelChunk = undefined;DOCS_modelChunkParseStart = new Date().getTime();DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":20699,"s":"o[i] +\u003d (1LL\u003c\u003c16);\nc \u003d o[i]\u003e\u003e16;\no[(i+1)*(i\u003c15)] +\u003d c-1+37*(c-1)*(i\u003d\u003d15);\no[i] -\u003d c\u003c\u003c16;\n}\n\nAside from carrying from one limb to the next, the function also adds 2^16 to each limb and subtracts 1 from the next highest limb before performing the carry. This ensures that repeated application of the function brings all limbs into the interval [0, 2^16 ‚àí 1]. Without this addition, repeated application of the carry chain would bring all limbs into the interval [‚àí2^16 ‚àí1, 2^16 ‚àí1]. We use this additional functionality to ‚Äúfreeze‚Äù field elements to a unique representation at the very end of the Curve25519 or Ed25519 computations. We reuse the multiplication for squarings, but make squarings explicit by spending a few bytes of source code for a separate function that simply calls multiplication. This makes it easy during code audit to compare the code to elliptic-curve addition formulas, for example from the Explicit Formulas Database. To match the notation of Explicit Formulas Database we use the names M and S for functions that multiply and square in the field F2^255‚àí19; we also use A for addition and Z for subtraction. Inversion uses Fermat‚Äôs little theorem and is implemented through exponentation with 2^255‚àí 21. We use a simple square-and-multiply algorithm and avoid storing the exponent by making use of its special shape: it has all bits set but the bits at position 4 and position 2. We perform the square-and-multiply loop for inversion as follows:\nfor(a\u003d253;a\u003e\u003d0;a--) {\n\tS(c,c);\n\tif(a!\u003d2\u0026\u0026a!\u003d4) M(c,c,i);\n}\n\nThe square-root computation for point decompression in Ed25519 uses exponentiation by 2^252 ‚àí 3. Observe that this exponent has all bits set but the bit at position 1; we use the same approach as for inversion.\nCurve arithmetic: The typical Curve25519 implementation computes a Montgomery ladder on the Montgomery curve M : y^2 \u003d x^3 + 486662x^2 + x. The Ed25519 signature scheme performs arithmetic on the birationally equivalent twisted Edwards curve E : ‚àíx^2 + y^2 \u003d 1 ‚àí 121665/121666x^2y^2.\nMore specifically, Ed25519 key generation and signing perform a fixed-basepoint scalar multiplication; verification performs a double-scalar multiplication. In principle, TweetNaCl could use the same scalar-multiplication code for both Curve25519 and Ed25519. This would require conversion of points on M to points on E and back. If we used the x-coordinate-based differential addition ladder of Curve25519 also for Ed25519, we would additionally need code to recover the y-coordinate as described by Okeya and Sakurai. Conversion code is not substantially shorter than the code required for the Curve25519 Montgomery ladder, so we decided to not use the same code for scalar multiplication in Curve25519 and Ed25519. Curve25519 uses the same Montgomery ladder as the reference implementation, except that we do not use a dedicated function for multiplication by the constant 121666. For Ed25519 we decided to use only one scalar-multiplication routine that can be used in key generation, signing, and verification. We represent points on E in extended coordinates as described in Twisted Edwards curves revisited and implement the complete addition law in an add function. We use this function for both addition and doubling of points. The scalar multiplication then performs a ladder of 256 steps; each step performs an addition and a doubling:\nset25519(p[0],gf0);\nset25519(p[1],gf1);\nset25519(p[2],gf1);\nset25519(p[3],gf0);\nfor (i \u003d 255;i \u003e\u003d 0;--i) {\n\tu8 b \u003d (s[i/8]\u003e\u003e(i\u00267))\u00261;\n\tcswap(p,q,b);\n\tadd(q,p);\n\tadd(p,p);\n\tcswap(p,q,b);\n}\n\nThe first four lines set the point p to the neutral element. The cswap function performs a constant-time conditional swap of p and q depending on the scalar bit that has been extracted into b before. The constant-time swap calls sel25519 for each of the 4 coordinates of p and q. The function sel25519 is reused in conditional swaps for the Montgomery ladder in Curve25519 and performs a constant-time conditional swap of field elements as DOCS_modelChunkLoadStart = new Date().getTime(); _getTimingInstance().incrementTime('mp', DOCS_modelChunkLoadStart - DOCS_modelChunkParseStart); DOCS_warmStartDocumentLoader.loadModelChunk(DOCS_modelChunk); DOCS_modelChunk = undefined;DOCS_modelChunkParseStart = new Date().getTime();DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":24709,"s":"sv sel25519(gf p,gf q,int b) {\n\ti64 t,i,c\u003d~(b-1);\n\tFOR(i,16) {\n\t\tt \u003d c \u0026 (p[i]^q[i]);\n\t\tp[i] ^\u003d t;\n\t\tq[i] ^\u003d t;\n\t\t}\n}\n\nArithmetic modulo the group order: Signing requires reduction of a 512-bit integer modulo the order of the Curve25519 group, a prime p \u003d 2^252+Œ¥ where Œ¥ ‚âà 2^124.38. We store this integer as a sequence of limbs in radix 2^8 . We eliminate the top limb of the integer, say 2^504b, by subtracting 2^504b and also subtracting 2^252Œ¥b; we then perform a partial carry so that 20 consecutive limbs are each between ‚àí2^7 and 2^7. We repeat this procedure to eliminate subsequent limbs from the top. This is considerably more concise than typical reduction methods:\nfor (i \u003d 63;i \u003e\u003d 32;--i) {\n\tcarry \u003d 0;\n\tfor (j \u003d i - 32;j \u003c i - 12;++j) {\n\t\tx[j] +\u003d carry - 16 * x[i] * L[j - (i - 32)];\n\t\tcarry \u003d (x[j] + 128) \u003e\u003e 8;\n\t\tx[j] -\u003d carry \u003c\u003c 8;\n\t\t}\n\t\tx[j] +\u003d carry;\n\t\tx[i] \u003d 0;\n\t}\n}\n\nWe similarly eliminate any remaining multiple of 2^252, leaving an integer between ‚àí1.1 ¬∑ 2^251 and 1.1 ¬∑ 2^251. We then multiply the final carry bit by p and add, obtaining an integer between 0 and p ‚àí 1, and carry in the traditional way so that each limb is between 0 and 255.\nLimitless potential for client applications\n\nHuddle01‚Äôs Divergent SDK offers developers the ability to create a wide range of client applications that utilize WebRTC for one-to-one communication. By simply replacing the existing signaling layer with Divergent, developers can easily integrate the SDK into their applications. As a generalized real-time communication protocol, Huddle01‚Äôs Divergent can be used to build a variety of applications, including eCDN services like Peer5, chat applications like Telegram, workflow automation services like Zapier, and even browser-based video games. The possibilities are endless with Huddle01‚Äôs Divergent SDK.\n\nFuture work\n\nThis paper should be considered a work in progress. The only motive behind building a system like this was to demonstrate the capabilities and potential of a decentralized real-time communication engine (dRTC) like Huddle01 and our first step towards our end goal of building a fully scalable, decentralized real-time communication network.\n\n\n\nConclusion\n\nHuddle01\u0027s Divergent offers a decentralized and secure solution for real-time communication using WebRTC. By utilizing the IPFS network for data storage and IPFS Pubsub for message exchange, the Divergent Protocol enables developers to build a diverse range of applications that require real-time communication, such as chat applications, eCDNs, and workflow automation services. The protocol\u0027s use of elliptic curve cryptography ensures the security and privacy of communication on the network. Overall, Divergent offers a promising solution for decentralized real-time communication.\n\n\nReferences\n\nWebRTC 1.0: Real-Time Communication Between Browsers. 26 February 2021.\nLibp2p/specs ( https://github.com/libp2p/specs )\nIPFS - Content Addressed, Versioned, P2P File System by Juan Benet\nSDP: Session Description Protocol. *)){padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}Huddle01 is building a dRTC engine that enables users to create tools that fuel the future of real-time communication. Our platform aims to bring people closer via seamless video calling from anywhere in the world and help them express their thoughts and feelings without any privacy concerns.
Huddle01‚Äôs Video SDK is built upon the infrastructure that powers Huddle01 platform. So now you can create your dApp that can be as powerful as the Huddle01 dApp itself üé•
React is the most widely used framework by developers around the world to build efficient, scalable, and fast web applications. We‚Äôve built our SDKs around it and have handled state management too!
Introducing Huddle01 Client SDK:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/@huddle01/huddle01-client
 
Web SDK - Client SDK Architecture üèó

The @huddle01/huddle01-client package comprises of 4 modules:

store Built-in state management built on top of zustand holding all states relevant to the conferencing (no need to manage your own state)

hooks We‚Äôve extracted and encapsulated stateful logic and side effects from reused components, making it easier for you to reuse this logic across multiple components

utils Added standalone functions that are usually small and focused, and they are designed to be used as needed throughout and are helpers which are optional

schema This includes useful types and interfaces that will give you access to datatypes while implementing the @huddle01/huddle01-client package in Typescript


Guide to building your own conferencing solution üìö
Prerequisites:
Before starting with development, setup your environment with these prerequisites:
https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/prerequisite
 
1. Generate an app from scratch
Run the following command to generate an app instantly ‚ö°
npx create-huddle01

or
yarn create huddle01

2. Add to an existing application
To add the @huddle01/huddle01-client package to an existing application, you will need to install it using npm, yarn or any other package manager of your choice
Open a terminal window and navigate to the root directory of your application, then run the following command:
npm install @huddle01/huddle01-client

or
yarn add @huddle01/huddle01-client

Get your API key
https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/api-key
 
Initialise the app
The HuddleClientProvider lets you access the huddleClient in any component within your application:
//src/App.tsx
import { HuddleClientProvider, getHuddleClient } from '@huddle01/huddle01-client';

const App = () => {
  const huddleClient = getHuddleClient('<Your-API-Key>')
  return (
    <HuddleClientProvider client = {huddleClient} >
      <YourApp>
        ...
      </YourApp>
    </HuddleClientProvider>
  );
};

Using the huddleClient instance

huddleClient.join('roomId');

Other methods can be found in the Builders' Kit ‚öíÔ∏è
Access state in the application
The useHuddleStore is a custom react hook built by us to give you access to the state of the app in a similar fashion as redux does.
// JavaScript | TypeScript
import { useHuddleStore } from "huddle01-client/hooks";

// Example
const isCamPaused = useHuddleStore((state) => state.isCamPaused);

You can even use the redux-devtools extension to monitor the state of your apps which are created using @huddle01/huddle01-client

Example Apps

Javascript - https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app

Typescript - https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app-ts



That's a wrap!
Now that you know how easy it is to use Huddle01 SDKs, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with the infra.
In case you have some doubts or need help with the integration, feel free to reach out to us on Discord or Twitter, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•
Read more about Huddle01 SDKs üìö
Try out Huddle01 for a quick meeting üé•

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

Add to an existing application\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo add the \u003ccode\u003e@huddle01/huddle01-client\u003c/code\u003e package to an existing application, you will need to install it using npm, yarn or any other package manager of your choice\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOpen a terminal window and navigate to the root directory of your application, then run the following command:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-bash\\\"\u003enpm install @huddle01/huddle01-client\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eor\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-bash\\\"\u003eyarn add @huddle01/huddle01-client\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-get-your-api-key\\\"\u003eGet your API key\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cdiv class=\\\"embed-wrapper\\\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"embed-loading\\\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"loadingRow\\\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"loadingRow\\\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003ca class=\\\"embed-card\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/api-key\\\"\u003ehttps://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/api-key\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-initialise-the-app\\\"\u003eInitialise the app\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003eHuddleClientProvider\u003c/code\u003e lets you access the \u003ccode\u003ehuddleClient\u003c/code\u003e in any component within your application:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-jsx\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-comment\\\"\u003e//src/App.tsx\u003c/span\u003e\\n\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e { HuddleClientProvider, getHuddleClient } \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-string\\\"\u003e'@huddle01/huddle01-client'\u003c/span\u003e;\\n\\n\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003econst\u003c/span\u003e App = \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-function\\\"\u003e() =\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e {\\n  \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003econst\u003c/span\u003e huddleClient = getHuddleClient(\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-string\\\"\u003e'\u0026lt;Your-API-Key\u0026gt;'\u003c/span\u003e)\\n  \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003ereturn\u003c/span\u003e (\\n    \u003cspan class=\\\"xml\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-tag\\\"\u003e\u0026lt;\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-name\\\"\u003eHuddleClientProvider\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-attr\\\"\u003eclient\u003c/span\u003e = \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-string\\\"\u003e{huddleClient}\u003c/span\u003e \u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\\n      \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-tag\\\"\u003e\u0026lt;\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-name\\\"\u003eYourApp\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\\n        ...\\n      \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-tag\\\"\u003e\u0026lt;/\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-name\\\"\u003eYourApp\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\\n    \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-tag\\\"\u003e\u0026lt;/\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-name\\\"\u003eHuddleClientProvider\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\\n  );\\n};\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-using-the-huddleclient-instance\\\"\u003eUsing the \u003ccode\u003ehuddleClient\u003c/code\u003e instance\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671692728122/pWzSNlOIq.png\\\" alt class=\\\"image--center mx-auto\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-jsx\\\"\u003ehuddleClient.join(\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-string\\\"\u003e'roomId'\u003c/span\u003e);\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOther methods can be found in the \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/methods\\\"\u003eBuilders' Kit\u003c/a\u003e ‚öíÔ∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-access-state-in-the-application\\\"\u003eAccess state in the application\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003euseHuddleStore\u003c/code\u003e is a custom react hook built by us to give you access to the state of the app in a similar fashion as \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://redux.js.org/\\\"\u003eredux\u003c/a\u003e does.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-jsx\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-comment\\\"\u003e// JavaScript | TypeScript\u003c/span\u003e\\n\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e { useHuddleStore } \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-string\\\"\u003e\\\"huddle01-client/hooks\\\"\u003c/span\u003e;\\n\\n\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-comment\\\"\u003e// Example\u003c/span\u003e\\n\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003econst\u003c/span\u003e isCamPaused = useHuddleStore(\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-function\\\"\u003e(\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-params\\\"\u003estate\u003c/span\u003e) =\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e state.isCamPaused);\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou can even use the \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/redux-devtools/lmhkpmbekcpmknklioeibfkpmmfibljd?hl=en\\\"\u003eredux-devtools\u003c/a\u003e extension to monitor the state of your apps which are created using \u003ccode\u003e@huddle01/huddle01-client\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671693057536/VUSWtgeDN.png\\\" alt class=\\\"image--center mx-auto\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-example-apps\\\"\u003eExample Apps\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eJavascript - \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app\\\"\u003ehttps://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eTypescript - \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app-ts\\\"\u003ehttps://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app-ts\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg id=\\\"heading-thats-a-wrap\\\"\u003eThat's a wrap!\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow that you know how easy it is to use Huddle01 SDKs, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with the infra.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn case you have some doubts or need help with the integration, feel free to reach out to us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eRead more about \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/docs\\\"\u003eHuddle01 SDKs\u003c/a\u003e üìö\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/\\\"\u003eTry out Huddle01\u003c/a\u003e for a quick meeting üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"Huddle01 is building a dRTC engine that enables users to create tools that fuel the future of real-time communication. Our platform aims to bring people closer via seamless video calling from anywhere in the world and help them express their thoughts and feelings without any privacy concerns.\\n\\nHuddle01‚Äôs Video SDK is built upon the infrastructure that powers Huddle01 platform. So now you can create your dApp that can be as powerful as the Huddle01 dApp itself üé•\\n\\nReact is the most widely used framework by developers around the world to build efficient, scalable, and fast web applications. We‚Äôve built our SDKs around it and have handled state management too!\\n\\n*Introducing* ***Huddle01 Client SDK:***\\n\\n%[https://www.npmjs.com/package/@huddle01/huddle01-client] \\n\\n## Web SDK - Client SDK Architecture üèó\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671692327926/xrXXV7mp9.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\nThe `@huddle01/huddle01-client` package comprises of 4 modules:\\n\\n*   **store** Built-in state management built on top of zustand holding all states relevant to the conferencing (no need to manage your own state)\\n    \\n*   **hooks** We‚Äôve extracted and encapsulated stateful logic and side effects from reused components, making it easier for you to reuse this logic across multiple components\\n    \\n*   **utils** Added standalone functions that are usually small and focused, and they are designed to be used as needed throughout and are helpers which are optional\\n    \\n*   **schema** This includes useful types and interfaces that will give you access to datatypes while implementing the `@huddle01/huddle01-client` package in **Typescript**\\n    \\n\\n## Guide to building your own conferencing solution üìö\\n\\n### Prerequisites:\\n\\nBefore starting with development, setup your environment with these prerequisites:\\n\\n%[https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/prerequisite] \\n\\n### 1\\\\. Generate an app from scratch\\n\\nRun the following command to generate an app instantly ‚ö°\\n\\n```bash\\nnpx create-huddle01\\n```\\n\\nor\\n\\n```bash\\nyarn create huddle01\\n```\\n\\n### 2\\\\. Add to an existing application\\n\\nTo add the `@huddle01/huddle01-client` package to an existing application, you will need to install it using npm, yarn or any other package manager of your choice\\n\\nOpen a terminal window and navigate to the root directory of your application, then run the following command:\\n\\n```bash\\nnpm install @huddle01/huddle01-client\\n```\\n\\nor\\n\\n```bash\\nyarn add @huddle01/huddle01-client\\n```\\n\\n### Get your API key\\n\\n%[https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/api-key] \\n\\n### Initialise the app\\n\\nThe `HuddleClientProvider` lets you access the `huddleClient` in any component within your application:\\n\\n```jsx\\n//src/App.tsx\\nimport { HuddleClientProvider, getHuddleClient } from '@huddle01/huddle01-client';\\n \\nconst App = () =\u003e {\\n  const huddleClient = getHuddleClient('\u003cYour-API-Key\u003e')\\n  return (\\n    \u003cHuddleClientProvider client = {huddleClient} \u003e\\n      \u003cYourApp\u003e\\n        ...\\n      \u003c/YourApp\u003e\\n    \u003c/HuddleClientProvider\u003e\\n  );\\n};\\n```\\n\\n### Using the `huddleClient` instance\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671692728122/pWzSNlOIq.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n```jsx\\nhuddleClient.join('roomId');\\n```\\n\\nOther methods can be found in the [Builders' Kit](https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/methods) ‚öíÔ∏è\\n\\n### Access state in the application\\n\\nThe `useHuddleStore` is a custom react hook built by us to give you access to the state of the app in a similar fashion as [redux](https://redux.js.org/) does.\\n\\n```jsx\\n// JavaScript | TypeScript\\nimport { useHuddleStore } from \\\"huddle01-client/hooks\\\";\\n \\n// Example\\nconst isCamPaused = useHuddleStore((state) =\u003e state.isCamPaused);\\n```\\n\\nYou can even use the [redux-devtools](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/redux-devtools/lmhkpmbekcpmknklioeibfkpmmfibljd?hl=en) extension to monitor the state of your apps which are created using `@huddle01/huddle01-client`\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671693057536/VUSWtgeDN.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n### Example Apps\\n\\n*   Javascript - [https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app](https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app)\\n    \\n*   Typescript - [https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app-ts](https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app-ts)\\n    \\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671693103700/qCQiDm_65.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n## That's a wrap!\\n\\nNow that you know how easy it is to use Huddle01 SDKs, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with the infra.\\n\\nIn case you have some doubts or need help with the integration, feel free to reach out to us on [Discord](http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com), and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\\n\\nRead more about [Huddle01 SDKs](https://huddle01.com/docs) üìö\\n\\n[Try out Huddle01](https://huddle01.com/) for a quick meeting class=\\\"hljs-name\\\"\u003eHuddleClientProvider\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\\n  );\\n};\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-using-the-huddleclient-instance\\\"\u003eUsing the \u003ccode\u003ehuddleClient\u003c/code\u003e instance\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/methods\\\"\u003eBuilders' Kit\u003c/a\u003e ‚öíÔ∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 by us to give you access to the state of the app in a similar fashion as \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://redux.js.org/\\\"\u003eredux\u003c/a\u003e does.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-jsx\\\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-comment\\\"\u003e// JavaScript | TypeScript\u003c/span\u003e\\n\u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e { useHuddleStore } \u003cspan class=\\\"hljs-keyword\\\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan =\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e state.isCamPaused);\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou can even use the \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/redux-devtools/lmhkpmbekcpmknklioeibfkpmmfibljd?hl=en\\\"\u003eredux-devtools\u003c/a\u003e extension to monitor the state of your apps which are created using \u003ccode\u003e@huddle01/huddle01-client\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg - \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" infra.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn case you have some doubts or need help with the integration, feel free to reach out to us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eRead more about \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/docs\\\"\u003eHuddle01 SDKs\u003c/a\u003e üìö\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/\\\"\u003eTry out Huddle01\u003c/a\u003e for a quick meeting üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"Huddle01 is building a dRTC engine that enables users to create tools that fuel the future of real-time communication. Our platform aims to bring people closer via seamless video calling from anywhere in the world and help them express their thoughts and feelings without any privacy concerns.\\n\\nHuddle01‚Äôs Video SDK is built upon the infrastructure that powers Huddle01 platform. So now you can create your dApp that can be as powerful as the Huddle01 dApp itself üé•\\n\\nReact is the most widely used framework by developers around the world to build efficient, scalable, and fast web applications. We‚Äôve built our SDKs around it and have handled state management too!\\n\\n*Introducing* ***Huddle01 Client SDK:***\\n\\n%[https://www.npmjs.com/package/@huddle01/huddle01-client] \\n\\n## Web SDK - Client SDK Architecture üèó\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671692327926/xrXXV7mp9.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\nThe `@huddle01/huddle01-client` package comprises of 4 modules:\\n\\n*   **store** Built-in state management built on top of zustand holding all states relevant to the conferencing (no need to manage your own state)\\n    \\n*   **hooks** We‚Äôve extracted and encapsulated stateful logic and side effects from reused components, making it easier for you to reuse this logic across multiple components\\n    \\n*   **utils** Added standalone functions that are usually small and focused, and they are designed to be used as needed throughout and are helpers which are optional\\n    \\n*   **schema** This includes useful types and interfaces that will give you access to datatypes while implementing the `@huddle01/huddle01-client` package in **Typescript**\\n    \\n\\n## Guide to building your own conferencing solution üìö\\n\\n### Prerequisites:\\n\\nBefore starting with development, setup your environment with these prerequisites:\\n\\n%[https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/prerequisite] \\n\\n### 1\\\\. Generate an app from scratch\\n\\nRun the following command to generate an app instantly ‚ö°\\n\\n```bash\\nnpx create-huddle01\\n```\\n\\nor\\n\\n```bash\\nyarn create huddle01\\n```\\n\\n### 2\\\\. Add to an existing application\\n\\nTo add the `@huddle01/huddle01-client` package to an existing application, you will need to install it using npm, yarn or any other package manager of your choice\\n\\nOpen a terminal window and navigate to the root directory of your application, then run the following command:\\n\\n```bash\\nnpm install @huddle01/huddle01-client\\n```\\n\\nor\\n\\n```bash\\nyarn add @huddle01/huddle01-client\\n```\\n\\n### Get your API key\\n\\n%[https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/api-key] \\n\\n### Initialise the app\\n\\nThe `HuddleClientProvider` lets you access the `huddleClient` in any component within your application:\\n\\n```jsx\\n//src/App.tsx\\nimport { HuddleClientProvider, getHuddleClient } from '@huddle01/huddle01-client';\\n \\nconst App = () =\u003e {\\n  const huddleClient = getHuddleClient('\u003cYour-API-Key\u003e')\\n  return (\\n    \u003cHuddleClientProvider client = {huddleClient} \u003e\\n      \u003cYourApp\u003e\\n        ...\\n      \u003c/YourApp\u003e\\n    \u003c/HuddleClientProvider\u003e\\n  );\\n};\\n```\\n\\n### Using the `huddleClient` instance\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671692728122/pWzSNlOIq.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n```jsx\\nhuddleClient.join('roomId');\\n```\\n\\nOther methods can be found in the [Builders' Kit](https://huddle01.com/docs/sdk/web-sdk/methods) ‚öíÔ∏è\\n\\n### Access state in the application\\n\\nThe `useHuddleStore` is a custom react hook built by us to give you access to the state of the app in a similar fashion as [redux](https://redux.js.org/) does.\\n\\n```jsx\\n// JavaScript | TypeScript\\nimport { useHuddleStore } from \\\"huddle01-client/hooks\\\";\\n \\n// Example\\nconst isCamPaused = useHuddleStore((state) =\u003e state.isCamPaused);\\n```\\n\\nYou can even use the [redux-devtools](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/redux-devtools/lmhkpmbekcpmknklioeibfkpmmfibljd?hl=en) extension to monitor the state of your apps which are created using `@huddle01/huddle01-client`\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671693057536/VUSWtgeDN.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n### Example Apps\\n\\n*   Javascript - [https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app](https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app)\\n    \\n*   Typescript - [https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app-ts](https://github.com/Huddle01/sdk-vite-example-app-ts)\\n    \\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1671693103700/qCQiDm_65.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n## That's a wrap!\\n\\nNow that you know how easy it is to use Huddle01 SDKs, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with the infra.\\n\\nIn case you have some doubts or need help with the integration, feel free to reach out to us on [Discord](http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com), and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\\n\\nRead more about [Huddle01 SDKs](https://huddle01.com/docs) üìö\\n\\n[Try out Huddle01](https://huddle01.com/) for a quick meeting *)){margin-top:2.8em;margin-bottom:2.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h2 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] :where(table):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){font-size:0.9em;line-height:1.5555556;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td, tfoot td):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-top:0.8888889em;padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:first-child, tfoot td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}The future of web3 is multi-chain.
Users from numerous blockchain ecosystems are looking to engage with multiple dApps seamlessly. Hence, building a chain-agnostic application will not only get you more users but also enhance their experience. However, chain-agnostic dApps are a headache to build right now, with developers having to write custom code to incorporate multiple blockchains and their pre-existing packages.
Wallet01 is an open-source, multi-chain wallet package built to enable chain-agnostic interaction in your application with just a single plug in. Once added, it facilitates a smooth and reliable onboarding experience for your users from various chain ecosystems.
Building a chain-agnostic application is a monolithic task
It needs stacks of code and hours of research on the internet:

1. Differing chain standards
Mismatched standards between blockchains are the biggest barrier for chain-agnostic applications:

Different APIs

Different environment

Different standards for addresses and key management


2. Lack of proper documentation
Blockchain standards are often poorly defined and are only understood after spending countless hours digging through multiple codebases.
3. UX at the cost of DX
Programmers go to great lengths to provide a better User Experience. However, building a good chain-agnostic application looks like a trade-off for a better Developer Experience.
Wallet01 enables a fast & reliable DX
It saves you a significant amount of time researching and writing code so that you can spend that time adding more cool features to your application.
Here‚Äôs how you can incorporate Wallet01 into your application:

Wallet01 is an ecosystem of packages
This ecosystem makes your application light and modular, with space for more features.
Wallet01 Ecosystem consists of 3 packages:

Core Package: @wallet01/core serves as the brain of the ecosystem, setting up the standards and procedures for all the other ecosystem packages.

Ecosystem Package: @wallet01/evm, @wallet01/solana, and @wallet01/cosmos serve as the mediator between Wallet01 standards and the chain standards.

Framework Package: @wallet01/react serves as the developer front, helping you scaffold a chain-agnostic application with React.


How does Wallet01 work?
Let‚Äôs get into the good part: making a chain-agnostic application with Wallet01 on NextJS üßëüèª‚Äçüíª
1Ô∏è‚É£ Installation npm i @wallet01/react @wallet01/evm @wallet01/solana @wallet01/cosmos
2Ô∏è‚É£ Initiation
import { Wallet01 } from '@wallet01/react';

import { InjectedConnector } from '@wallet01/evm';
import { KeplrConnector } from '@wallet01/cosmos';
import { PhantomConnector } from '@wallet01/solana';

function MyApp({ Component, pageProps }) {

    const desiredConnectors = [
        new InjectedConnector(),
        new KeplrConnector(),
        new PhantomConnector(),
    ]

    return (
        <Wallet01 autConnect={true} connectors=(() => desiredConnectors)>
            <Component {...pageProps} />
        </Wallet01>
    )
}

export default MyApp;

3Ô∏è‚É£ Connect Buttons
import React from 'react'
import { useClient, useConnect, useWallet } from '@wallet01/react'

const ConnectButtons = () => {
    const { connectors } = useClient()
    const { connect } = useConnect()

    return (
        <div>
            {
                connectors.map((connector) => (
                    <button
                        key={connector.name}
                        onCLick={() => {
                            connect({connector})
                        }
                    >
                        {connector.name}
                    </button>
                ))
            }
        <div>
    ) 
}

export default ConnectButtons;

4Ô∏è‚É£ Setting up the Home Page
import React from 'react';
import { useWallet } from '@wallet01/react'

import { ConnectButtons } from 'components/ConnectButtons';

const Home = () => {
    const { isConnected, address, name } = useWallet()

    return (
        <div>
            {
                !isConnected ? <ConnectButtons /> : (
                    <div>
                        <span>{address}</span>
                        <span>{name}</span>
                    </div>
                )
            }
        </div>
    )
}

5Ô∏è‚É£ Final Application: (With a dash of CSS üòâ)

Easy. Quick. Effective. ‚ö°Ô∏è
Wallet01 provides a plug n‚Äô play architecture to make your dApp chain agnostic.
Want to start right away?
You can play with the above-shown app at: https://wallet01.vercel.app/
Dev docs for Wallet01 can be found here: Wallet01
Wallet01 is Huddle01‚Äôs 1st open-source initiative and can be found on GitHub

(min-width: 640px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:640px;}}@media (min-width: 768px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:768px;}}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1024px;}}@media (min-width:               var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

CSS üòâ)\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131862224/c91a5ad9-f159-4c0a-9867-ca1d6ab58785.png\\\" alt class=\\\"image--center Quick. Effective. ‚ö°Ô∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWallet01 provides a plug n‚Äô play architecture to make your dApp chain agnostic.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-want-to-start-right-away\\\"\u003eWant to start right away?\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou can play with the above-shown app at: \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://wallet01.vercel.app/\\\"\u003ehttps://wallet01.vercel.app/\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDev docs for \u003cstrong\u003eWallet01\u003c/strong\u003e can be found here: \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://www.notion.so/Wallet01-66b9a56d73964fd19614743fb7a38780\\\"\u003eWallet01\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWallet01 is Huddle01‚Äôs 1st open-source initiative and can be found on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://github.com/Huddle01/Wallet01\\\"\u003eGitHub\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"The future of web3 is multi-chain.\\n\\nUsers from numerous blockchain ecosystems are looking to engage with multiple dApps seamlessly. Hence, building a chain-agnostic application will not only get you more users but also enhance their experience. However, chain-agnostic dApps are a headache to build right now, with developers having to write custom code to incorporate multiple blockchains and their pre-existing packages.\\n\\n**Wallet01** is an open-source, multi-chain wallet package built to enable chain-agnostic interaction in your application with just a single plug in. Once added, it facilitates a smooth and reliable onboarding experience for your users from various chain ecosystems.\\n\\n## Building a chain-agnostic application is a monolithic task\\n\\nIt needs stacks of code and hours of research on the internet:\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131507463/da76cadd-21ab-493d-9241-4fb1f59e1014.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n### 1\\\\. Differing chain standards\\n\\nMismatched standards between blockchains are the biggest barrier for chain-agnostic applications:\\n\\n* Different APIs\\n    \\n* Different environment\\n    \\n* Different standards for addresses and key management\\n    \\n\\n### 2\\\\. Lack of proper documentation\\n\\nBlockchain standards are often poorly defined and are only understood after spending countless hours digging through multiple codebases.\\n\\n### 3\\\\. UX at the cost of DX\\n\\nProgrammers go to great lengths to provide a better User Experience. However, building a good chain-agnostic application looks like a trade-off for a better Developer Experience.\\n\\n## Wallet01 enables a fast \u0026 reliable DX\\n\\nIt saves you a significant amount of time researching and writing code so that you can spend that time adding more cool features to your application.\\n\\nHere‚Äôs how you can incorporate Wallet01 into your application:\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131763154/baa5f6d9-d4d5-4039-8646-2b0ceab32657.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n## **Wallet01** is an **ecosystem** of packages\\n\\nThis ecosystem makes your application light and modular, with space for more features.\\n\\n**Wallet01 Ecosystem** consists of 3 packages:\\n\\n* **Core Package**: `@wallet01/core` serves as the brain of the ecosystem, setting up the standards and procedures for all the other ecosystem packages.\\n    \\n* **Ecosystem Package**: `@wallet01/evm`, `@wallet01/solana`, and `@wallet01/cosmos` serve as the mediator between Wallet01 standards and the chain standards.\\n    \\n* **Framework Package**: `@wallet01/react` serves as the developer front, helping you scaffold a chain-agnostic application with React.\\n    \\n\\n## How does Wallet01 work?\\n\\nLet‚Äôs get into the good part: making a chain-agnostic application with Wallet01 on NextJS üßëüèª‚Äçüíª\\n\\n1Ô∏è‚É£ Installation `npm i @wallet01/react @wallet01/evm @wallet01/solana @wallet01/cosmos`\\n\\n2Ô∏è‚É£ Initiation\\n\\n```jsx\\nimport { Wallet01 } from '@wallet01/react';\\n\\nimport { InjectedConnector } from '@wallet01/evm';\\nimport { KeplrConnector } from '@wallet01/cosmos';\\nimport { PhantomConnector } from '@wallet01/solana';\\n\\nfunction MyApp({ Component, pageProps }) {\\n\\n\\tconst desiredConnectors = [\\n\\t\\tnew InjectedConnector(),\\n\\t\\tnew KeplrConnector(),\\n\\t\\tnew PhantomConnector(),\\n\\t]\\n\\n\\treturn (\\n\\t\\t\u003cWallet01 autConnect={true} connectors=(() =\u003e desiredConnectors)\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\u003cComponent {...pageProps} /\u003e\\n\\t\\t\u003c/Wallet01\u003e\\n\\t)\\n}\\n\\nexport default MyApp;\\n```\\n\\n3Ô∏è‚É£ Connect Buttons\\n\\n```jsx\\nimport React from 'react'\\nimport { useClient, useConnect, useWallet } from '@wallet01/react'\\n\\nconst ConnectButtons = () =\u003e {\\n\\tconst { connectors } = useClient()\\n\\tconst { connect } = useConnect()\\n\\n\\treturn (\\n\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t{\\n\\t\\t\\t\\tconnectors.map((connector) =\u003e (\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cbutton\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\tkey={connector.name}\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\tonCLick={() =\u003e {\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\tconnect({connector})\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t}\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t{connector.name}\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003c/button\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t))\\n\\t\\t\\t}\\n\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t) \\n}\\n\\nexport default ConnectButtons;\\n```\\n\\n4Ô∏è‚É£ Setting up the Home Page\\n\\n```jsx\\nimport React from 'react';\\nimport { useWallet } from '@wallet01/react'\\n\\nimport { ConnectButtons } from 'components/ConnectButtons';\\n\\nconst Home = () =\u003e {\\n\\tconst { isConnected, address, name } = useWallet()\\n\\n\\treturn (\\n\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t{\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t!isConnected ? \u003cConnectButtons /\u003e : (\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cspan\u003e{address}\u003c/span\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cspan\u003e{name}\u003c/span\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003c/div\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t)\\n\\t\\t\\t}\\n\\t\\t\u003c/div\u003e\\n\\t)\\n}\\n```\\n\\n5Ô∏è‚É£ Final Application: (With a dash of CSS üòâ)\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131862224/c91a5ad9-f159-4c0a-9867-ca1d6ab58785.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\nEasy. Quick. Effective. ‚ö°Ô∏è\\n\\nWallet01 provides a plug n‚Äô play architecture to make your dApp chain agnostic.\\n\\n## Want to start right away?\\n\\nYou can play with the above-shown app at: [https://wallet01.vercel.app/](https://wallet01.vercel.app/)\\n\\nDev docs for **Wallet01** can be found here: [Wallet01](https://www.notion.so/Wallet01-66b9a56d73964fd19614743fb7a38780)\\n\\nWallet01 is Huddle01‚Äôs 1st open-source initiative and can be found on [GitHub](https://github.com/Huddle01/Wallet01)\",\"hasPolls\":false,\"totalPollVotes\":0,\"upvotes\":0,\"downvotes\":0,\"tags\":[],\"untaggedFrom\":[],\"popularity\":5848.2409,\"responseCount\":0,\"replyCount\":0,\"followers\":[],\"isActive\":true,\"isFeatured\":false,\"isEngaging\":false,\"answeredByTarget\":false,\"isDelisted\":false,\"isNotified\":false,\"duplicatePosts\":[],\"numCollapsed\":0,\"hasReward\":false,\"bookmarkedIn\":[],\"reactions\":[\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d35486\",\"567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd\",\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d35484\",\"567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab9\",\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d3548b\",\"5d9dd859f31791c942dc5b52\"],\"totalReactions\":10,\"reactionsByCurrentUser\":[],\"isPinnedToBlog\":false,\"disableComments\":false,\"commentsPaused\":false,\"hasLatex\":false,\"syncAlgolia\":true,\"enableToc\":true,\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"b4aa30cd-6be4-4e86-a0c6-124164dfb399\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"building-a-chain-agnostic-application-is-a-monolithic-task\",\"title\":\"Building a chain-agnostic application is a monolithic task\"}],[{\"id\":\"1bf9ffd3-66a7-4317-9565-8b09db78ac0b\",\"level\":3,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":\"b4aa30cd-6be4-4e86-a0c6-124164dfb399\",\"slug\":\"1-differing-chain-standards\",\"title\":\"1. CSS üòâ)\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131862224/c91a5ad9-f159-4c0a-9867-ca1d6ab58785.png\\\" alt class=\\\"image--center mx-auto\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eEasy. Quick. Effective. ‚ö°Ô∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWallet01 provides a plug n‚Äô play architecture to make your dApp chain agnostic.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-want-to-start-right-away\\\"\u003eWant to start right away?\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou can play with the above-shown app at: \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://wallet01.vercel.app/\\\"\u003ehttps://wallet01.vercel.app/\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDev docs for \u003cstrong\u003eWallet01\u003c/strong\u003e can be found here: \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://www.notion.so/Wallet01-66b9a56d73964fd19614743fb7a38780\\\"\u003eWallet01\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWallet01 is Huddle01‚Äôs 1st open-source initiative and can be found on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://github.com/Huddle01/Wallet01\\\"\u003eGitHub\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"The future of web3 is multi-chain.\\n\\nUsers from numerous blockchain ecosystems are looking to engage with multiple dApps seamlessly. Hence, building a chain-agnostic application will not only get you more users but also enhance their experience. However, chain-agnostic dApps are a headache to build right now, with developers having to write custom code to incorporate multiple blockchains and their pre-existing packages.\\n\\n**Wallet01** is an open-source, multi-chain wallet package built to enable chain-agnostic interaction in your application with just a single plug in. Once added, it facilitates a smooth and reliable onboarding experience for your users from various chain ecosystems.\\n\\n## Building a chain-agnostic application is a monolithic task\\n\\nIt needs stacks of code and hours of research on the internet:\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131507463/da76cadd-21ab-493d-9241-4fb1f59e1014.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n### 1\\\\. Differing chain standards\\n\\nMismatched standards between blockchains are the biggest barrier for chain-agnostic applications:\\n\\n* Different APIs\\n    \\n* Different environment\\n    \\n* Different standards for addresses and key management\\n    \\n\\n### 2\\\\. Lack of proper documentation\\n\\nBlockchain standards are often poorly defined and are only understood after spending countless hours digging through multiple codebases.\\n\\n### 3\\\\. UX at the cost of DX\\n\\nProgrammers go to great lengths to provide a better User Experience. However, building a good chain-agnostic application looks like a trade-off for a better Developer Experience.\\n\\n## Wallet01 enables a fast \u0026 reliable DX\\n\\nIt saves you a significant amount of time researching and writing code so that you can spend that time adding more cool features to your application.\\n\\nHere‚Äôs how you can incorporate Wallet01 into your application:\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131763154/baa5f6d9-d4d5-4039-8646-2b0ceab32657.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\n## **Wallet01** is an **ecosystem** of packages\\n\\nThis ecosystem makes your application light and modular, with space for more features.\\n\\n**Wallet01 Ecosystem** consists of 3 packages:\\n\\n* **Core Package**: `@wallet01/core` serves as the brain of the ecosystem, setting up the standards and procedures for all the other ecosystem packages.\\n    \\n* **Ecosystem Package**: `@wallet01/evm`, `@wallet01/solana`, and `@wallet01/cosmos` serve as the mediator between Wallet01 standards and the chain standards.\\n    \\n* **Framework Package**: `@wallet01/react` serves as the developer front, helping you scaffold a chain-agnostic application with React.\\n    \\n\\n## How does Wallet01 work?\\n\\nLet‚Äôs get into the good part: making a chain-agnostic application with Wallet01 on NextJS üßëüèª‚Äçüíª\\n\\n1Ô∏è‚É£ Installation `npm i @wallet01/react @wallet01/evm @wallet01/solana @wallet01/cosmos`\\n\\n2Ô∏è‚É£ Initiation\\n\\n```jsx\\nimport { Wallet01 } from '@wallet01/react';\\n\\nimport { InjectedConnector } from '@wallet01/evm';\\nimport { KeplrConnector } from '@wallet01/cosmos';\\nimport { PhantomConnector } from '@wallet01/solana';\\n\\nfunction MyApp({ Component, pageProps }) {\\n\\n\\tconst desiredConnectors = [\\n\\t\\tnew InjectedConnector(),\\n\\t\\tnew KeplrConnector(),\\n\\t\\tnew PhantomConnector(),\\n\\t]\\n\\n\\treturn (\\n\\t\\t\u003cWallet01 autConnect={true} connectors=(() =\u003e desiredConnectors)\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\u003cComponent {...pageProps} /\u003e\\n\\t\\t\u003c/Wallet01\u003e\\n\\t)\\n}\\n\\nexport default MyApp;\\n```\\n\\n3Ô∏è‚É£ Connect Buttons\\n\\n```jsx\\nimport React from 'react'\\nimport { useClient, useConnect, useWallet } from '@wallet01/react'\\n\\nconst ConnectButtons = () =\u003e {\\n\\tconst { connectors } = useClient()\\n\\tconst { connect } = useConnect()\\n\\n\\treturn (\\n\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t{\\n\\t\\t\\t\\tconnectors.map((connector) =\u003e (\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cbutton\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\tkey={connector.name}\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\tonCLick={() =\u003e {\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\tconnect({connector})\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t}\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t{connector.name}\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003c/button\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t))\\n\\t\\t\\t}\\n\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t) \\n}\\n\\nexport default ConnectButtons;\\n```\\n\\n4Ô∏è‚É£ Setting up the Home Page\\n\\n```jsx\\nimport React from 'react';\\nimport { useWallet } from '@wallet01/react'\\n\\nimport { ConnectButtons } from 'components/ConnectButtons';\\n\\nconst Home = () =\u003e {\\n\\tconst { isConnected, address, name } = useWallet()\\n\\n\\treturn (\\n\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t{\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t!isConnected ? \u003cConnectButtons /\u003e : (\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cdiv\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cspan\u003e{address}\u003c/span\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003cspan\u003e{name}\u003c/span\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t\\t\u003c/div\u003e\\n\\t\\t\\t\\t)\\n\\t\\t\\t}\\n\\t\\t\u003c/div\u003e\\n\\t)\\n}\\n```\\n\\n5Ô∏è‚É£ Final Application: (With a dash of CSS üòâ)\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1672131862224/c91a5ad9-f159-4c0a-9867-ca1d6ab58785.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\nEasy. Quick. Effective. ‚ö°Ô∏è\\n\\nWallet01 provides a plug n‚Äô play architecture to make your dApp chain agnostic.\\n\\n## Want to start right away?\\n\\nYou can play with the above-shown app at: [https://wallet01.vercel.app/](https://wallet01.vercel.app/)\\n\\nDev docs for **Wallet01** can be found here: [Wallet01](https://www.notion.so/Wallet01-66b9a56d73964fd19614743fb7a38780)\\n\\nWallet01 is Huddle01‚Äôs 1st open-source initiative and can be found on [GitHub](https://github.com/Huddle01/Wallet01)\",\"hasPolls\":false,\"totalPollVotes\":0,\"upvotes\":0,\"downvotes\":0,\"tags\":[],\"untaggedFrom\":[],\"popularity\":5848.2409,\"responseCount\":0,\"replyCount\":0,\"followers\":[],\"isActive\":true,\"isFeatured\":false,\"isEngaging\":false,\"answeredByTarget\":false,\"isDelisted\":false,\"isNotified\":false,\"duplicatePosts\":[],\"numCollapsed\":0,\"hasReward\":false,\"bookmarkedIn\":[],\"reactions\":[\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d35486\",\"567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd\",\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d35484\",\"567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab9\",\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d3548b\",\"5d9dd859f31791c942dc5b52\"],\"totalReactions\":10,\"reactionsByCurrentUser\":[],\"isPinnedToBlog\":false,\"disableComments\":false,\"commentsPaused\":false,\"hasLatex\":false,\"syncAlgolia\":true,\"enableToc\":true,\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"b4aa30cd-6be4-4e86-a0c6-124164dfb399\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"building-a-chain-agnostic-application-is-a-monolithic-task\",\"title\":\"Building a chain-agnostic application is a monolithic task\"}],[{\"id\":\"1bf9ffd3-66a7-4317-9565-8b09db78ac0b\",\"level\":3,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":\"b4aa30cd-6be4-4e86-a0c6-124164dfb399\",\"slug\":\"1-differing-chain-standards\",\"title\":\"1. :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}For any digital experience-focused company, code quality security is a critical factor. The code's architecture, storage, access, and evolution are essential considerations. To manage this, all software projects utilize version control software.
Current Approaches and Multirepo
The Multirepo approach involves dividing the codebase into multiple repositories, each maintained independently. This is often the starting point for small projects. However, as the number of repositories grows, the overhead of maintaining them increases, resulting in challenges such as code duplication, dependency management, and end-to-end testing. Additionally, a small change in one repository may impact multiple repositories, requiring review and merge processes that Monorepo addresses.
What is Monorepo?
Monorepo is a central repository that holds all the code for a project or a company. Instead of having multiple repositories for different projects, all the code is stored and versioned in one place. This approach has several advantages, such as better collaboration across teams and simplified dependency management, as well as disadvantages, such as limitations around access control and version control tooling issues.
Advantages of Monorepo

Improved Team Collaboration

All projects are housed in one repository, enabling all team members to view and utilize the code, making it easier to create and leverage shared libraries and reducing technical debt.

The co-location of code makes it easier to identify and resolve inter-dependencies and potential conflicts.



Streamlined Dependency Management

Multiple teams within a company may work on different projects that share common dependencies. Storing all dependencies in a central location resolves the diamond dependency problem.

This approach allows for faster and more straightforward dependency upgrades, downgrades, and testing, and facilitates the detection of vulnerabilities in shared libraries.



Large-Scale Code Refactoring

MonoRepo allows for comprehensive code changes across multiple areas of the codebase to be executed and reviewed in a single pull request, speeding up the time to deployment.



Disadvantages of Monorepo

Build Pipeline Complexity

Each repository may have its build pipeline, making it challenging to standardize processes. To overcome this, some companies like Google and Meta have developed their build solutions.

While MonoRepo allows for module caching, the cost of setting up the infrastructure is higher.



Access Control Limitations

Access control is a major challenge in Monorepo, as granting access to the entire codebase for all engineers may not be desirable.

Open-sourcing parts of the code is more challenging, as it requires extraction of code dependencies and packages.



Version Control Tooling Issues

Large codebases, such as those at Google or Microsoft, with many tests, linters, and commits, can result in performance issues in version control systems. This led Google to develop its own VCS tool.



Huddle01 and Monorepo
The decision to use Monorepo or Multirepo ultimately depends on the specific use case and the organization's ability to effectively manage the challenges posed by Monorepo. The choice of architecture reflects and influences the company's culture, impacting factors such as speed of development, collaboration across departments, and lines of ownership.
At Huddle01, we initially used a Multirepo approach for managing our services, but as the number of services grew, we switched to a Monorepo structure using TurboRepo. This solution met our requirements for a Monorepo, including support for open-sourcing our services.

The Communication Toolkit for web3, Huddle01 powers decentralised a/v calls & chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities & users üí¨ üìû
To keep up with all the updates at Huddle01, follow us on Twitter or join our Discord.

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

To overcome this, some companies like Google and Meta have developed their build solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile MonoRepo allows for module caching, the cost of setting up the infrastructure is higher.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAccess Control Limitations\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccess control is a major challenge in Monorepo, as granting access to the entire codebase for all engineers may not be desirable.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eOpen-sourcing parts of the code is more challenging, as it requires extraction of code dependencies and packages.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVersion Control Tooling Issues\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eLarge codebases, such as those at Google or Microsoft, with many tests, linters, and commits, can result in performance issues in version control systems. This led Google to develop its own VCS tool.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-and-monorepo\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHuddle01 and Monorepo\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe decision to use Monorepo or Multirepo ultimately depends on the specific use case and the organization's ability to effectively manage the challenges posed by Monorepo. The choice of architecture reflects and influences the company's culture, impacting factors such as speed of development, collaboration across departments, and lines of ownership.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAt Huddle01, we initially used a Multirepo approach for managing our services, but as the number of services grew, we switched to a Monorepo structure using TurboRepo. This solution met our requirements for a Monorepo, including support for open-sourcing our services.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003chr /\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe Communication Toolkit for web3, \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/\\\"\u003eHuddle01\u003c/a\u003e powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026amp; chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026amp; users üí¨ üìû\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo keep up with all the updates at Huddle01, follow us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or join our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://t.co/xJXlcCKBNi\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"For any digital experience-focused company, code quality security is a critical factor. The code's architecture, storage, access, and evolution are essential considerations. To manage this, all software projects utilize version control software.\\n\\n### **Current Approaches and Multirepo**\\n\\nThe Multirepo approach involves dividing the codebase into multiple repositories, each maintained independently. This is often the starting point for small projects. However, as the number of repositories grows, the overhead of maintaining them increases, resulting in challenges such as code duplication, dependency management, and end-to-end testing. Additionally, a small change in one repository may impact multiple repositories, requiring review and merge processes that Monorepo addresses.\\n\\n### **What is Monorepo?**\\n\\nMonorepo is a central repository that holds all the code for a project or a company. Instead of having multiple repositories for different projects, all the code is stored and versioned in one place. This approach has several advantages, such as better collaboration across teams and simplified dependency management, as well as disadvantages, such as limitations around access control and version control tooling issues.\\n\\n### **Advantages of Monorepo**\\n\\n1. **Improved Team Collaboration**\\n    \\n    1. All projects are housed in one repository, enabling all team members to view and utilize the code, making it easier to create and leverage shared libraries and reducing technical debt.\\n        \\n    2. The co-location of code makes it easier to identify and resolve inter-dependencies and potential conflicts.\\n        \\n2. **Streamlined Dependency Management**\\n    \\n    1. Multiple teams within a company may work on different projects that share common dependencies. Storing all dependencies in a central location resolves the diamond dependency problem.\\n        \\n    2. This approach allows for faster and more straightforward dependency upgrades, downgrades, and testing, and facilitates the detection of vulnerabilities in shared libraries.\\n        \\n3. **Large-Scale Code Refactoring**\\n    \\n    1. MonoRepo allows for comprehensive code changes across multiple areas of the codebase to be executed and reviewed in a single pull request, speeding up the time to deployment.\\n        \\n\\n### **Disadvantages of Monorepo**\\n\\n1. **Build Pipeline Complexity**\\n    \\n    1. Each repository may have its build pipeline, making it challenging to standardize processes. To overcome this, some companies like Google and Meta have developed their build solutions.\\n        \\n    2. While MonoRepo allows for module caching, the cost of setting up the infrastructure is higher.\\n        \\n2. **Access Control Limitations**\\n    \\n    1. Access control is a major challenge in Monorepo, as granting access to the entire codebase for all engineers may not be desirable.\\n        \\n    2. Open-sourcing parts of the code is more challenging, as it requires extraction of code dependencies and packages.\\n        \\n3. **Version Control Tooling Issues**\\n    \\n    1. Large codebases, such as those at Google or Microsoft, with many tests, linters, and commits, can result in performance issues in version control systems. This led Google to develop its own VCS tool.\\n        \\n\\n### **Huddle01 and Monorepo**\\n\\nThe decision to use Monorepo or Multirepo ultimately depends on the specific use case and the organization's ability to effectively manage the challenges posed by Monorepo. The choice of architecture reflects and influences the company's culture, impacting factors such as speed of development, collaboration across departments, and lines of ownership.\\n\\nAt Huddle01, we initially used a Multirepo approach for managing our services, but as the number of services grew, we switched to a Monorepo structure using TurboRepo. This solution met our requirements for a Monorepo, including support for open-sourcing our services.\\n\\n---\\n\\nThe Communication Toolkit for web3, [Huddle01](https://huddle01.com/) powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026 chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026 users üí¨ üìû\\n\\nTo keep up with all the updates at Huddle01, follow us on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or join our [Discord](https://t.co/xJXlcCKBNi).\",\"hasPolls\":false,\"totalPollVotes\":0,\"upvotes\":0,\"downvotes\":0,\"tags\":[],\"untaggedFrom\":[],\"popularity\":5926.0342,\"responseCount\":0,\"replyCount\":0,\"followers\":[],\"isActive\":true,\"isFeatured\":false,\"isEngaging\":false,\"answeredByTarget\":false,\"isDelisted\":false,\"isNotified\":false,\"duplicatePosts\":[],\"numCollapsed\":0,\"hasReward\":false,\"bookmarkedIn\":[],\"reactions\":[],\"totalReactions\":1,\"reactionsByCurrentUser\":[],\"totalReactionsByCurrentUser\":0,\"isPinnedToBlog\":false,\"disableComments\":false,\"commentsPaused\":false,\"hasLatex\":false,\"syncAlgolia\":false,\"enableToc\":true,\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"72be9c37-aa40-4904-a461-3c844972cd9a\",\"level\":3,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"current-approaches-and-multirepo\",\"title\":\"Current
