The code's architecture, storage, access, and evolution are essential considerations. To manage this, all software projects utilize version control software.\\nCurr...\",\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eFor any digital experience-focused company, code quality security is a critical factor. The code's architecture, storage, access, and evolution are essential considerations. To manage this, all software projects utilize version control software.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-current-approaches-and-multirepo\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCurrent Approaches and Multirepo\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe Multirepo approach involves dividing the codebase into multiple repositories, each maintained independently. This is often the starting point for small projects. However, as the number of repositories grows, the overhead of maintaining them increases, resulting in challenges such as code duplication, dependency management, and end-to-end testing. Additionally, a small change in one repository may impact multiple repositories, requiring review and merge processes that Monorepo addresses.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-what-is-monorepo\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is Monorepo?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eMonorepo is a central repository that holds all the code for a project or a company. Instead of having multiple repositories for different projects, all the code is stored and versioned in one place. This approach has several advantages, such as better collaboration across teams and simplified dependency management, as well as disadvantages, such as limitations around access control and version control tooling issues.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-advantages-of-monorepo\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdvantages of Monorepo\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImproved Team Collaboration\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eAll projects are housed in one repository, enabling all team members to view and utilize the code, making it easier to create and leverage shared libraries and reducing technical debt.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe co-location of code makes it easier to identify and resolve inter-dependencies and potential conflicts.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStreamlined Dependency Management\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eMultiple teams within a company may work on different projects that share common dependencies. Storing all dependencies in a central location resolves the diamond dependency problem.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis approach allows for faster and more straightforward dependency upgrades, downgrades, and testing, and facilitates the detection of vulnerabilities in shared libraries.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLarge-Scale Code Refactoring\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eMonoRepo allows for comprehensive code changes across multiple areas of the codebase to be executed and reviewed in a single pull request, speeding up the time to deployment.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-disadvantages-of-monorepo\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDisadvantages of Monorepo\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuild Pipeline Complexity\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eEach repository may have its build pipeline, making it challenging to standardize processes. To overcome this, some companies like Google and Meta have developed their build solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile MonoRepo allows for module caching, the cost of setting up the infrastructure is higher.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAccess Control Limitations\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eAccess control is a major challenge in Monorepo, as granting access to the entire codebase for all engineers may not be desirable.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eOpen-sourcing parts of the code is more challenging, as it requires extraction of code dependencies and packages.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVersion Control Tooling Issues\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eLarge codebases, such as those at Google or Microsoft, with many tests, linters, and commits, can result in performance issues in version control systems. This led Google to develop its own VCS tool.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-and-monorepo\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHuddle01 and Monorepo\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe decision to use Monorepo or Multirepo ultimately depends on the specific use case and the organization's ability to effectively manage the challenges posed by Monorepo. The choice of architecture reflects and influences the company's culture, impacting factors such as speed of development, collaboration across departments, and lines of ownership.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAt Huddle01, we initially used a Multirepo approach for managing our services, but as the number of services grew, we switched to a Monorepo structure using TurboRepo. This solution met our requirements for a Monorepo, including support for open-sourcing our services.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003chr /\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe Communication Toolkit for web3, \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/\\\"\u003eHuddle01\u003c/a\u003e powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026amp; chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026amp; users üí¨ üìû\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo keep up with all the updates at Huddle01, follow us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or join our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://t.co/xJXlcCKBNi\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"For any digital experience-focused company, code quality security is a critical factor. The code's architecture, storage, access, and evolution are essential considerations. To manage this, all software projects utilize version control software.\\n\\n### **Current Approaches and Multirepo**\\n\\nThe Multirepo approach involves dividing the codebase into multiple repositories, each maintained independently. This is often the starting point for small projects. However, as the number of repositories grows, the overhead of maintaining them increases, resulting in challenges such as code duplication, dependency management, and end-to-end testing. Additionally, a small change in one repository may impact multiple repositories, requiring review and merge processes that Monorepo addresses.\\n\\n### **What is Monorepo?**\\n\\nMonorepo is a central repository that holds all the code for a project or a company. Instead of having multiple repositories for different projects, all the code is stored and versioned in one place. This approach has several advantages, such as better collaboration across teams and simplified dependency management, as well as disadvantages, such as limitations around access control and version control tooling issues.\\n\\n### **Advantages of Monorepo**\\n\\n1. **Improved Team Collaboration**\\n    \\n    1. All projects are housed in one repository, enabling all team members to view and utilize the code, making it easier to create and leverage shared libraries and reducing technical debt.\\n        \\n    2. The co-location of code makes it easier to identify and resolve inter-dependencies and potential conflicts.\\n        \\n2. **Streamlined Dependency Management**\\n    \\n    1. Multiple teams within a company may work on different projects that share common dependencies. Storing all dependencies in a central location resolves the diamond dependency problem.\\n        \\n    2. This approach allows for faster and more straightforward dependency upgrades, downgrades, and testing, and facilitates the detection of vulnerabilities in shared libraries.\\n        \\n3. **Large-Scale Code Refactoring**\\n    \\n    1. MonoRepo allows for comprehensive code changes across multiple areas of the codebase to be executed and reviewed in a single pull request, speeding up the time to deployment.\\n        \\n\\n### **Disadvantages of Monorepo**\\n\\n1. **Build Pipeline Complexity**\\n    \\n    1. Each repository may have its build pipeline, making it challenging to standardize processes. To overcome this, some companies like Google and Meta have developed their build solutions.\\n        \\n    2. While MonoRepo allows for module caching, the cost of setting up the infrastructure is higher.\\n        \\n2. **Access Control Limitations**\\n    \\n    1. Access control is a major challenge in Monorepo, as granting access to the entire codebase for all engineers may not be desirable.\\n        \\n    2. Open-sourcing parts of the code is more challenging, as it requires extraction of code dependencies and packages.\\n        \\n3. **Version Control Tooling Issues**\\n    \\n    1. Large codebases, such as those at Google or Microsoft, with many tests, linters, and commits, can result in performance issues in version control systems. This led Google to develop its own VCS tool.\\n        \\n\\n### **Huddle01 and Monorepo**\\n\\nThe decision to use Monorepo or Multirepo ultimately depends on the specific use case and the organization's ability to effectively manage the challenges posed by Monorepo. The choice of architecture reflects and influences the company's culture, impacting factors such as speed of development, collaboration across departments, and lines of ownership.\\n\\nAt Huddle01, we initially used a Multirepo approach for managing our services, but as the number of services grew, we switched to a Monorepo structure using TurboRepo. This solution met our requirements for a Monorepo, including support for open-sourcing our services.\\n\\n---\\n\\nThe Communication Toolkit for web3, [Huddle01](https://huddle01.com/) powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026 chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026 users üí¨ üìû\\n\\nTo keep up with all the updates at Huddle01, follow us on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or join our Huddle01 is building the next innovation in the communication space via the internet. We are taking a progressive decentralized approach while keeping privacy and security intact! With that said, we are also taking a product-first approach while making the dRTC, a decentralized RTC protocol.
Let‚Äôs dive into today‚Äôs topic, live streaming!
You might wonder, "How did it start?"
In the early days of the internet, there were services like Real Player **that were popular among the early adopters of the internet. This was a service that allowed anyone to stream live videos of themselves to the world. There were no real guidelines or policing of the content. This allowed for a lot of interesting, and sometimes very strange, content to be streamed live.
As the internet became more mainstream, platforms like YouTube and Twitch emerged as live streaming platforms for creators, media outlets, and even a new line of creators called live streamers!
With the rise of 5G and other new technologies, we are seeing a new wave of live-streaming platforms and services emerge. We are also seeing a lot of new use cases for live streaming. Some of these include, but are not limited to:

Online Education
Gaming
Sports
Music
Conferences and events

The list goes on and on. The possibilities are endless!
As the world starts to adapt to the new normal, we are seeing a lot of these use cases become even more popular.
How big is live streaming?

Live streaming is becoming one of the most essential services in the entertainment market today. Almost all social platforms have live streaming as an option. Many creators are full-time streamers on various platforms while they live-stream different activities like gaming, the entertainment industry, making art, singing, etc. This enabled a new industry inside the entertainment industry.
This industry is growing exponentially and is only going to get bigger. In 2019, the global live-streaming market was valued at around 12.65 billion USD and was projected to reach around 30.79 billion USD by 2025, at a CAGR of around 17.5% during the forecast period from 2020 to 2025.
This industry is still in its early days and has a lot of potential for growth. This is evident by the amount of investment that is going into the live-streaming industry. Just in the past year, we have seen a lot of companies raise a lot of money to invest in the live-streaming industry. Some of these companies include

Stacked (12.9 Million USD)
Caffeine (100 Million USD)
Loco (42 Million USD)

This begs the question: Why is live streaming so popular?
Usually, movies, TV shows, and other forms of entertainment follow a script, which limits what the audience can see and how they can interact with the actors.
People can actually live the experiences with creators; they can also interact with them and mark that as an experience. This is similar to watching a live match of any sport; you can always watch the highlights, but when witnessed in real-time, they give an immeasurable amazing experience.
Creators can also get rapid feedback for their content and even plan their future content around the feedback given by the viewers in real time. This is something that is not possible in any other form of entertainment.
Huddle01 and Live Streaming

Apart from the need for a high-speed internet connection and a good computer, there are other challenges with the current state of live streaming.
There are various platforms one has to pick to Livestream, and there is also an issue with choosing hardware or software solutions for live streaming. Multistreaming is a solution, but it costs a lot and has specific requirements for the speed of the Internet and the hardware.
With Huddle01, we intend to make the process of live streaming simple, efficient, and cost-effective for all types of creators from all around the globe.
How is Huddle01 efficient for live streaming?
Huddle01 has a few key features that make it efficient for live streaming. These are:

One-click streaming
Universal format

We allow live streaming directly from our app to major streaming platforms.
Follow these steps to directly stream to YouTube via Huddle01.
Step 1: Open Huddle01

Step 2: Go to Tools.

Step 3: Visit studio.youtube.com & click on Go live.

Step 4: Put in your keys, and you are live!

Similarly, the same steps apply to going live on Twitch and Livepeer.
We currently support Twitch, YouTube, and Livepeer as our streaming partners. Soon, we'll also add a multistreaming feature that will let creators go live on more than one platform at the same time.
With Huddle01, you don‚Äôt need any fancy equipment or expensive service; you just need a browser and you are good to go.
Whats next?

As I mentioned earlier, we are coming out with a Multistream feature that would be a solution for many creators. If you are a live-streaming platform, reach out to us, and we‚Äôll add support for your platform too! Also, if you are a creator who is looking for a live-streaming platform, we highly recommend giving us a try!
We are also coming up with other interesting use cases for our platform, and live streaming is certainly one of them. We will be announcing more about them very soon. So stay tuned for more blogs, tutorials, and announcements coming your way.
That‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out to us on Twitter or land on our Discord! See you at the next one üëã

var(--tw-bg-opacity));}.css-oyfwdt{width:100%;position:relative;z-index:20;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;display:grid;grid-auto-flow:row;grid-template-columns:repeat(8, minmax(0, 1fr));}@media (min-width: 640px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:640px;}}@media (min-width: 768px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:768px;}}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1024px;}}@media (min-width:               var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

We are taking a progressive decentralized approach while keeping privacy and security intact! With that said, we are also taking a product-first approach while making the dRTC, a decentralized RTC protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs dive into today‚Äôs topic, live streaming!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou might wonder, \u003cstrong\u003e\\\"How did it start?\\\"\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn the early days of the internet, there were services like \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://justin.tv/\\\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eReal Player \u003cem\u003e**\u003c/em\u003ethat were popular among the early adopters of the internet. This was a service that allowed anyone to stream live videos of themselves to the world. There were no real guidelines or policing of the content. This allowed for a lot of interesting, and sometimes very strange, content to be streamed live.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the internet became more mainstream, platforms like YouTube and Twitch emerged as live streaming platforms for creators, media outlets, and even a new line of creators called live streamers!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith the rise of 5G and other new technologies, we are seeing a new wave of live-streaming platforms and services emerge. Almost all social platforms have live streaming as an option. Many creators are full-time streamers on various platforms while they live-stream different activities like gaming, the entertainment industry, making art, singing, etc. This enabled a new industry inside the entertainment industry.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis industry is growing exponentially and is only going to get bigger. In 2019, the global live-streaming market was valued at around 12.65 billion USD and was projected to reach around 30.79 billion USD by 2025, at a CAGR of around 17.5% during the forecast period from 2020 to 2025.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis industry is still in its early days and has a lot of potential for growth. This is evident by the amount of investment that is going into the live-streaming industry. Just in the past year, we have seen a lot of companies raise a lot of money to invest in the live-streaming industry. Some of these companies include\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eStacked (12.9 Million USD)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCaffeine (100 Million USD)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eLoco (42 Million USD)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis begs the question: \u003cstrong\u003eWhy is live streaming so popular?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eUsually, movies, TV shows, and other forms of entertainment follow a script, which limits what the audience can see and how they can interact with the actors.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003ePeople can actually live the experiences with creators; they can also interact with them and mark that as an experience. This is similar to watching a live match of any sport; you can always watch the highlights, but when witnessed in real-time, they give an immeasurable amazing experience.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eCreators can also get rapid feedback for their content and even plan their future content around the feedback given by the viewers in real time. This is something that is not possible in any other form of entertainment.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-and-live-streaming\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHuddle01 and Live Streaming\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002942782/hx8cWOT-r.png\\\" alt=\\\"Huddle01 and livestreaming.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eApart from the need for a high-speed internet connection and a good computer, there are other challenges with the current state of live streaming.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are various platforms one has to pick to Livestream, and there is also an issue with choosing hardware or software solutions for live streaming. Multistreaming is a solution, but it costs a lot and has specific requirements for the speed of the Internet and the hardware.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith Huddle01, we intend to make the process of live streaming simple, efficient, and cost-effective for all types of creators from all around the globe.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHow is Huddle01 efficient for live streaming?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 has a few key features that make it efficient for live streaming. We are taking a progressive decentralized approach while keeping privacy and security intact! With that said, we are also taking a product-first approach while making the dRTC, a decentralized RTC protocol.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs dive into today‚Äôs topic, live streaming!\\n\\nYou might wonder, **\\\"How did it start?\\\"**\\n\\nIn the early days of the internet, there were services like [](http://justin.tv/)Real Player ****that were popular among the early adopters of the internet. This was a service that allowed anyone to stream live videos of themselves to the world. There were no real guidelines or policing of the content. This allowed for a lot of interesting, and sometimes very strange, content to be streamed live.\\n\\nAs the internet became more mainstream, platforms like YouTube and Twitch emerged as live streaming platforms for creators, media outlets, and even a new line of creators called live streamers!\\n\\nWith the rise of 5G and other new technologies, we are seeing a new wave of live-streaming platforms and services emerge. We are also seeing a lot of new use cases for live streaming. Some of these include, but are not limited to:\\n\\n- Online Education\\n- Gaming\\n- Sports\\n- Music\\n- Conferences and events\\n\\nThe list goes on and on. The possibilities are endless!\\n\\nAs the world starts to adapt to the new normal, we are seeing a lot of these use cases become even more popular.\\n\\n## **How big is live streaming?**\\n\\n\\n![livestreaming market.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002911983/IDpuy0gIr.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLive streaming is becoming one of the most essential services in the entertainment market today. Almost all social platforms have live streaming as an option. Many creators are full-time streamers on various platforms while they live-stream different activities like gaming, the entertainment industry, making art, singing, etc. This enabled a new industry inside the entertainment industry.\\n\\nThis industry is growing exponentially and is only going to get bigger. In 2019, the global live-streaming market was valued at around 12.65 billion USD and was projected to reach around 30.79 billion USD by 2025, at a CAGR of around 17.5% during the forecast period from 2020 to 2025.\\n\\nThis industry is still in its early days and has a lot of potential for growth. This is evident by the amount of investment that is going into the live-streaming industry. Just in the past year, we have seen a lot of companies raise a lot of money to invest in the live-streaming industry. Some of these companies include\\n\\n- Stacked (12.9 Million USD)\\n- Caffeine (100 Million USD)\\n- Loco (42 Million USD)\\n\\nThis begs the question: **Why is live streaming so popular?**\\n\\nUsually, movies, TV shows, and other forms of entertainment follow a script, which limits what the audience can see and how they can interact with the actors.\\n\\nPeople can actually live the experiences with creators; they can also interact with them and mark that as an experience. This is similar to watching a live match of any sport; you can always watch the highlights, but when witnessed in real-time, they give an immeasurable amazing experience.\\n\\nCreators can also get rapid feedback for their content and even plan their future content around the feedback given by the viewers in real time. This is something that is not possible in any other form of entertainment.\\n\\n## **Huddle01 and Live Streaming**\\n\\n\\n![Huddle01 and livestreaming.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002942782/hx8cWOT-r.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nApart from the need for a high-speed internet connection and a good computer, there are other challenges with the current state of live streaming.\\n\\nThere are various platforms one has to pick to Livestream, and there is also an issue with choosing hardware or software solutions for live streaming. Multistreaming is a solution, but it costs a lot and has specific requirements for the speed of the Internet and the hardware.\\n\\nWith Huddle01, we intend to make the process of live streaming simple, efficient, and cost-effective for all types of creators from all around the globe.\\n\\nHow is Huddle01 efficient for live streaming?\\n\\nHuddle01 has a few key features that make it efficient for live streaming. These are:\\n\\n- One-click streaming\\n- Universal format\\n\\nWe allow live streaming directly from our app to major streaming platforms.\\n\\nFollow these steps to directly stream to YouTube via Huddle01.\\n\\nStep 1: Open Huddle01\\n\\n![Untitled.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002973475/hGH6_mVTN.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nStep 2: Go to Tools.\\n\\n\\n![Step 1_ Visit \u0026 start a meeting then click on ‚ÄúTools‚Äù üõ†.gif](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002991674/LIXudkaVD.gif align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nStep 3: Visit http://studio.youtube.com \u0026 click on Go live.\\n\\n![Step 2_ Visit \u0026 click on Go live üöÄ.gif](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003019768/qkdScwn0P.gif align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nStep 4: Put in your keys, and you are live!\\n\\n![Step_3__Fill_in_the_respective_details___you_will_be_live_üî•_AdobeExpress.gif](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003152878/P1NDXeI40.gif align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nSimilarly, the same steps apply to going live on Twitch and Livepeer.\\n\\nWe currently support Twitch, YouTube, and Livepeer as our streaming partners. Soon, we'll also add a multistreaming feature that will let creators go live on more than one platform at the same time.\\n\\nWith Huddle01, you don‚Äôt need any fancy equipment or expensive service; you just need a browser and you are good to go.\\n\\n## **Whats next?**\\n\\n![whats next.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003120261/qWng3oREr.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAs I mentioned earlier, we are coming out with a Multistream feature that would be a solution for many creators. We are taking a progressive decentralized approach while keeping privacy and security intact! With that said, we are also taking a product-first approach while making the dRTC, a decentralized RTC protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs dive into today‚Äôs topic, live streaming!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou might wonder, \u003cstrong\u003e\\\"How did it start?\\\"\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn the early days of the internet, there were services like \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://justin.tv/\\\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eReal Player \u003cem\u003e**\u003c/em\u003ethat were popular among the early adopters of the internet. This was a service that allowed anyone to stream live videos of themselves to the world. There were no real guidelines or policing of the content. This allowed for a lot of interesting, and sometimes very strange, content to be streamed live.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the internet became more mainstream, platforms like YouTube and Twitch emerged as live streaming platforms for creators, media outlets, and even a new line of creators called live streamers!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith the rise of 5G and other new technologies, we are seeing a new wave of live-streaming platforms and services emerge. We are also seeing a lot of new use cases for live streaming. Some of these include, but are not limited to:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eOnline Education\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eGaming\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSports\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eMusic\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eConferences and events\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe list goes on and on. The possibilities are endless!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the world starts to adapt to the new normal, we are seeing a lot of these use cases become even more popular.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-big-is-live-streaming\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow big is live streaming?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002911983/IDpuy0gIr.png\\\" alt=\\\"livestreaming market.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLive streaming is becoming one of the most essential services in the entertainment market today. Almost all social platforms have live streaming as an option. Many creators are full-time streamers on various platforms while they live-stream different activities like gaming, the entertainment industry, making art, singing, etc. This enabled a new industry inside the entertainment industry.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis industry is growing exponentially and is only going to get bigger. In 2019, the global live-streaming market was valued at around 12.65 billion USD and was projected to reach around 30.79 billion USD by 2025, at a CAGR of around 17.5% during the forecast period from 2020 to 2025.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis industry is still in its early days and has a lot of potential for growth. This is evident by the amount of investment that is going into the live-streaming industry. Just in the past year, we have seen a lot of companies raise a lot of money to invest in the live-streaming industry. Some of these companies include\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eStacked (12.9 Million USD)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCaffeine (100 Million USD)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eLoco (42 Million USD)\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis begs the question: \u003cstrong\u003eWhy is live streaming so popular?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eUsually, movies, TV shows, and other forms of entertainment follow a script, which limits what the audience can see and how they can interact with the actors.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003ePeople can actually live the experiences with creators; they can also interact with them and mark that as an experience. This is similar to watching a live match of any sport; you can always watch the highlights, but when witnessed in real-time, they give an immeasurable amazing experience.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eCreators can also get rapid feedback for their content and even plan their future content around the feedback given by the viewers in real time. This is something that is not possible in any other form of entertainment.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-and-live-streaming\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHuddle01 and Live Streaming\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002942782/hx8cWOT-r.png\\\" alt=\\\"Huddle01 and livestreaming.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eApart from the need for a high-speed internet connection and a good computer, there are other challenges with the current state of live streaming.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are various platforms one has to pick to Livestream, and there is also an issue with choosing hardware or software solutions for live streaming. Multistreaming is a solution, but it costs a lot and has specific requirements for the speed of the Internet and the hardware.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith Huddle01, we intend to make the process of live streaming simple, efficient, and cost-effective for all types of creators from all around the globe.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHow is Huddle01 efficient for live streaming?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 has a few key features that make it efficient for live streaming. These are:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eOne-click streaming\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eUniversal format\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe allow live streaming directly from our app to major streaming platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFollow these steps to directly stream to YouTube via Huddle01.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eStep 1: Open Huddle01\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002973475/hGH6_mVTN.png\\\" alt=\\\"Untitled.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eStep 2: Go to Tools.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002991674/LIXudkaVD.gif\\\" alt=\\\"Step 1_ Visit \u0026amp; start a meeting then click on ‚ÄúTools‚Äù üõ†.gif\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eStep 3: Visit \u003ca href=\\\"http://studio.youtube.com\\\" class=\\\"autolinkedURL autolinkedURL-url\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003estudio.youtube.com\u003c/a\u003e \u0026amp; click on Go live.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003019768/qkdScwn0P.gif\\\" alt=\\\"Step 2_ Visit \u0026amp; click on Go live üöÄ.gif\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eStep 4: Put in your keys, and you are live!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003152878/P1NDXeI40.gif\\\" alt=\\\"Step_3__Fill_in_the_respective_details___you_will_be_live_üî•_AdobeExpress.gif\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly, the same steps apply to going live on Twitch and Livepeer.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe currently support Twitch, YouTube, and Livepeer as our streaming partners. Soon, we'll also add a multistreaming feature that will let creators go live on more than one platform at the same time.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith Huddle01, you don‚Äôt need any fancy equipment or expensive service; you just need a browser and you are good to go.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-whats-next\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhats next?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003120261/qWng3oREr.png\\\" alt=\\\"whats next.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs I mentioned earlier, we are coming out with a Multistream feature that would be a solution for many creators. Also, if you are a creator who is looking for a live-streaming platform, we highly recommend giving us a try!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are also coming up with other interesting use cases for our platform, and live streaming is certainly one of them. See you at the next one üëã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![Huddle01 for streamers.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002864464/FbRD7RCi2.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is building the next innovation in the communication space via the internet. We are taking a progressive decentralized approach while keeping privacy and security intact! With that said, we are also taking a product-first approach while making the dRTC, a decentralized RTC protocol.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs dive into today‚Äôs topic, live streaming!\\n\\nYou might wonder, **\\\"How did it start?\\\"**\\n\\nIn the early days of the internet, there were services like [](http://justin.tv/)Real Player ****that were popular among the early adopters of the internet. This was a service that allowed anyone to stream live videos of themselves to the world. There were no real guidelines or policing of the content. This allowed for a lot of interesting, and sometimes very strange, content to be streamed live.\\n\\nAs the internet became more mainstream, platforms like YouTube and Twitch emerged as live streaming platforms for creators, media outlets, and even a new line of creators called live streamers!\\n\\nWith the rise of 5G and other new technologies, we are seeing a new wave of live-streaming platforms and services emerge. We are also seeing a lot of new use cases for live streaming. Some of these include, but are not limited to:\\n\\n- Online Education\\n- Gaming\\n- Sports\\n- Music\\n- Conferences and events\\n\\nThe list goes on and on. The possibilities are endless!\\n\\nAs the world starts to adapt to the new normal, we are seeing a lot of these use cases become even more popular.\\n\\n## **How big is live streaming?**\\n\\n\\n![livestreaming market.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002911983/IDpuy0gIr.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLive streaming is becoming one of the most essential services in the entertainment market today. Almost all social platforms have live streaming as an option. Many creators are full-time streamers on various platforms while they live-stream different activities like gaming, the entertainment industry, making art, singing, etc. This enabled a new industry inside the entertainment industry.\\n\\nThis industry is growing exponentially and is only going to get bigger. In 2019, the global live-streaming market was valued at around 12.65 billion USD and was projected to reach around 30.79 billion USD by 2025, at a CAGR of around 17.5% during the forecast period from 2020 to 2025.\\n\\nThis industry is still in its early days and has a lot of potential for growth. This is evident by the amount of investment that is going into the live-streaming industry. Just in the past year, we have seen a lot of companies raise a lot of money to invest in the live-streaming industry. Some of these companies include\\n\\n- Stacked (12.9 Million USD)\\n- Caffeine (100 Million USD)\\n- Loco (42 Million USD)\\n\\nThis begs the question: **Why is live streaming so popular?**\\n\\nUsually, movies, TV shows, and other forms of entertainment follow a script, which limits what the audience can see and how they can interact with the actors.\\n\\nPeople can actually live the experiences with creators; they can also interact with them and mark that as an experience. This is similar to watching a live match of any sport; you can always watch the highlights, but when witnessed in real-time, they give an immeasurable amazing experience.\\n\\nCreators can also get rapid feedback for their content and even plan their future content around the feedback given by the viewers in real time. This is something that is not possible in any other form of entertainment.\\n\\n## **Huddle01 and Live Streaming**\\n\\n\\n![Huddle01 and livestreaming.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002942782/hx8cWOT-r.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nApart from the need for a high-speed internet connection and a good computer, there are other challenges with the current state of live streaming.\\n\\nThere are various platforms one has to pick to Livestream, and there is also an issue with choosing hardware or software solutions for live streaming. Multistreaming is a solution, but it costs a lot and has specific requirements for the speed of the Internet and the hardware.\\n\\nWith Huddle01, we intend to make the process of live streaming simple, efficient, and cost-effective for all types of creators from all around the globe.\\n\\nHow is Huddle01 efficient for live streaming?\\n\\nHuddle01 has a few key features that make it efficient for live streaming. These are:\\n\\n- One-click streaming\\n- Universal format\\n\\nWe allow live streaming directly from our app to major streaming platforms.\\n\\nFollow these steps to directly stream to YouTube via Huddle01.\\n\\nStep 1: Open Huddle01\\n\\n![Untitled.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002973475/hGH6_mVTN.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nStep 2: Go to Tools.\\n\\n\\n![Step 1_ Visit \u0026 start a meeting then click on ‚ÄúTools‚Äù üõ†.gif](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668002991674/LIXudkaVD.gif align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nStep 3: Visit http://studio.youtube.com \u0026 click on Go live.\\n\\n![Step 2_ Visit \u0026 click on Go live üöÄ.gif](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003019768/qkdScwn0P.gif align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nStep 4: Put in your keys, and you are live!\\n\\n![Step_3__Fill_in_the_respective_details___you_will_be_live_üî•_AdobeExpress.gif](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003152878/P1NDXeI40.gif align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nSimilarly, the same steps apply to going live on Twitch and Livepeer.\\n\\nWe currently support Twitch, YouTube, and Livepeer as our streaming partners. Soon, we'll also add a multistreaming feature that will let creators go live on more than one platform at the same time.\\n\\nWith Huddle01, you don‚Äôt need any fancy equipment or expensive service; you just need a browser and you are good to go.\\n\\n## **Whats next?**\\n\\n![whats next.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1668003120261/qWng3oREr.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAs I mentioned earlier, we are coming out with a Multistream feature that would be a solution for many creators. If you are a live-streaming platform, reach out to us, and we‚Äôll add support for your platform too! Also, if you are a creator who is looking for a live-streaming platform, we highly recommend giving us a try!\\n\\nWe are also coming up with other interesting use cases for our platform, and live streaming is certainly one of them. We will be announcing more about them very soon. So stay tuned for more blogs, tutorials, and announcements coming your way.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out to us on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg)! td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}
Huddle01 is developing the next generation of real-time communications systems through progressive decentralization. We are developing a dRTC engine that will allow technical and social primitives to operate on existing L1 and L2 networks.
If we think about a video, it is just a series of images updating at high speed. Even old movies that used "photo reels" worked on this concept. Our minds tend to see this as motion or moving things, so it is considered to be moving. This principle is still used today, everywhere; just individual images are called "frames," not "pictures"

Fun fact: If you go below 30 frames per second, you can see that it‚Äôs a series of frames. Also, if you go above 60 FPS, you can‚Äôt tell much difference.

What does it have to do with Simulcast, and what is Simulcast anyway?

Simulcast allows publishers to distribute multiple versions of the same A/V stream in various encodings. Huddle01 receives multiple streams and chooses the best one for each subscriber based on network conditions.
If you understand the frame concept in a video, it is easy to grasp the workings of Simulcast.
Scalable Video Codecs (SVCs)

These are the types of video codecs that let a single media stream be encoded in different ways to meet different bitrates and resolutions. This is preferable to making multiple versions of the stream. Although VP9 and AV1 are newer codecs with built-in scalability (SVCs), they have the following drawbacks: 
AV1 is only compatible with browsers that use the Chromium engine simulcast. 
VP9 is compute-intensive and recently received Safari Support in v15.0
Since SVCs are not yet compatible everywhere, we use more reliable codecs like VP8 and RTX for simulcast. We like VP9 for our Huddle01 mobile app because it frees us from browser limitations, which is a problem we often run into when developing with WebRTC (different browsers support different levels of video encoders and decoders, so fallbacks are needed).
Spatial Layering
Spatial layers are the different streams that the client publisher is sending out with different encodings, which in this case means different video qualities. In Huddle01‚Äôs case, we support creating three spatial layers: 
High resolution(1080p) 
Medium resolution(720p) 
Low resolution (480p) of the same A/V stream encoded at different bitrates.

In the image above, you can see an example of two spatial layers. A larger frame means that the video quality is better.
The streams go to huddle01's media server, which chooses which layers to send to the viewer. From a viewer's perspective, it keeps receiving one layer, which is dynamically switched by the Media Server based on the viewer's network conditions, while the viewer gets one smooth stream without noticing any visible switching. That is the magic of simulcast!
Temporal Layering
Temporal is just a geeky word for time. So these layers are separated by time, and it is the ability of our media server to dynamically change the frame rate on the fly without affecting the resolution. 
Let's understand a little about how encoders work. There are two types of frames:
Keyframes: These are full-frame images
Delta frames: These only have the difference in the new frame with respect to the keyframe
Delta frames are usually smaller in size compared to keyframes, so encoders rely heavily on them; they also depend on the previous frames.
Encoded streams mostly contain delta frames.
Let's take this example where there is only one temporal layer

We have one temporal layer, T1, in which each frame is dependent on the frame before it. If a frame is lost, the decoder is unable to determine the difference between the next frames. As a result, it isn't scalable.

Above, we see a temporal base layer (T0) with two upper layers (T1 and T2). T0 is our base temporal layer, and frames on the base layer only refer to other base layer frames. 
We can send all three temporal layers to a high-bandwidth client, resulting in a smooth, high-quality experience. But if the client's network isn't reliable, the media server will only send the base temporal layer (T0) until the network gets better. This saves up to 67% of bandwidth and makes sure the user has a smooth experience.
Huddle01 Media server leverages the powers of Space and Time
Our Homemade Media server (SFU) utilizes both Spatial and Temporal Layers for our Simulcast Implementation.

For video streams, we use S3T3_KEY, which is a 3-layer spatial simulcast and 3-layer-temporal encoding that has worked best in all-around network scenarios from our internal testing and experimentation. 
For screen sharing, where clear quality is more important than fast frame rate, it's best to use more temporal layers than spatial layers (S2T3 and S2T3h).
That‚Äôs it, folks; these are some of the basics of Simulcast and how we have leveraged it! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out to us on Twitter or land on our Discord!

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

This principle is still used today, everywhere; just individual images are called \\\"frames,\\\" not \\\"pictures\\\"\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFun fact: If you go below 30 frames per second, you can see that it‚Äôs a series of frames. Also, if you go above 60 FPS, you can‚Äôt tell much difference.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat does it have to do with Simulcast, and what is Simulcast anyway?\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSimulcast allows publishers to distribute multiple versions of the same A/V stream in various encodings. Huddle01 receives multiple streams and chooses the best one for each subscriber based on network conditions.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you understand the frame concept in a video, it is easy to grasp the workings of Simulcast.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-scalable-video-codecs-svcs\\\"\u003eScalable Video Codecs (SVCs)\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575522185/jpqKA9sgp.png\\\" alt=\\\"SVCs.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThese are the types of video codecs that let a single media stream be encoded in different ways to meet different bitrates and resolutions. This is preferable to making multiple versions of the stream. Although VP9 and AV1 are newer codecs with built-in scalability (SVCs), they have the following drawbacks: \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAV1 is only compatible with browsers that use the Chromium engine simulcast. \\nVP9 is compute-intensive and recently received Safari Support in v15.0\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSince SVCs are not yet compatible everywhere, we use more reliable codecs like VP8 and RTX for simulcast. We like VP9 for our Huddle01 mobile app because it frees us from browser limitations, which is a problem we often run into when developing with WebRTC (different browsers support different levels of video encoders and decoders, so fallbacks are needed).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-spatial-layering\\\"\u003eSpatial Layering\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSpatial layers are the different streams that the client publisher is sending out with different encodings, which in this case means different video qualities. In Huddle01‚Äôs case, we support creating three spatial layers: \\nHigh resolution(1080p) \\nMedium resolution(720p) \\nLow resolution (480p) of the same A/V stream encoded at different bitrates.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667659815776/MMITgX5uE.png\\\" alt=\\\"Spatial Layering.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn the image above, you can see an example of two spatial layers. A larger frame means that the video quality is better.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe streams go to huddle01's media server, which chooses which layers to send to the viewer. From a viewer's perspective, it keeps receiving one layer, which is dynamically switched by the Media Server based on the viewer's network conditions, while the viewer gets one smooth stream without noticing any visible switching. That is the magic of simulcast!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-temporal-layering\\\"\u003eTemporal Layering\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTemporal is just a geeky word for time. So these layers are separated by time, and it is the ability of our media server to dynamically change the frame rate on the fly without affecting the resolution. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet's understand a little about how encoders work. There are two types of frames:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKeyframes:\u003c/strong\u003e These are full-frame images\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDelta frames:\u003c/strong\u003e These only have the difference in the new frame with respect to the keyframe\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDelta frames are usually smaller in size compared to keyframes, so encoders rely heavily on them; they also depend on the previous frames.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eEncoded streams mostly contain delta frames.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet's take this example where there is only one temporal layer\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575607352/651dXO4Td.png\\\" alt=\\\"Temporal Layering.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe have one temporal layer, T1, in which each frame is dependent on the frame before it. If a frame is lost, the decoder is unable to determine the difference between the next frames. As a result, it isn't scalable.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575638589/w-A5ib5hc.png\\\" alt=\\\"Temporal Layering2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAbove, we see a temporal base layer (T0) with two upper layers (T1 and T2). T0 is our base temporal layer, and frames on the base layer only refer to other base layer frames. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe can send all three temporal layers to a high-bandwidth client, resulting in a smooth, high-quality experience. But if the client's network isn't reliable, the media server will only send the base temporal layer (T0) until the network gets better. This saves up to 67% of bandwidth and makes sure the user has a smooth experience.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-media-server-leverages-the-powers-of-space-and-time\\\"\u003eHuddle01 Media server leverages the powers of Space and Time\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOur Homemade Media server (SFU) utilizes both Spatial and Temporal Layers for our Simulcast Implementation.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575662768/KdpowlqDL.png\\\" alt=\\\"Spatial Layering2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFor video streams, we use S3T3_KEY, which is a 3-layer spatial simulcast and 3-layer-temporal encoding that has worked best in all-around network scenarios from our internal testing and experimentation. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFor screen sharing, where clear quality is more important than fast frame rate, it's best to use more temporal layers than spatial layers (\u003cstrong\u003eS2T3 and S2T3h\u003c/strong\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it, folks; these are some of the basics of Simulcast and how we have leveraged it! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out to us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![Simulccast.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575386625/7P6kdl4n2.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is developing the next generation of real-time communications systems through progressive decentralization. We are developing a dRTC engine that will allow technical and social primitives to operate on existing L1 and L2 networks.\\n\\nIf we think about a video, it is just a series of images updating at high speed. Even old movies that used \\\"photo reels\\\" worked on this concept. Our minds tend to see this as motion or moving things, so it is considered to be moving. This principle is still used today, everywhere; just individual images are called \\\"frames,\\\" not \\\"pictures\\\"\\n\\n\u003e Fun fact: If you go below 30 frames per second, you can see that it‚Äôs a series of frames. Also, if you go above 60 FPS, you can‚Äôt tell much difference.\\n\\n**What does it have to do with Simulcast, and what is Simulcast anyway?\\n**\\n\\nSimulcast allows publishers to distribute multiple versions of the same A/V stream in various encodings. Huddle01 receives multiple streams and chooses the best one for each subscriber based on network conditions.\\n\\nIf you understand the frame concept in a video, it is easy to grasp the workings of Simulcast.\\n\\n## Scalable Video Codecs (SVCs)\\n\\n![SVCs.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575522185/jpqKA9sgp.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThese are the types of video codecs that let a single media stream be encoded in different ways to meet different bitrates and resolutions. This is preferable to making multiple versions of the stream. Although VP9 and AV1 are newer codecs with built-in scalability (SVCs), they have the following drawbacks: \\n\\nAV1 is only compatible with browsers that use the Chromium engine simulcast. \\nVP9 is compute-intensive and recently received Safari Support in v15.0\\n\\nSince SVCs are not yet compatible everywhere, we use more reliable codecs like VP8 and RTX for simulcast. We like VP9 for our Huddle01 mobile app because it frees us from browser limitations, which is a problem we often run into when developing with WebRTC (different browsers support different levels of video encoders and decoders, so fallbacks are needed).\\n\\n## Spatial Layering\\n\\nSpatial layers are the different streams that the client publisher is sending out with different encodings, which in this case means different video qualities. In Huddle01‚Äôs case, we support creating three spatial layers: \\nHigh resolution(1080p) \\nMedium resolution(720p) \\nLow resolution (480p) of the same A/V stream encoded at different bitrates.\\n\\n\\n![Spatial Layering.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667659815776/MMITgX5uE.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nIn the image above, you can see an example of two spatial layers. A larger frame means that the video quality is better.\\n\\nThe streams go to huddle01's media server, which chooses which layers to send to the viewer. From a viewer's perspective, it keeps receiving one layer, which is dynamically switched by the Media Server based on the viewer's network conditions, while the viewer gets one smooth stream without noticing any visible switching. That is the magic of simulcast!\\n\\n## Temporal Layering\\n\\nTemporal is just a geeky word for time. So these layers are separated by time, and it is the ability of our media server to dynamically change the frame rate on the fly without affecting the resolution. \\n\\nLet's understand a little about how encoders work. There are two types of frames:\\n\\n**Keyframes:** These are full-frame images\\n\\n**Delta frames:** These only have the difference in the new frame with respect to the keyframe\\n\\nDelta frames are usually smaller in size compared to keyframes, so encoders rely heavily on them; they also depend on the previous frames.\\n\\nEncoded streams mostly contain delta frames.\\n\\nLet's take this example where there is only one temporal layer\\n\\n\\n![Temporal Layering.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575607352/651dXO4Td.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe have one temporal layer, T1, in which each frame is dependent on the frame before it. If a frame is lost, the decoder is unable to determine the difference between the next frames. As a result, it isn't scalable.\\n\\n![Temporal Layering2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575638589/w-A5ib5hc.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAbove, we see a temporal base layer (T0) with two upper layers (T1 and T2). T0 is our base temporal layer, and frames on the base layer only refer to other base layer frames. \\n\\nWe can send all three temporal layers to a high-bandwidth client, resulting in a smooth, high-quality experience. But if the client's network isn't reliable, the media server will only send the base temporal layer (T0) until the network gets better. This saves up to 67% of bandwidth and makes sure the user has a smooth experience.\\n\\n## Huddle01 Media server leverages the powers of Space and Time\\n\\nOur Homemade Media server (SFU) utilizes both Spatial and Temporal Layers for our Simulcast Implementation.\\n\\n\\n![Spatial Layering2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575662768/KdpowlqDL.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nFor video streams, we use S3T3_KEY, which is a 3-layer spatial simulcast and 3-layer-temporal encoding that has worked best in all-around network scenarios from our internal testing and experimentation. \\n\\nFor screen sharing, where clear quality is more important than fast frame rate, it's best to use more temporal layers than spatial layers (**S2T3 and S2T3h**).\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it, folks; these are some of the basics of Simulcast and how we have leveraged it! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out to us on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg)!\\n\",\"coverImage\":\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575851609/QKRmbJq40.png\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is developing the next generation of real-time communications systems through progressive decentralization. üí¨\\n\",\"numPosts\":15},\"ogImage\":\"\",\"metaTitle\":\"\",\"metaDescription\":\"\",\"viewsUpdatedOn\":1676278851028,\"series\":null,\"__v\":1,\"answeredByTarget\":false,\"autoGeneratedCover\":\"\",\"badges\":[],\"bookmarkedIn\":[],\"contributors\":[],\"dateUpdated\":\"2022-11-05T14:50:33.920Z\",\"downvotes\":0,\"duplicatePosts\":[],\"followers\":[],\"hasPolls\":false,\"hasReward\":false,\"isAnonymous\":false,\"pendingPublicationApproval\":false,\"pollOptions\":[],\"questionReplies\":[],\"reactionsByCurrentUser\":[],\"reward\":{\"type\":\"xlm\"},\"stickCoverToBottom\":false,\"subtitle\":\"\",\"totalPollVotes\":0,\"untaggedFrom\":[],\"upvotes\":0,\"reactionToCountMap\":{},\"hasTags\":true,\"isPartOfSeries\":false,\"responses\":[]}","publication":"{\"_id\":\"632f155e3a049a0d9db75b83\",\"wwwPrefixedDomainStatus\":{\"certIssued\":false,\"ready\":false},\"betaFeatures\":{\"newsletter\":false,\"embeds\":false,\"csvImport\":false,\"customCSS\":false,\"githubAsSource\":false,\"payments\":false,\"rssIntegration\":false,\"magazineLayout\":false,\"allowGithubBackupForTeams\":false},\"views\":{\"today\":2,\"thisWeek\":32,\"lastWeek\":138,\"thisMonth\":304,\"allTime\":1583},\"stripe\":{\"connected\":false},\"emailPreferences\":{\"draftSubmissionNotifications\":true},\"wwwPrefixedDomain\":\"\",\"numFollowers\":0,\"badgePageEnabled\":true,\"membersPageEnabled\":true,\"newsletterPageEnabled\":true,\"newsletterEnabled\":true,\"audioBlogEnabled\":false,\"audioBlogVoiceType\":\"male\",\"textSelectionSharerEnabled\":true,\"newsletterFrequency\":\"asap\",\"staticPages\":[],\"isFeatured\":false,\"dailyViewsForCurrentMonth\":{\"1674172800\":25,\"1674259200\":4,\"1674345600\":6,\"1674432000\":7,\"1674518400\":8,\"1674604800\":5,\"1674691200\":16,\"1674777600\":3,\"1674864000\":3,\"1674950400\":17,\"1675036800\":7,\"1675123200\":17,\"1675209600\":6,\"1675296000\":7,\"1675382400\":3,\"1675468800\":6,\"1675641600\":49,\"1675728000\":50,\"1675814400\":6,\"1675900800\":10,\"1675987200\":8,\"1676073600\":4,\"1676160000\":5,\"1676246400\":6,\"1676332800\":2,\"1676419200\":3,\"1676505600\":7,\"1676592000\":4,\"1676678400\":8,\"1676764800\":1,\"1676851200\":1},\"viewCountVisible\":false,\"readTimeHidden\":false,\"customCSSEnabled\":false,\"domainChecklistSkipped\":false,\"umamiDataImported\":true,\"isGithubAsSourceConnected\":false,\"githubAsSourceDetails\":null,\"blockBackupAllButton\":false,\"author\":{\"_id\":\"632f13813a049a0d9db75b4a\",\"socialMedia\":{\"twitter\":\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\",\"instagram\":\"https://www.instagram.com/huddle01com/?hl=en\",\"github\":\"https://github.com/Huddle01\",\"stackoverflow\":\"\",\"facebook\":\"\",\"website\":\"https://huddle01.com/\",\"linkedin\":\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/huddle-01/\",\"youtube\":\"https://www.youtube.com/@huddle0174\"},\"location\":\"\",\"isBanned\":false,\"isDeactivated\":false,\"numFollowers\":4,\"numFollowing\":0,\"storiesCreated\":[],\"totalUpvotesReceived\":0,\"tagManagerOf\":[],\"isEvangelist\":false,\"isAmbassador\":false,\"hasGoldRing\":false,\"name\":\"Huddle01\",\"username\":\"Huddle01com\",\"tagline\":\"The Communication Toolkit for web3. Huddle01 powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026 chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026 users üìû üí¨\",\"photo\":\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664030104296/SagvY7rRI.jpg\",\"dateJoined\":\"2022-09-24T14:26:09.370Z\",\"publicationDomain\":null,\"bio\":\"\u003cp\u003eThe Communication Toolkit for web3. Huddle01 powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026amp; chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026amp; users üìû üí¨\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"numPosts\":4,\"numReactions\":13},\"isActive\":true,\"username\":\"huddle01\",\"urlPattern\":\"simple\",\"layout\":\"magazine\",\"title\":\"Huddle01\",\"links\":{\"twitter\":\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\",\"instagram\":\"\",\"github\":\"\",\"website\":\"https://huddle01.com/\",\"hashnode\":\"https://hashnode.com/@Huddle01com\",\"youtube\":\"https://www.youtube.com/@huddle0174\",\"dailydev\":\"\",\"linkedin\":\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/huddle-01/\",\"mastodon\":\"\"},\"domainStatus\":{\"ready\":false,\"certIssued\":false},\"domainUpdatedOn\":\"2022-09-24T14:34:06.426Z\",\"customRules\":[],\"menu\":[],\"__v\":0,\"umamiWebsiteUUID\":\"6cfb4e9d-68bd-437b-b72d-ea1988e29da2\",\"hasBadges\":true,\"imprint\":\"\",\"imprintMarkdown\":\"\",\"meta\":\"The Communication Toolkit for web3. Huddle01 powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026 chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026 users üìû üí¨\",\"metaHTML\":\"\u003cp\u003eThe Communication Toolkit for web3.
