Video Codecs (SVCs)\"}],[{\"id\":\"6fa3a100-eca0-4345-9c22-776e5912adfe\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"spatial-layering\",\"title\":\"Spatial Layering\"}],[{\"id\":\"424cf59a-c1c7-4f15-ac33-9b4449074b2b\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"temporal-layering\",\"title\":\"Temporal Layering\"}],[{\"id\":\"c9282805-cf29-419e-a97e-ad9b2f0655d1\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"huddle01-media-server-leverages-the-powers-of-space-and-time\",\"title\":\"Huddle01 Media server leverages the powers of Space and Time\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575386625/7P6kdl4n2.png\\\" alt=\\\"Simulccast.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is developing the next generation of real-time communications systems through progressive decentralization. We are developing a dRTC engine that will allow technical and social primitives to operate on existing L1 and L2 networks.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf we think about a video, it is just a series of images updating at high speed. Even old movies that used \\\"photo reels\\\" worked on this concept. Our minds tend to see this as motion or moving things, so it is considered to be moving. This principle is still used today, everywhere; just individual images are called \\\"frames,\\\" not \\\"pictures\\\"\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFun fact: If you go below 30 frames per second, you can see that it‚Äôs a series of frames. Also, if you go above 60 FPS, you can‚Äôt tell much difference.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat does it have to do with Simulcast, and what is Simulcast anyway?\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSimulcast allows publishers to distribute multiple versions of the same A/V stream in various encodings. Huddle01 receives multiple streams and chooses the best one for each subscriber based on network conditions.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you understand the frame concept in a video, it is easy to grasp the workings of Simulcast.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-scalable-video-codecs-svcs\\\"\u003eScalable Video Codecs (SVCs)\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575522185/jpqKA9sgp.png\\\" alt=\\\"SVCs.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThese are the types of video codecs that let a single media stream be encoded in different ways to meet different bitrates and resolutions. This is preferable to making multiple versions of the stream. Although VP9 and AV1 are newer codecs with built-in scalability (SVCs), they have the following drawbacks: \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAV1 is only compatible with browsers that use the Chromium engine simulcast. \\nVP9 is compute-intensive and recently received Safari Support in v15.0\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSince SVCs are not yet compatible everywhere, we use more reliable codecs like VP8 and RTX for simulcast. We like VP9 for our Huddle01 mobile app because it frees us from browser limitations, which is a problem we often run into when developing with WebRTC (different browsers support different levels of video encoders and decoders, so fallbacks are needed).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-spatial-layering\\\"\u003eSpatial Layering\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSpatial layers are the different streams that the client publisher is sending out with different encodings, which in this case means different video qualities. In Huddle01‚Äôs case, we support creating three spatial layers: \\nHigh resolution(1080p) \\nMedium resolution(720p) \\nLow resolution (480p) of the same A/V stream encoded at different bitrates.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667659815776/MMITgX5uE.png\\\" alt=\\\"Spatial Layering.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn the image above, you can see an example of two spatial layers. A larger frame means that the video quality is better.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe streams go to huddle01's media server, which chooses which layers to send to the viewer. From a viewer's perspective, it keeps receiving one layer, which is dynamically switched by the Media Server based on the viewer's network conditions, while the viewer gets one smooth stream without noticing any visible switching. That is the magic of simulcast!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-temporal-layering\\\"\u003eTemporal Layering\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTemporal is just a geeky word for time. So these layers are separated by time, and it is the ability of our media server to dynamically change the frame rate on the fly without affecting the resolution. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet's understand a little about how encoders work. There are two types of frames:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKeyframes:\u003c/strong\u003e These are full-frame images\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDelta frames:\u003c/strong\u003e These only have the difference in the new frame with respect to the keyframe\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDelta frames are usually smaller in size compared to keyframes, so encoders rely heavily on them; they also depend on the previous frames.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eEncoded streams mostly contain delta frames.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet's take this example where there is only one temporal layer\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575607352/651dXO4Td.png\\\" alt=\\\"Temporal Layering.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe have one temporal layer, T1, in which each frame is dependent on the frame before it. If a frame is lost, the decoder is unable to determine the difference between the next frames. As a result, it isn't scalable.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575638589/w-A5ib5hc.png\\\" alt=\\\"Temporal Layering2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAbove, we see a temporal base layer (T0) with two upper layers (T1 and T2). T0 is our base temporal layer, and frames on the base layer only refer to other base layer frames. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe can send all three temporal layers to a high-bandwidth client, resulting in a smooth, high-quality experience. But if the client's network isn't reliable, the media server will only send the base temporal layer (T0) until the network gets better. This saves up to 67% of bandwidth and makes sure the user has a smooth experience.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-media-server-leverages-the-powers-of-space-and-time\\\"\u003eHuddle01 Media server leverages the powers of Space and Time\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOur Homemade Media server (SFU) utilizes both Spatial and Temporal Layers for our Simulcast Implementation.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575662768/KdpowlqDL.png\\\" alt=\\\"Spatial Layering2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFor video streams, we use S3T3_KEY, which is a 3-layer spatial simulcast and 3-layer-temporal encoding that has worked best in all-around network scenarios from our internal testing and experimentation. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFor screen sharing, where clear quality is more important than fast frame rate, it's best to use more temporal layers than spatial layers (\u003cstrong\u003eS2T3 and S2T3h\u003c/strong\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it, folks; these are some of the basics of Simulcast and how we have leveraged it! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out to us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![Simulccast.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575386625/7P6kdl4n2.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is developing the next generation of real-time communications systems through progressive decentralization. We are developing a dRTC engine that will allow technical and social primitives to operate on existing L1 and L2 networks.\\n\\nIf we think about a video, it is just a series of images updating at high speed. Even old movies that used \\\"photo reels\\\" worked on this concept. Our minds tend to see this as motion or moving things, so it is considered to be moving. This principle is still used today, everywhere; just individual images are called \\\"frames,\\\" not \\\"pictures\\\"\\n\\n\u003e Fun fact: If you go below 30 frames per second, you can see that it‚Äôs a series of frames. Also, if you go above 60 FPS, you can‚Äôt tell much difference.\\n\\n**What does it have to do with Simulcast, and what is Simulcast anyway?\\n**\\n\\nSimulcast allows publishers to distribute multiple versions of the same A/V stream in various encodings. Huddle01 receives multiple streams and chooses the best one for each subscriber based on network conditions.\\n\\nIf you understand the frame concept in a video, it is easy to grasp the workings of Simulcast.\\n\\n## Scalable Video Codecs (SVCs)\\n\\n![SVCs.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575522185/jpqKA9sgp.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThese are the types of video codecs that let a single media stream be encoded in different ways to meet different bitrates and resolutions. This is preferable to making multiple versions of the stream. Although VP9 and AV1 are newer codecs with built-in scalability (SVCs), they have the following drawbacks: \\n\\nAV1 is only compatible with browsers that use the Chromium engine simulcast. \\nVP9 is compute-intensive and recently received Safari Support in v15.0\\n\\nSince SVCs are not yet compatible everywhere, we use more reliable codecs like VP8 and RTX for simulcast. We like VP9 for our Huddle01 mobile app because it frees us from browser limitations, which is a problem we often run into when developing with WebRTC (different browsers support different levels of video encoders and decoders, so fallbacks are needed).\\n\\n## Spatial Layering\\n\\nSpatial layers are the different streams that the client publisher is sending out with different encodings, which in this case means different video qualities. In Huddle01‚Äôs case, we support creating three spatial layers: \\nHigh resolution(1080p) \\nMedium resolution(720p) \\nLow resolution (480p) of the same A/V stream encoded at different bitrates.\\n\\n\\n![Spatial Layering.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667659815776/MMITgX5uE.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nIn the image above, you can see an example of two spatial layers. A larger frame means that the video quality is better.\\n\\nThe streams go to huddle01's media server, which chooses which layers to send to the viewer. From a viewer's perspective, it keeps receiving one layer, which is dynamically switched by the Media Server based on the viewer's network conditions, while the viewer gets one smooth stream without noticing any visible switching. That is the magic of simulcast!\\n\\n## Temporal Layering\\n\\nTemporal is just a geeky word for time. So these layers are separated by time, and it is the ability of our media server to dynamically change the frame rate on the fly without affecting the resolution. \\n\\nLet's understand a little about how encoders work. There are two types of frames:\\n\\n**Keyframes:** These are full-frame images\\n\\n**Delta frames:** These only have the difference in the new frame with respect to the keyframe\\n\\nDelta frames are usually smaller in size compared to keyframes, so encoders rely heavily on them; they also depend on the previous frames.\\n\\nEncoded streams mostly contain delta frames.\\n\\nLet's take this example where there is only one temporal layer\\n\\n\\n![Temporal Layering.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575607352/651dXO4Td.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe have one temporal layer, T1, in which each frame is dependent on the frame before it. If a frame is lost, the decoder is unable to determine the difference between the next frames. As a result, it isn't scalable.\\n\\n![Temporal Layering2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575638589/w-A5ib5hc.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAbove, we see a temporal base layer (T0) with two upper layers (T1 and T2). T0 is our base temporal layer, and frames on the base layer only refer to other base layer frames. \\n\\nWe can send all three temporal layers to a high-bandwidth client, resulting in a smooth, high-quality experience. But if the client's network isn't reliable, the media server will only send the base temporal layer (T0) until the network gets better. This saves up to 67% of bandwidth and makes sure the user has a smooth experience.\\n\\n## Huddle01 Media server leverages the powers of Space and Time\\n\\nOur Homemade Media server (SFU) utilizes both Spatial and Temporal Layers for our Simulcast Implementation.\\n\\n\\n![Spatial Layering2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575662768/KdpowlqDL.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nFor video streams, we use S3T3_KEY, which is a 3-layer spatial simulcast and 3-layer-temporal encoding that has worked best in all-around network scenarios from our internal testing and experimentation. \\n\\nFor screen sharing, where clear quality is more important than fast frame rate, it's best to use more temporal layers than spatial layers (**S2T3 and S2T3h**).\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it, folks; these are some of the basics of Simulcast and how we have leveraged it! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out to us on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg)!\\n\",\"coverImage\":\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1667575851609/QKRmbJq40.png\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is developing the next generation of real-time communications systems through progressive decentralization. Huddle01 is improving how we talk to each other over the internet by putting the product first. We are always working to improve the app's user experience (UX) and overall efficiency, and we are also building a protocol that can be used for all internet-based communication.
Today, we‚Äôll be discussing simulcast, a concept derived from "simultaneous casting."
If you are good at using Google, you‚Äôll get multiple definitions for the same term. To clear up the confusion, let me explain what the different definitions are and why each is accurate in their specific contexts.

A tool enables people to simultaneously stream on different platforms in real-time. If you love playing games and streaming, you‚Äôll stream on Twitch, Youtube, and sometimes even StreamYard.

A method to send multiple videos of different resolutions to enable real-time communications, I know it's a bit complicated, but this is what we‚Äôll be understanding in this blog further.


Simulcast seems like a complicated concept and some optimizations are associated with it but don‚Äôt worry, I got you covered. We‚Äôll understand from the core why it is necessary and how it is an effective solution despite its cons. Let‚Äôs start with bandwidth and what it is!
What is bandwidth ü§î

Ah! The great thing that made people millionaires in the age of the Internet was: But what does it even mean? Bandwidth usually means if you have some time for a task or not. Even today, when people talk about taking on additional work, they use the term.
Bandwidth means how fast the data can be shared with the network. It is a measure of the speed of data transfer over the internet. It is measured in bits/sec or bytes/sec. If you think about it, optical fiber uses light as a medium of signaling and data transfer. That‚Äôs why when you install an optical fiber, you get super-fast speeds.
In computer science or in terms of the Internet, we usually use the terms "internet speed" and "bandwidth" as synonyms. 
But, what does it actually mean?
People have different bandwidths for communication over the internet, so they can only send and receive so much information for a seamless experience. That‚Äôs where different concepts come into play.
We need to understand that most of the world still doesn‚Äôt have daily access to computers and bandwidth is no more than 35 Mbps. The problem with mobile users is that the bandwidth isn't as stable as compared to LANs. Because of this, many improvements are made to the application itself so that users can have a smooth experience.
Problems with low bandwidth üò¢

We know different users have different bandwidths. Along with this, different users also have different computational powers. Someone may have a gaming setup. Someone may join in from the phone. You have to consider all the factors!
That‚Äôs why we also need to consider the case where we have users with slow bandwidth, as we already covered the computational issue in our earlier blog, where we discussed SFU.
The real-world issue is that, because many people have variable bandwidths, some might not be able to receive the full information from an audio or video source. This would cause the entire system to work on lower bandwidth because it would have to cater to just one user with terrible internet.
Let‚Äôs understand this with an example,
You are out with your friends. While hanging out, everyone suggests that we get to eat something. In a group of four friends, three of you are non-veg lovers, and one is pure vegan. When you get to order, you realize that you are at a place that only serves meat. This won‚Äôt work as one of your friends is a vegetarian. So you get to the next place, and it turns out it is pure veg, so you‚Äôll have vegan food. That‚Äôs how webRTC works.
That‚Äôs where simulcasting comes in. Let‚Äôs see how.
What is Simulcast üëÄ

Simulcast, as mentioned earlier, is a word made by combining Simultaneous and Casting, i.e., Simulcasting. The term is pretty easy to understand.
People had different bandwidths, which was a problem. Eventually, everyone had to work on the lowest bandwidth, even though they had the resources and bandwidth to set up better connections. Simulcast works as it sends different quality videos to the Huddle01 media server, such as the server deciding which quality is best as well as sustainable for everyone present in the call.

Going back to our previous example, when you have to eat vegetarian food because one person in a group of five was unable to eat meat. Well, Simulcast is like going to a mixed restaurant where they serve both meat and vegetarian food.
Simulcast makes video communication better because it automatically changes based on the bandwidth and processing power of both the sender and the receiver. This makes the user experience better because the architecture will eventually change itself to give you the best possible experience. It's like how YouTube automatically changes the quality of videos when there are bandwidth problems.
Huddle01 and Simulcast ü§ù

We also make use of simulcast to ensure that the user's interaction with our product is as seamless as possible. In addition to this, we also provide developers who are interested in utilizing the tech stack with an SDK, as well as I-frames and APIs.
The disadvantages of simultaneous broadcasting include:

Users who have access to large bandwidth and sufficient processing power typically send more data.
If a computer is already engaged in an intensive task, sending different videos to a server is problematic because encoding would further drain CPU usage.

But, these are some small trade-offs made in implementing Simulcast with a media server.
That's all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on Twitter or land on our Discord!

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

Let‚Äôs start with bandwidth and what it is!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-bandwidth\\\"\u003eWhat is bandwidth ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880405942/BJarqrSWf.png\\\" alt=\\\"bandwidth.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAh! It is a measure of the speed of data transfer over the internet. It is measured in bits/sec or bytes/sec. If you think about it, optical fiber uses light as a medium of signaling and data transfer. That‚Äôs why when you install an optical fiber, you get super-fast speeds.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn computer science or in terms of the Internet, we usually use the terms \\\"internet speed\\\" and \\\"bandwidth\\\" as synonyms. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBut, what does it actually mean?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003ePeople have different bandwidths for communication over the internet, so they can only send and receive so much information for a seamless experience. The problem with mobile users is that the bandwidth isn't as stable as compared to LANs. Because of this, many improvements are made to the application itself so that users can have a smooth experience.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-problems-with-low-bandwidth\\\"\u003eProblems with low bandwidth üò¢\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880474590/78X7WFVSH.png\\\" alt=\\\"problems with slow bandwidth.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe know different users have different bandwidths. Along with this, different users also have different computational powers. Someone may have a gaming setup. Someone may join in from the phone. You have to consider all the factors!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs why we also need to consider the case where we have users with slow bandwidth, as we already covered the computational issue in our earlier blog, where we discussed SFU.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe real-world issue is that, because many people have variable bandwidths, some might not be able to receive the full information from an audio or video source. This would cause the entire system to work on lower bandwidth because it would have to cater to just one user with terrible internet.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs understand this with an example,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou are out with your friends. We‚Äôll understand from the core why it is necessary and how it is an effective solution despite its cons. Let‚Äôs start with bandwidth and what it is!\\n\\n## What is bandwidth ü§î\\n\\n![bandwidth.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880405942/BJarqrSWf.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAh! The great thing that made people millionaires in the age of the Internet was: But what does it even mean? Bandwidth usually means if you have some time for a task or not. Even today, when people talk about taking on additional work, they use the term.\\n\\nBandwidth means how fast the data can be shared with the network. It is a measure of the speed of data transfer over the internet. It is measured in bits/sec or bytes/sec. If you think about it, optical fiber uses light as a medium of signaling and data transfer. That‚Äôs why when you install an optical fiber, you get super-fast speeds.\\n\\nIn computer science or in terms of the Internet, we usually use the terms \\\"internet speed\\\" and \\\"bandwidth\\\" as synonyms. \\n\\nBut, what does it actually mean?\\n\\nPeople have different bandwidths for communication over the internet, so they can only send and receive so much information for a seamless experience. That‚Äôs where different concepts come into play.\\n\\nWe need to understand that most of the world still doesn‚Äôt have daily access to computers and bandwidth is no more than 35 Mbps. The problem with mobile users is that the bandwidth isn't as stable as compared to LANs. Because of this, many improvements are made to the application itself so that users can have a smooth experience.\\n\\n## Problems with low bandwidth üò¢\\n\\n\\n![problems with slow bandwidth.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880474590/78X7WFVSH.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe know different users have different bandwidths. Along with this, different users also have different computational powers. Someone may have a gaming setup. Someone may join in from the phone. You have to consider all the factors!\\n\\nThat‚Äôs why we also need to consider the case where we have users with slow bandwidth, as we already covered the computational issue in our earlier blog, where we discussed SFU.\\n\\nThe real-world issue is that, because many people have variable bandwidths, some might not be able to receive the full information from an audio or video source. This would cause the entire system to work on lower bandwidth because it would have to cater to just one user with terrible internet.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs understand this with an example,\\n\\nYou are out with your friends. While hanging out, everyone suggests that we get to eat something. In a group of four friends, three of you are non-veg lovers, and one is pure vegan. When you get to order, you realize that you are at a place that only serves meat. This won‚Äôt work as one of your friends is a vegetarian. So you get to the next place, and it turns out it is pure veg, so you‚Äôll have vegan food. That‚Äôs how webRTC works.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs where simulcasting comes in. Let‚Äôs see how.\\n\\n## What is Simulcast üëÄ\\n\\n\\n![what is simulcast.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880546817/ElMk7cSTv.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nSimulcast, as mentioned earlier, is a word made by combining Simultaneous and Casting, i.e., Simulcasting. The term is pretty easy to understand.\\n\\nPeople had different bandwidths, which was a problem. Eventually, everyone had to work on the lowest bandwidth, even though they had the resources and bandwidth to set up better connections. Simulcast works as it sends different quality videos to the Huddle01 media server, such as the server deciding which quality is best as well as sustainable for everyone present in the call.\\n\\n\\n![simulcast exampl.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880581742/US3Zg2C5Y.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nGoing back to our previous example, when you have to eat vegetarian food because one person in a group of five was unable to eat meat. Well, Simulcast is like going to a mixed restaurant where they serve both meat and vegetarian food.\\n\\nSimulcast makes video communication better because it automatically changes based on the bandwidth and processing power of both the sender and the receiver. This makes the user experience better because the architecture will eventually change itself to give you the best possible experience. It's like how YouTube automatically changes the quality of videos when there are bandwidth problems.\\n\\n## Huddle01 and Simulcast ü§ù\\n\\n\\n![huddle01.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880622955/3Ad1PtLBK.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe also make use of simulcast to ensure that the user's interaction with our product is as seamless as possible. In addition to this, we also provide developers who are interested in utilizing the tech stack with an SDK, as well as I-frames and APIs.\\n\\nThe disadvantages of simultaneous broadcasting include:\\n\\n- Users who have access to large bandwidth and sufficient processing power typically send more data.\\n- If a computer is already engaged in an intensive task, sending different videos to a server is problematic because encoding would further drain CPU usage.\\n\\nBut, these are some small trade-offs made in implementing Simulcast with a media server.\\n\\nThat's all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg)!\\n\",\"coverImage\":\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880853928/EKJ7b3tvj.png\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is improving how we talk to each other over the internet by putting the product first. Simultaneous casting and its beauty\",\"cuid\":\"cl9r5vvkm000o09l1etcv4bbs\",\"dateAdded\":\"2022-10-27T14:29:19.126Z\",\"hasCustomDate\":null,\"isCoverAttributionHidden\":false,\"coverImageAttribution\":\"\",\"coverImagePhotographer\":\"\",\"slug\":\"simulcast-simultaneous-casting-and-its-beauty\",\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"590b8978-8b78-463b-89c8-38ffd3fb8c03\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-bandwidth\",\"title\":\"What is bandwidth ü§î\"}],[{\"id\":\"56030bb7-e0dd-4d9f-91b4-b450ca4318d1\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"problems-with-low-bandwidth\",\"title\":\"Problems with low bandwidth üò¢\"}],[{\"id\":\"11b40d5d-f5f8-4e8a-8d3a-fe4a55cbe312\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-simulcast\",\"title\":\"What is Simulcast üëÄ\"}],[{\"id\":\"8e430504-00d4-4216-88e4-3c2abcab2e8d\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"huddle01-and-simulcast\",\"title\":\"Huddle01 and Simulcast ü§ù\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880355111/_auI70BZM.png\\\" alt=\\\"simulcast.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is improving how we talk to each other over the internet by putting the product first. We are always working to improve the app's user experience (UX) and overall efficiency, and we are also building a protocol that can be used for all internet-based communication.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eToday, we‚Äôll be discussing simulcast, a concept derived from \\\"simultaneous casting.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are good at using Google, you‚Äôll get multiple definitions for the same term. To clear up the confusion, let me explain what the different definitions are and why each is accurate in their specific contexts.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eA tool enables people to simultaneously stream on different platforms in real-time. If you love playing games and streaming, you‚Äôll stream on Twitch, Youtube, and sometimes even StreamYard.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eA method to send multiple videos of different resolutions to enable real-time communications, I know it's a bit complicated, but this is what we‚Äôll be understanding in this blog further.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSimulcast seems like a complicated concept and some optimizations are associated with it but don‚Äôt worry, I got you covered. We‚Äôll understand from the core why it is necessary and how it is an effective solution despite its cons. Let‚Äôs start with bandwidth and what it is!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-bandwidth\\\"\u003eWhat is bandwidth ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880405942/BJarqrSWf.png\\\" alt=\\\"bandwidth.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAh! The great thing that made people millionaires in the age of the Internet was: But what does it even mean? Bandwidth usually means if you have some time for a task or not. Even today, when people talk about taking on additional work, they use the term.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBandwidth means how fast the data can be shared with the network. It is a measure of the speed of data transfer over the internet. It is measured in bits/sec or bytes/sec. If you think about it, optical fiber uses light as a medium of signaling and data transfer. That‚Äôs why when you install an optical fiber, you get super-fast speeds.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn computer science or in terms of the Internet, we usually use the terms \\\"internet speed\\\" and \\\"bandwidth\\\" as synonyms. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBut, what does it actually mean?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003ePeople have different bandwidths for communication over the internet, so they can only send and receive so much information for a seamless experience. That‚Äôs where different concepts come into play.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe need to understand that most of the world still doesn‚Äôt have daily access to computers and bandwidth is no more than 35 Mbps. The problem with mobile users is that the bandwidth isn't as stable as compared to LANs. Because of this, many improvements are made to the application itself so that users can have a smooth experience.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-problems-with-low-bandwidth\\\"\u003eProblems with low bandwidth üò¢\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880474590/78X7WFVSH.png\\\" alt=\\\"problems with slow bandwidth.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe know different users have different bandwidths. Along with this, different users also have different computational powers. Someone may have a gaming setup. Someone may join in from the phone. You have to consider all the factors!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs why we also need to consider the case where we have users with slow bandwidth, as we already covered the computational issue in our earlier blog, where we discussed SFU.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe real-world issue is that, because many people have variable bandwidths, some might not be able to receive the full information from an audio or video source. This would cause the entire system to work on lower bandwidth because it would have to cater to just one user with terrible internet.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs understand this with an example,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou are out with your friends. While hanging out, everyone suggests that we get to eat something. In a group of four friends, three of you are non-veg lovers, and one is pure vegan. When you get to order, you realize that you are at a place that only serves meat. This won‚Äôt work as one of your friends is a vegetarian. So you get to the next place, and it turns out it is pure veg, so you‚Äôll have vegan food. That‚Äôs how webRTC works.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs where simulcasting comes in. Let‚Äôs see how.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-simulcast\\\"\u003eWhat is Simulcast üëÄ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880546817/ElMk7cSTv.png\\\" alt=\\\"what is simulcast.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSimulcast, as mentioned earlier, is a word made by combining Simultaneous and Casting, i.e., Simulcasting. The term is pretty easy to understand.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003ePeople had different bandwidths, which was a problem. Eventually, everyone had to work on the lowest bandwidth, even though they had the resources and bandwidth to set up better connections. Simulcast works as it sends different quality videos to the Huddle01 media server, such as the server deciding which quality is best as well as sustainable for everyone present in the call.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880581742/US3Zg2C5Y.png\\\" alt=\\\"simulcast exampl.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eGoing back to our previous example, when you have to eat vegetarian food because one person in a group of five was unable to eat meat. Well, Simulcast is like going to a mixed restaurant where they serve both meat and vegetarian food.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSimulcast makes video communication better because it automatically changes based on the bandwidth and processing power of both the sender and the receiver. This makes the user experience better because the architecture will eventually change itself to give you the best possible experience. It's like how YouTube automatically changes the quality of videos when there are bandwidth problems.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-and-simulcast\\\"\u003eHuddle01 and Simulcast ü§ù\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880622955/3Ad1PtLBK.png\\\" alt=\\\"huddle01.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe also make use of simulcast to ensure that the user's interaction with our product is as seamless as possible. In addition to this, we also provide developers who are interested in utilizing the tech stack with an SDK, as well as I-frames and APIs.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe disadvantages of simultaneous broadcasting include:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eUsers who have access to large bandwidth and sufficient processing power typically send more data.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIf a computer is already engaged in an intensive task, sending different videos to a server is problematic because encoding would further drain CPU usage.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBut, these are some small trade-offs made in implementing Simulcast with a media server.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat's all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n\\n![simulcast.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880355111/_auI70BZM.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is improving how we talk to each other over the internet by putting the product first. We are always working to improve the app's user experience (UX) and overall efficiency, and we are also building a protocol that can be used for all internet-based communication.\\n\\nToday, we‚Äôll be discussing simulcast, a concept derived from \\\"simultaneous casting.\\\"\\n\\nIf you are good at using Google, you‚Äôll get multiple definitions for the same term. To clear up the confusion, let me explain what the different definitions are and why each is accurate in their specific contexts.\\n\\n1. A tool enables people to simultaneously stream on different platforms in real-time. If you love playing games and streaming, you‚Äôll stream on Twitch, Youtube, and sometimes even StreamYard.\\n\\n2. A method to send multiple videos of different resolutions to enable real-time communications, I know it's a bit complicated, but this is what we‚Äôll be understanding in this blog further.\\n\\nSimulcast seems like a complicated concept and some optimizations are associated with it but don‚Äôt worry, I got you covered. We‚Äôll understand from the core why it is necessary and how it is an effective solution despite its cons. Let‚Äôs start with bandwidth and what it is!\\n\\n## What is bandwidth ü§î\\n\\n![bandwidth.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880405942/BJarqrSWf.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAh! The great thing that made people millionaires in the age of the Internet was: But what does it even mean? Bandwidth usually means if you have some time for a task or not. Even today, when people talk about taking on additional work, they use the term.\\n\\nBandwidth means how fast the data can be shared with the network. It is a measure of the speed of data transfer over the internet. It is measured in bits/sec or bytes/sec. If you think about it, optical fiber uses light as a medium of signaling and data transfer. That‚Äôs why when you install an optical fiber, you get super-fast speeds.\\n\\nIn computer science or in terms of the Internet, we usually use the terms \\\"internet speed\\\" and \\\"bandwidth\\\" as synonyms. \\n\\nBut, what does it actually mean?\\n\\nPeople have different bandwidths for communication over the internet, so they can only send and receive so much information for a seamless experience. That‚Äôs where different concepts come into play.\\n\\nWe need to understand that most of the world still doesn‚Äôt have daily access to computers and bandwidth is no more than 35 Mbps. The problem with mobile users is that the bandwidth isn't as stable as compared to LANs. Because of this, many improvements are made to the application itself so that users can have a smooth experience.\\n\\n## Problems with low bandwidth üò¢\\n\\n\\n![problems with slow bandwidth.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880474590/78X7WFVSH.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe know different users have different bandwidths. Along with this, different users also have different computational powers. Someone may have a gaming setup. Someone may join in from the phone. You have to consider all the factors!\\n\\nThat‚Äôs why we also need to consider the case where we have users with slow bandwidth, as we already covered the computational issue in our earlier blog, where we discussed SFU.\\n\\nThe real-world issue is that, because many people have variable bandwidths, some might not be able to receive the full information from an audio or video source. This would cause the entire system to work on lower bandwidth because it would have to cater to just one user with terrible internet.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs understand this with an example,\\n\\nYou are out with your friends. While hanging out, everyone suggests that we get to eat something. In a group of four friends, three of you are non-veg lovers, and one is pure vegan. When you get to order, you realize that you are at a place that only serves meat. This won‚Äôt work as one of your friends is a vegetarian. So you get to the next place, and it turns out it is pure veg, so you‚Äôll have vegan food. That‚Äôs how webRTC works.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs where simulcasting comes in. Let‚Äôs see how.\\n\\n## What is Simulcast üëÄ\\n\\n\\n![what is simulcast.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880546817/ElMk7cSTv.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nSimulcast, as mentioned earlier, is a word made by combining Simultaneous and Casting, i.e., Simulcasting. The term is pretty easy to understand.\\n\\nPeople had different bandwidths, which was a problem. Eventually, everyone had to work on the lowest bandwidth, even though they had the resources and bandwidth to set up better connections. Simulcast works as it sends different quality videos to the Huddle01 media server, such as the server deciding which quality is best as well as sustainable for everyone present in the call.\\n\\n\\n![simulcast exampl.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880581742/US3Zg2C5Y.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nGoing back to our previous example, when you have to eat vegetarian food because one person in a group of five was unable to eat meat. Well, Simulcast is like going to a mixed restaurant where they serve both meat and vegetarian food.\\n\\nSimulcast makes video communication better because it automatically changes based on the bandwidth and processing power of both the sender and the receiver. This makes the user experience better because the architecture will eventually change itself to give you the best possible experience. It's like how YouTube automatically changes the quality of videos when there are bandwidth problems.\\n\\n## Huddle01 and Simulcast ü§ù\\n\\n\\n![huddle01.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880622955/3Ad1PtLBK.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe also make use of simulcast to ensure that the user's interaction with our product is as seamless as possible. In addition to this, we also provide developers who are interested in utilizing the tech stack with an SDK, as well as I-frames and APIs.\\n\\nThe disadvantages of simultaneous broadcasting include:\\n\\n- Users who have access to large bandwidth and sufficient processing power typically send more data.\\n- If a computer is already engaged in an intensive task, sending different videos to a server is problematic because encoding would further drain CPU usage.\\n\\nBut, these are some small trade-offs made in implementing Simulcast with a media server.\\n\\nThat's all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/SycvV5wQDg)!\\n\",\"coverImage\":\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666880853928/EKJ7b3tvj.png\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is improving how we talk to each other over the internet by putting the product first. td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}

We are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. 
~ Stephen Hawkings

The internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that are processing and data efficient. With this in mind, we at Huddle01 are constantly working to improve our video conferencing application while developing the deRTC Protocol.
We ran into a re-rendering issue while optimizing our Huddle01 video conferencing platform. This allowed us to deal with the problem of re-rendering with new solutions more efficiently.
Before diving into what re-rendering is, let‚Äôs talk about,
What is rendering ü§î

You may have heard of rendering from a friend who edits videos or creates crazy 3D art. Rendering has always been thought of as ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù or a better synonym for ‚Äúloading.‚Äù
Depending on the context, the word ‚Äúrendering‚Äù can have several different meanings.

If you are a video editor or a 3D artist, it refers to the process of generating images or a modal with computers.
Depending on the context, it can mean to cause something to happen or to help someone.

In our case of web development, it means gathering different data and either processing or directly sending the output to the screen. Simply put, when you click on a website link, it renders as soon as you are directed to it.
What is re-rendering ‚öô

We know that when a component loads on the screen for the first time, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúrendering.‚Äù Similarly, whenever it‚Äôs loaded again, it‚Äôs called re-rendering.
Why does re-rendering happen üëÄ

When new information is added to the page, it needs to re-render some parts with further information. For example, when you press various buttons on the website, i.e., interact with it, there are some changes in it. When you press like on a tweet, the number count changes. The specific component which is displaying the like count gets updated.
Good application architecture refers to minimal re-renders as a part of the design. But re-renders are necessary as many applications have to be interactive.
There are two types of re-rendering.
Necessary re-render:

As the name implies, it refers to re-renders that are absolutely necessary. It also means that the re-rendered components are specific, with no effect on a larger scale than that. For example, when you toggle your microphone on and off in the Huddle01 app.
Unnecessary re-rendering:

As previously discussed, re-rendering is required for an interactive application. However, when unnecessary re-rendering occurs, not only does the specific component re-render, but all other elements that were not involved are also re-rendered. For example, when a keystroke causes the entire page to be re-rendered.
With this background, let‚Äôs see some of the re-rendering issues we faced and how we solved them!
What were the issues ‚ùì

Whenever there is a UI update on the screen, a re-render is caused in order to update it for the user. Whenever a button is clicked, a re-render is caused to update the UI. The re-renders are denoted by the green border around the component which is being updated.
In our previous iteration of the meeting product (as shown below), there were a lot of re-renders on the UI, which triggered multiple side effects, causing memory leaks. The major reasons for this were:

Whenever a peer (or attendee) entered the meeting room, they got added to the list of peers (array of peers) which triggered a re-render to update the grid of peers to show them on the screen.

Whenever a speaker gets active, they get prioritized in the grid and the grid is supposed to be reshuffled which caused even more re-renders.

We used redux in the application and destructured properties from the state object using them in the dependency arrays of useEffects.


These re-renders over time made the app running in the browser slower and slower exponentially as the meeting progressed.

How did we fix it üõ†

To fix these issues, we made some major changes to our front-end architecture :

We memoized components using React.memo() wherever necessary, to prevent unnecessary re-rendering.

We provided unique keys to every peer viewport in the grid so that even if they shuffled in an array a re-render won‚Äôt be required to change their order. We also had to map the peer's array inside a separate child component to prevent re-renders.

We used a library called zustand instead of redux which is much easier to implement as well as has much more re-rendering optimization built-in.

Rather than destructuring the properties from the state object. We created new variables from the state selectors minimizing re-renders even more.

We minimized the use of useEffects for side effects and avoided putting variables in dependency arrays of useEffects.


Takeaways for you!
It may take some time, but if you try to optimize, you will eventually reach a solution that is both effective and intelligent. It took a significant amount of effort and time on our part to bring the app up to its current state of optimal performance. We stayed focused on our primary goal of improving the application and, over time, figured out ways to do so. This effort assisted aspiring developers in finding easy ways to optimize the re-rendering problem.
That‚Äôs all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on Twitter or land on our discord!

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

we fixed Huddle01‚Äôs Re-rendering issues\",\"cuid\":\"cl9ekd418000409l77a7u40k9\",\"dateAdded\":\"2022-10-18T18:53:37.581Z\",\"hasCustomDate\":null,\"isCoverAttributionHidden\":false,\"coverImageAttribution\":\"\",\"coverImagePhotographer\":\"\",\"slug\":\"how-we-fixed-huddle01s-re-rendering-issues\",\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"fb178f62-7474-407f-bb76-8374350168d9\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-re-rendering\",\"title\":\"What is re-rendering ‚öô\"}],[{\"id\":\"6fbe7bc8-b40f-4755-8824-24bdf4eeac04\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-were-the-issues\",\"title\":\"What were the issues ‚ùì\"}],[{\"id\":\"91d91d31-1874-415b-9579-4ed4ecbf20f9\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"how-did-we-fix-it\",\"title\":\"How did we fix it üõ†\"}],[{\"id\":\"1ac400fd-3032-44a6-a659-9aa116acae7e\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"takeaways-for-you\",\"title\":\"Takeaways for you!\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118717150/N9wgoemc4.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e~ Stephen Hawkings\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that are processing and data efficient. With this in mind, we at Huddle01 are constantly working to improve our video conferencing application while developing the deRTC Protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe ran into a re-rendering issue while optimizing our Huddle01 video conferencing platform. This allowed us to deal with the problem of re-rendering with new solutions more efficiently.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBefore diving into what re-rendering is, let‚Äôs talk about,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is rendering ü§î\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou may have heard of rendering from a friend who edits videos or creates crazy 3D art. Rendering has always been thought of as ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù or a better synonym for ‚Äúloading.‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDepending on the context, the word ‚Äúrendering‚Äù can have several different meanings.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIf you are a video editor or a 3D artist, it refers to the process of generating images or a modal with computers.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDepending on the context, it can mean to cause something to happen or to help someone.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our case of web development, it means gathering different data and either processing or directly sending the output to the screen. Simply put, when you click on a website link, it renders as soon as you are directed to it.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-re-rendering\\\"\u003eWhat is re-rendering ‚öô\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118783606/Kv5cbcgCV.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe know that when a component loads on the screen for the first time, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúrendering.‚Äù Similarly, whenever it‚Äôs loaded again, it‚Äôs called re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy does re-rendering happen üëÄ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhen new information is added to the page, it needs to re-render some parts with further information. For example, when you press various buttons on the website, i.e., interact with it, there are some changes in it. When you press like on a tweet, the number count changes. The specific component which is displaying the like count gets updated.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eGood application architecture refers to minimal re-renders as a part of the design. But re-renders are necessary as many applications have to be interactive.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two types of re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNecessary re-render:\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the name implies, it refers to re-renders that are absolutely necessary. It also means that the re-rendered components are specific, with no effect on a larger scale than that. For example, when you toggle your microphone on and off in the Huddle01 app.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUnnecessary re-rendering:\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs previously discussed, re-rendering is required for an interactive application. However, when unnecessary re-rendering occurs, not only does the specific component re-render, but all other elements that were not involved are also re-rendered. For example, when a keystroke causes the entire page to be re-rendered.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith this background, let‚Äôs see some of the re-rendering issues we faced and how we solved them!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-were-the-issues\\\"\u003eWhat were the issues ‚ùì\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118863431/gsUxcKwsy.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhenever there is a UI update on the screen, a re-render is caused in order to update it for the user. Whenever a button is clicked, a re-render is caused to update the UI. The re-renders are denoted by the green border around the component which is being updated.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our previous iteration of the meeting product (as shown below), there were a lot of re-renders on the UI, which triggered multiple side effects, causing memory leaks. The major reasons for this were:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhenever a peer (or attendee) entered the meeting room, they got added to the list of peers (array of peers) which triggered a re-render to update the grid of peers to show them on the screen.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhenever a speaker gets active, they get prioritized in the grid and the grid is supposed to be reshuffled which caused even more re-renders.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe used redux in the application and destructured properties from the state object using them in the dependency arrays of useEffects.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThese re-renders over time made the app running in the browser slower and slower exponentially as the meeting progressed.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119002218/_x5j7JZ9e.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-did-we-fix-it\\\"\u003eHow did we fix it üõ†\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119022005/cbAznYDfT.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo fix these issues, we made some major changes to our front-end architecture :\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe memoized components using React.memo() wherever necessary, to prevent unnecessary re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe provided unique keys to every peer viewport in the grid so that even if they shuffled in an array a re-render won‚Äôt be required to change their order. We also had to map the peer's array inside a separate child component to prevent re-renders.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe used a library called zustand instead of redux which is much easier to implement as well as has much more re-rendering optimization built-in.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eRather than destructuring the properties from the state object. We created new variables from the state selectors minimizing re-renders even more.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe minimized the use of useEffects for side effects and avoided putting variables in dependency arrays of useEffects.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-takeaways-for-you\\\"\u003eTakeaways for you!\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt may take some time, but if you try to optimize, you will eventually reach a solution that is both effective and intelligent. It took a significant amount of effort and time on our part to bring the app up to its current state of optimal performance. We stayed focused on our primary goal of improving the application and, over time, figured out ways to do so. This effort assisted aspiring developers in finding easy ways to optimize the re-rendering problem.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"Link\\\"\u003eText\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118717150/N9wgoemc4.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n\u003e We are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \\n\u003e \\n\u003e ~ Stephen Hawkings\\n\\nThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that are processing and data efficient. With this in mind, we at Huddle01 are constantly working to improve our video conferencing application while developing the deRTC Protocol.\\n\\nWe ran into a re-rendering issue while optimizing our Huddle01 video conferencing platform. This allowed us to deal with the problem of re-rendering with new solutions more efficiently.\\n\\nBefore diving into what re-rendering is, let‚Äôs talk about,\\n\\n**What is rendering ü§î\\n**\\n\\nYou may have heard of rendering from a friend who edits videos or creates crazy 3D art. Rendering has always been thought of as ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù or a better synonym for ‚Äúloading.‚Äù\\n\\nDepending on the context, the word ‚Äúrendering‚Äù can have several different meanings.\\n\\n- If you are a video editor or a 3D artist, it refers to the process of generating images or a modal with computers.\\n- Depending on the context, it can mean to cause something to happen or to help someone.\\n\\nIn our case of web development, it means gathering different data and either processing or directly sending the output to the screen. Simply put, when you click on a website link, it renders as soon as you are directed to it.\\n\\n## What is re-rendering ‚öô\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118783606/Kv5cbcgCV.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe know that when a component loads on the screen for the first time, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúrendering.‚Äù Similarly, whenever it‚Äôs loaded again, it‚Äôs called re-rendering.\\n\\n**Why does re-rendering happen üëÄ\\n**\\n\\nWhen new information is added to the page, it needs to re-render some parts with further information. For example, when you press various buttons on the website, i.e., interact with it, there are some changes in it. When you press like on a tweet, the number count changes. The specific component which is displaying the like count gets updated.\\n\\nGood application architecture refers to minimal re-renders as a part of the design. But re-renders are necessary as many applications have to be interactive.\\n\\nThere are two types of re-rendering.\\n\\n**Necessary re-render:\\n**\\n\\nAs the name implies, it refers to re-renders that are absolutely necessary. It also means that the re-rendered components are specific, with no effect on a larger scale than that. For example, when you toggle your microphone on and off in the Huddle01 app.\\n\\n**Unnecessary re-rendering:\\n**\\n\\nAs previously discussed, re-rendering is required for an interactive application. However, when unnecessary re-rendering occurs, not only does the specific component re-render, but all other elements that were not involved are also re-rendered. For example, when a keystroke causes the entire page to be re-rendered.\\n\\nWith this background, let‚Äôs see some of the re-rendering issues we faced and how we solved them!\\n\\n## What were the issues ‚ùì\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118863431/gsUxcKwsy.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWhenever there is a UI update on the screen, a re-render is caused in order to update it for the user. Whenever a button is clicked, a re-render is caused to update the UI. The re-renders are denoted by the green border around the component which is being updated.\\n\\nIn our previous iteration of the meeting product (as shown below), there were a lot of re-renders on the UI, which triggered multiple side effects, causing memory leaks. The major reasons for this were:\\n\\n1. Whenever a peer (or attendee) entered the meeting room, they got added to the list of peers (array of peers) which triggered a re-render to update the grid of peers to show them on the screen.\\n\\n2. Whenever a speaker gets active, they get prioritized in the grid and the grid is supposed to be reshuffled which caused even more re-renders.\\n\\n3. We used redux in the application and destructured properties from the state object using them in the dependency arrays of useEffects.\\n\\nThese re-renders over time made the app running in the browser slower and slower exponentially as the meeting progressed.\\n\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119002218/_x5j7JZ9e.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n## How did we fix it üõ†\\n\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119022005/cbAznYDfT.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nTo fix these issues, we made some major changes to our front-end architecture :\\n\\n1. We memoized components using React.memo() wherever necessary, to prevent unnecessary re-rendering.\\n\\n2. We provided unique keys to every peer viewport in the grid so that even if they shuffled in an array a re-render won‚Äôt be required to change their order. We also had to map the peer's array inside a separate child component to prevent re-renders.\\n\\n3. We used a library called zustand instead of redux which is much easier to implement as well as has much more re-rendering optimization built-in.\\n\\n4. Rather than destructuring the properties from the state object. We created new variables from the state selectors minimizing re-renders even more.\\n\\n5. We minimized the use of useEffects for side effects and avoided putting variables in dependency arrays of useEffects.\\n\\n## Takeaways for you!\\nIt may take some time, but if you try to optimize, you will eventually reach a solution that is both effective and intelligent. It took a significant amount of effort and time on our part to bring the app up to its current state of optimal performance. We stayed focused on our primary goal of improving the application and, over time, figured out ways to do so. This effort assisted aspiring developers in finding easy ways to optimize the re-rendering problem.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\n) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)!\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n[Text](Link)\",\"brief\":\"We are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \\n~ Stephen Hawkings\\n\\nThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that a...\",\"author\":{\"_id\":\"632f13813a049a0d9db75b4a\",\"socialMedia\":{\"twitter\":\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\",\"instagram\":\"https://www.instagram.com/huddle01com/?hl=en\",\"github\":\"https://github.com/Huddle01\",\"stackoverflow\":\"\",\"facebook\":\"\",\"website\":\"https://huddle01.com/\",\"linkedin\":\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/huddle-01/\",\"youtube\":\"https://www.youtube.com/@huddle0174\"},\"location\":\"\",\"isBanned\":false,\"isDeactivated\":false,\"numFollowers\":4,\"numFollowing\":0,\"storiesCreated\":[],\"totalUpvotesReceived\":0,\"tagManagerOf\":[],\"isEvangelist\":false,\"isAmbassador\":false,\"hasGoldRing\":false,\"name\":\"Huddle01\",\"username\":\"Huddle01com\",\"tagline\":\"The Communication Toolkit for web3. \":\"https://github.com/Huddle01\",\"stackoverflow\":\"\",\"facebook\":\"\",\"website\":\"https://huddle01.com/\",\"linkedin\":\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/huddle-01/\",\"youtube\":\"https://www.youtube.com/@huddle0174\"},\"location\":\"\",\"isBanned\":false,\"isDeactivated\":false,\"numFollowers\":4,\"numFollowing\":0,\"storiesCreated\":[],\"totalUpvotesReceived\":0,\"tagManagerOf\":[],\"isEvangelist\":false,\"isAmbassador\":false,\"hasGoldRing\":false,\"name\":\"Huddle01\",\"username\":\"Huddle01com\",\"tagline\":\"The
