we fixed Huddle01‚Äôs Re-rendering issues\",\"cuid\":\"cl9ekd418000409l77a7u40k9\",\"dateAdded\":\"2022-10-18T18:53:37.581Z\",\"hasCustomDate\":null,\"isCoverAttributionHidden\":false,\"coverImageAttribution\":\"\",\"coverImagePhotographer\":\"\",\"slug\":\"how-we-fixed-huddle01s-re-rendering-issues\",\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"fb178f62-7474-407f-bb76-8374350168d9\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-re-rendering\",\"title\":\"What is re-rendering ‚öô\"}],[{\"id\":\"6fbe7bc8-b40f-4755-8824-24bdf4eeac04\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-were-the-issues\",\"title\":\"What were the issues ‚ùì\"}],[{\"id\":\"91d91d31-1874-415b-9579-4ed4ecbf20f9\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"how-did-we-fix-it\",\"title\":\"How did we fix it üõ†\"}],[{\"id\":\"1ac400fd-3032-44a6-a659-9aa116acae7e\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"takeaways-for-you\",\"title\":\"Takeaways for you!\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118717150/N9wgoemc4.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e~ Stephen Hawkings\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that are processing and data efficient. With this in mind, we at Huddle01 are constantly working to improve our video conferencing application while developing the deRTC Protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe ran into a re-rendering issue while optimizing our Huddle01 video conferencing platform. This allowed us to deal with the problem of re-rendering with new solutions more efficiently.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBefore diving into what re-rendering is, let‚Äôs talk about,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is rendering ü§î\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou may have heard of rendering from a friend who edits videos or creates crazy 3D art. Rendering has always been thought of as ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù or a better synonym for ‚Äúloading.‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDepending on the context, the word ‚Äúrendering‚Äù can have several different meanings.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIf you are a video editor or a 3D artist, it refers to the process of generating images or a modal with computers.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDepending on the context, it can mean to cause something to happen or to help someone.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our case of web development, it means gathering different data and either processing or directly sending the output to the screen. Simply put, when you click on a website link, it renders as soon as you are directed to it.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-re-rendering\\\"\u003eWhat is re-rendering ‚öô\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118783606/Kv5cbcgCV.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe know that when a component loads on the screen for the first time, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúrendering.‚Äù Similarly, whenever it‚Äôs loaded again, it‚Äôs called re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy does re-rendering happen üëÄ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhen new information is added to the page, it needs to re-render some parts with further information. For example, when you press various buttons on the website, i.e., interact with it, there are some changes in it. When you press like on a tweet, the number count changes. The specific component which is displaying the like count gets updated.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eGood application architecture refers to minimal re-renders as a part of the design. But re-renders are necessary as many applications have to be interactive.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two types of re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNecessary re-render:\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the name implies, it refers to re-renders that are absolutely necessary. It also means that the re-rendered components are specific, with no effect on a larger scale than that. For example, when you toggle your microphone on and off in the Huddle01 app.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUnnecessary re-rendering:\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs previously discussed, re-rendering is required for an interactive application. However, when unnecessary re-rendering occurs, not only does the specific component re-render, but all other elements that were not involved are also re-rendered. For example, when a keystroke causes the entire page to be re-rendered.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith this background, let‚Äôs see some of the re-rendering issues we faced and how we solved them!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-were-the-issues\\\"\u003eWhat were the issues ‚ùì\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118863431/gsUxcKwsy.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhenever there is a UI update on the screen, a re-render is caused in order to update it for the user. Whenever a button is clicked, a re-render is caused to update the UI. The re-renders are denoted by the green border around the component which is being updated.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our previous iteration of the meeting product (as shown below), there were a lot of re-renders on the UI, which triggered multiple side effects, causing memory leaks. The major reasons for this were:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhenever a peer (or attendee) entered the meeting room, they got added to the list of peers (array of peers) which triggered a re-render to update the grid of peers to show them on the screen.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhenever a speaker gets active, they get prioritized in the grid and the grid is supposed to be reshuffled which caused even more re-renders.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe used redux in the application and destructured properties from the state object using them in the dependency arrays of useEffects.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThese re-renders over time made the app running in the browser slower and slower exponentially as the meeting progressed.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119002218/_x5j7JZ9e.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-did-we-fix-it\\\"\u003eHow did we fix it üõ†\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119022005/cbAznYDfT.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo fix these issues, we made some major changes to our front-end architecture :\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe memoized components using React.memo() wherever necessary, to prevent unnecessary re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe provided unique keys to every peer viewport in the grid so that even if they shuffled in an array a re-render won‚Äôt be required to change their order. We also had to map the peer's array inside a separate child component to prevent re-renders.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe used a library called zustand instead of redux which is much easier to implement as well as has much more re-rendering optimization built-in.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eRather than destructuring the properties from the state object. We created new variables from the state selectors minimizing re-renders even more.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe minimized the use of useEffects for side effects and avoided putting variables in dependency arrays of useEffects.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-takeaways-for-you\\\"\u003eTakeaways for you!\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt may take some time, but if you try to optimize, you will eventually reach a solution that is both effective and intelligent. It took a significant amount of effort and time on our part to bring the app up to its current state of optimal performance. We stayed focused on our primary goal of improving the application and, over time, figured out ways to do so. This effort assisted aspiring developers in finding easy ways to optimize the re-rendering problem.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"Link\\\"\u003eText\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118717150/N9wgoemc4.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n\u003e We are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \\n\u003e \\n\u003e ~ Stephen Hawkings\\n\\nThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that are processing and data efficient. With this in mind, we at Huddle01 are constantly working to improve our video conferencing application while developing the deRTC Protocol.\\n\\nWe ran into a re-rendering issue while optimizing our Huddle01 video conferencing platform. This allowed us to deal with the problem of re-rendering with new solutions more efficiently.\\n\\nBefore diving into what re-rendering is, let‚Äôs talk about,\\n\\n**What is rendering ü§î\\n**\\n\\nYou may have heard of rendering from a friend who edits videos or creates crazy 3D art. Rendering has always been thought of as ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù or a better synonym for ‚Äúloading.‚Äù\\n\\nDepending on the context, the word ‚Äúrendering‚Äù can have several different meanings.\\n\\n- If you are a video editor or a 3D artist, it refers to the process of generating images or a modal with computers.\\n- Depending on the context, it can mean to cause something to happen or to help someone.\\n\\nIn our case of web development, it means gathering different data and either processing or directly sending the output to the screen. Simply put, when you click on a website link, it renders as soon as you are directed to it.\\n\\n## What is re-rendering ‚öô\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118783606/Kv5cbcgCV.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe know that when a component loads on the screen for the first time, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúrendering.‚Äù Similarly, whenever it‚Äôs loaded again, it‚Äôs called re-rendering.\\n\\n**Why does re-rendering happen üëÄ\\n**\\n\\nWhen new information is added to the page, it needs to re-render some parts with further information. For example, when you press various buttons on the website, i.e., interact with it, there are some changes in it. When you press like on a tweet, the number count changes. The specific component which is displaying the like count gets updated.\\n\\nGood application architecture refers to minimal re-renders as a part of the design. But re-renders are necessary as many applications have to be interactive.\\n\\nThere are two types of re-rendering.\\n\\n**Necessary re-render:\\n**\\n\\nAs the name implies, it refers to re-renders that are absolutely necessary. It also means that the re-rendered components are specific, with no effect on a larger scale than that. For example, when you toggle your microphone on and off in the Huddle01 app.\\n\\n**Unnecessary re-rendering:\\n**\\n\\nAs previously discussed, re-rendering is required for an interactive application. However, when unnecessary re-rendering occurs, not only does the specific component re-render, but all other elements that were not involved are also re-rendered. For example, when a keystroke causes the entire page to be re-rendered.\\n\\nWith this background, let‚Äôs see some of the re-rendering issues we faced and how we solved them!\\n\\n## What were the issues ‚ùì\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118863431/gsUxcKwsy.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWhenever there is a UI update on the screen, a re-render is caused in order to update it for the user. Whenever a button is clicked, a re-render is caused to update the UI. The re-renders are denoted by the green border around the component which is being updated.\\n\\nIn our previous iteration of the meeting product (as shown below), there were a lot of re-renders on the UI, which triggered multiple side effects, causing memory leaks. The major reasons for this were:\\n\\n1. Whenever a peer (or attendee) entered the meeting room, they got added to the list of peers (array of peers) which triggered a re-render to update the grid of peers to show them on the screen.\\n\\n2. Whenever a speaker gets active, they get prioritized in the grid and the grid is supposed to be reshuffled which caused even more re-renders.\\n\\n3. We used redux in the application and destructured properties from the state object using them in the dependency arrays of useEffects.\\n\\nThese re-renders over time made the app running in the browser slower and slower exponentially as the meeting progressed.\\n\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119002218/_x5j7JZ9e.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n## How did we fix it üõ†\\n\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119022005/cbAznYDfT.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nTo fix these issues, we made some major changes to our front-end architecture :\\n\\n1. We memoized components using React.memo() wherever necessary, to prevent unnecessary re-rendering.\\n\\n2. We provided unique keys to every peer viewport in the grid so that even if they shuffled in an array a re-render won‚Äôt be required to change their order. We also had to map the peer's array inside a separate child component to prevent re-renders.\\n\\n3. We used a library called zustand instead of redux which is much easier to implement as well as has much more re-rendering optimization built-in.\\n\\n4. Rather than destructuring the properties from the state object. We created new variables from the state selectors minimizing re-renders even more.\\n\\n5. We minimized the use of useEffects for side effects and avoided putting variables in dependency arrays of useEffects.\\n\\n## Takeaways for you!\\nIt may take some time, but if you try to optimize, you will eventually reach a solution that is both effective and intelligent. It took a significant amount of effort and time on our part to bring the app up to its current state of optimal performance. We stayed focused on our primary goal of improving the application and, over time, figured out ways to do so. This effort assisted aspiring developers in finding easy ways to optimize the re-rendering problem.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\n) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)!\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n[Text](Link)\",\"brief\":\"We are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \\n~ Stephen Hawkings\\n\\nThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that a...\",\"author\":{\"_id\":\"632f13813a049a0d9db75b4a\",\"socialMedia\":{\"twitter\":\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\",\"instagram\":\"https://www.instagram.com/huddle01com/?hl=en\",\"github\":\"https://github.com/Huddle01\",\"stackoverflow\":\"\",\"facebook\":\"\",\"website\":\"https://huddle01.com/\",\"linkedin\":\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/huddle-01/\",\"youtube\":\"https://www.youtube.com/@huddle0174\"},\"location\":\"\",\"isBanned\":false,\"isDeactivated\":false,\"numFollowers\":4,\"numFollowing\":0,\"storiesCreated\":[],\"totalUpvotesReceived\":0,\"tagManagerOf\":[],\"isEvangelist\":false,\"isAmbassador\":false,\"hasGoldRing\":false,\"name\":\"Huddle01\",\"username\":\"Huddle01com\",\"tagline\":\"The Communication Toolkit for web3. nprogress-spinner{0%{transform:rotate(0)}100%{transform:rotate(360deg)}}@font-face{font-family:'Inter';font-style:normal;font-weight:300;font-display:swap;src:url(https://fonts.gstatic.com/s/inter/v12/UcCO3FwrK3iLTeHuS_fvQtMwCp50KnMw2boKoduKmMEVuOKfMZs.woff) p):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0.8em;margin-bottom:0.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ul > li > *:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ul > li > *:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ol > li > *:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ol > li > *:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(ul ul, ul ol, ol ul, ol ol):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0.8em;margin-bottom:0.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:2.8em;margin-bottom:2.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h2 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h3 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h4 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(table):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){font-size:0.9em;line-height:1.5555556;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td, tfoot td):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-top:0.8888889em;padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:first-child, tfoot td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}The communication toolkit for web3, Huddle01 enables open & seamless cross-chain a/v calls and messaging for wallets, dApps, DAOs, NFT Communities and users. The toolkit includes a feature-rich sufficiently decentralised meeting platform, plug-n-play video conferencing SDK for dApps and dRTC protocol to power the future of real-time communication.
One of the exciting features that our Video Conferencing Platform includes is the ability for organisations, DAOs and NFT Communities to host token-gated meetings. This gives you the ability to conduct invite-only virtual events/calls on the Huddle01 Platform for your web3 fam.
Now let‚Äôs deep dive into the details of how you can token-gate your meetings using POAPs, NFTs, Tokens and Lens ‚§µÔ∏è
üîê First, what is a token-gated meeting?
Let's understand what ‚Äòtoken-gated meetings‚Äô are by first deconstructing the word:

Token-gated: A mechanism where an event is accessed by only tokens. Here, ‚Äòtoken‚Äô means tokens in your crypto wallet.

Meetings: A video conference between users.


Token-gated meetings solve a crucial problem in organisations, guilds, and communities that want to connect and collaborate virtually with complete privacy.
‚öíÔ∏è How does token-gating work?
Token-gated meetings are an upgraded version of the usual meetings when it comes to utility. In terms of how things work in the backend, it is similar to how any authentication tool works.
The differentiating factor here is that verification is less painful on the user side as compared to web2 meetings. Also, the host doesn‚Äôt need to privately share links and go through a complicated procedure to just set up one call.
Now let‚Äôs first understand the problems with the web2 workflow to know the current landscape and why we need token-gated meetings.
üö® Issues with current infrastructure
Fundamentally both web2 and web3 work in a similar fashion to authenticate identities, but the variables used are different, and that is a key differentiator. Let‚Äôs dive into what the exact issues are in the web2 space:

Credentials for verification: Web2 uses different credentials for verification. That usually involves setting up an email. That email has a verification method once it is set up. You need to set up passwords for the video conferencing service that is going to be used, and so on. This also creates an issue where you have to remember many passwords, and then your mailbox looks like a mess. Token-gated meetings just need their wallet to be connected to verify the existence of the existing tokens. If you have them, then you can enter; or else not. No need to create accounts on third-party services and plague your inbox with spam mail.

Setting up meetings: It is tough to set up exclusive meetings. You either collect everyone‚Äôs email addresses to create a meeting in everyone‚Äôs calendar, or you can use tools like Luma that ease the last part, but it‚Äôs hectic. For token-gated meetings, you just need to let users mint a specific token as they become a part of your exclusive organization. That token becomes an identifier for your attendees during meetings.

Hard to track exclusive events: Your inboxes are always full of invites, and your calendar always has some pending approval to set up a meeting. It also becomes difficult to hunt for specific links in email for those meetings. With tokens, everything is abstracted! Just share the link on public channels. Only the folks with a token can enter, so no worries about maintaining secrecy around links.

Difficulty in repeating events: Once you set up an exclusive event, there is always a threat that if someone external gets the link, the exclusivity of the event is instantly lost. You‚Äôll need to repeat to schedule a new meeting with a new link.

Difficult to maintain anonymity: The current infrastructure needs you to reveal your identity in some or the other way. With so many layers of verification and authentication involved, it is really hard to maintain an anonymous identity. At Token-gated events, you can be either completely anonymous or pseudo-anonymous as only your wallet and token are required for the verification.


‚úÖ Advantages of Token-gated meetings
Token-gated meetings are helpful in a lot of specific use cases. Let's see how:

Influencer events: Influencers can add layer of connection with their fans. People who want to get in touch with a lot of folks but want to filter out the crowd in tiers to give them access to specific content based on the token they hold.

Easy setup: Unlike the tiresome web2 setup, web3 token-gated meetings take just 2 quick steps to be scheduled. You first have to set up a process to mint certain tokens for the call, or you can use already existing ones to filter out the attendees. The second step is to just schedule a meeting and share the link on public channels. And it‚Äôs done! You‚Äôve successfully hosted your first-token gated meeting.

Reusability: The links for exclusive meetings can be reused for recurring events. The same tokens and links can be used to host regular community calls.

Organisation-friendly: The good part about token-gated meetings is that they work with all kinds of organizations. People in hierarchal organizations can be given links to different token mints so that they get access to different tiers of meetings, which provides every user with variable access to the organization. Just a basic subdomain and landing pages would do the trick instead of setting up the entire organization on Microsoft Teams or Google Suite or any other tool.


ü™ô Huddle01 and Token gating

If you are wondering if Token gated meetings are awesome, we have good news for you - you can now host Token-gated calls for your organisation or community using the Huddle01 platform. Here are the tokens we currently support:

POAPs: We support token-gating using POAPs (Proof of Attention Protocol) tokens, ensuring that only users who have the required tokens can access the calls.

Token:
 a. Ethereum: We support ERC20 and ERC721 tokens for token-gating an event on the Ethereum chain.
 b. Polygon: Similarly, we yet again support ERC20 and ERC721 for token-gating on the Polygon chain.

NFTs: You can token-gate Huddle01 meeting for your community with NFTs live on Ethereum and Polygon


Looking at the impressive growth of the Lens Community in the previous year, we‚Äôve also introduced Lens Social Graph support on the platform, you can now token-gate your meetings and soon live streaming, using Lens Handle üåø and attributes like:

Followed a particular profile

Collected a particular post

Mirrored a particular post


We are also working on adding more chains so that you can invite diverse attendees to your meetings or calls.
That's a wrap! ‚ú®
Now that you know how easy it is to host token-gated meetings, go ahead and schedule one for your community. In case you have some doubts or need help setting that up, feel free to reach out to us on Discord or Twitter, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•
Try out Huddle01 for a quick meeting üé•

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);

              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

It also becomes difficult to hunt for specific links in email for those meetings.\u003cbr /\u003e With tokens, everything is abstracted! Just share the link on public channels. Only the folks with a token can enter, so no worries about maintaining secrecy around links.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDifficulty in repeating events:\u003c/strong\u003e Once you set up an exclusive event, there is always a threat that if someone external gets the link, the exclusivity of the event is instantly lost. You‚Äôll need to repeat to schedule a new meeting with a new link.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDifficult to maintain anonymity:\u003c/strong\u003e The current infrastructure needs you to reveal your identity in some or the other way. With so many layers of verification and authentication involved, it is really hard to maintain an anonymous identity. At Token-gated events, you can be either completely anonymous or pseudo-anonymous as only your wallet and token are required for the verification.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-advantages-of-token-gated-meetings\\\"\u003e‚úÖ Advantages of Token-gated meetings\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eToken-gated meetings are helpful in a lot of specific use cases. Let's see how:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInfluencer events:\u003c/strong\u003e Influencers can add layer of connection with their fans. People who want to get in touch with a lot of folks but want to filter out the crowd in tiers to give them access to specific content based on the token they hold.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEasy setup:\u003c/strong\u003e Unlike the tiresome web2 setup, web3 token-gated meetings take just 2 quick steps to be scheduled. You first have to set up a process to mint certain tokens for the call, or you can use already existing ones to filter out the attendees. The second step is to just schedule a meeting and share the link on public channels. And it‚Äôs done! You‚Äôve successfully hosted your first-token gated meeting.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eReusability:\u003c/strong\u003e The links for exclusive meetings can be reused for recurring events. The same tokens and links can be used to host regular community calls.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOrganisation-friendly:\u003c/strong\u003e The good part about token-gated meetings is that they work with all kinds of organizations. People in hierarchal organizations can be given links to different token mints so that they get access to different tiers of meetings, which provides every user with variable access to the organization. Just a basic subdomain and landing pages would do the trick instead of setting up the entire organization on Microsoft Teams or Google Suite or any other tool.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-and-token-gating\\\"\u003eü™ô Huddle01 and Token gating\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1674198609736/b6cd5b59-f947-4d93-b7df-c0f515261051.png\\\" alt class=\\\"image--center mx-auto\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are wondering if Token gated meetings are awesome, we have good news for you - you can now host Token-gated calls for your organisation or community using the Huddle01 platform. Here are the tokens we currently support:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePOAPs:\u003c/strong\u003e We support token-gating using POAPs (Proof of Attention Protocol) tokens, ensuring that only users who have the required tokens can access the calls.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eToken:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e a. Ethereum: We support ERC20 and ERC721 tokens for token-gating an event on the Ethereum chain.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e b. Polygon: Similarly, we yet again support ERC20 and ERC721 for token-gating on the Polygon chain.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNFTs:\u003c/strong\u003e You can token-gate Huddle01 meeting for your community with NFTs live on Ethereum and Polygon\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLooking at the impressive growth of the Lens Community in the previous year, we‚Äôve also introduced Lens Social Graph support on the platform, you can now token-gate your meetings and soon live streaming, using Lens Handle üåø and attributes like:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eFollowed a particular profile\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eCollected a particular post\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eMirrored a particular post\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are also working on adding more chains so that you can invite diverse attendees to your meetings or calls.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-thats-a-wrap\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThat's a wrap! ‚ú®\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow that you know how easy it is to host token-gated meetings, go ahead and \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com/status/1565709946742009856?s=20\u0026amp;t=-zMSoOVWLpPS3vOHazpXjA\\\"\u003eschedule one for your community\u003c/a\u003e. In case you have some doubts or need help setting that up, feel free to reach out to us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDiscord\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTwitter\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTry out Huddle01\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e for a quick meeting üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"The communication toolkit for web3, Huddle01 enables open \u0026 seamless cross-chain a/v calls and messaging for wallets, dApps, DAOs, NFT Communities and users. The toolkit includes a feature-rich sufficiently decentralised meeting platform, plug-n-play video conferencing SDK for dApps and dRTC protocol to power the future of real-time communication.\\n\\nOne of the exciting features that our Video Conferencing Platform includes is the ability for organisations, DAOs and NFT Communities to host token-gated meetings. This gives you the ability to conduct invite-only virtual events/calls on the Huddle01 Platform for your web3 fam.\\n\\nNow let‚Äôs deep dive into the details of how you can token-gate your meetings using POAPs, NFTs, Tokens and Lens ‚§µÔ∏è\\n\\n### **üîê¬†First, what is a token-gated meeting?**\\n\\nLet's understand what ‚Äòtoken-gated meetings‚Äô are by first deconstructing the word:\\n\\n* **Token-gated:** A mechanism where an event is accessed by only tokens. Here, ‚Äòtoken‚Äô means tokens in your crypto wallet.\\n    \\n* **Meetings:** A video conference between users.\\n    \\n\\nToken-gated meetings solve a crucial problem in organisations, guilds, and communities that want to connect and collaborate virtually with complete privacy.\\n\\n### **‚öíÔ∏è¬†How does token-gating work?**\\n\\nToken-gated meetings are an upgraded version of the usual meetings when it comes to utility. In terms of how things work in the backend, it is similar to how any authentication tool works.\\n\\nThe differentiating factor here is that verification is less painful on the user side as compared to web2 meetings. Also, the host doesn‚Äôt need to privately share links and go through a complicated procedure to just set up one call.\\n\\nNow let‚Äôs first understand the problems with the web2 workflow to know the current landscape and why we need token-gated meetings.\\n\\n### üö®¬†Issues with current infrastructure\\n\\nFundamentally both web2 and web3 work in a similar fashion to authenticate identities, but the variables used are different, and that is a key differentiator. Let‚Äôs dive into what the exact issues are in the web2 space:\\n\\n1. **Credentials for verification:** Web2 uses different credentials for verification. That usually involves setting up an email. That email has a verification method once it is set up. You need to set up passwords for the video conferencing service that is going to be used, and so on. This also creates an issue where you have to remember many passwords, and then your mailbox looks like a mess. Token-gated meetings just need their wallet to be connected to verify the existence of the existing tokens. If you have them, then you can enter; or else not. No need to create accounts on third-party services and plague your inbox with spam mail.\\n    \\n2. **Setting up meetings:** It is tough to set up exclusive meetings. You either collect everyone‚Äôs email addresses to create a meeting in everyone‚Äôs calendar, or you can use tools like Luma that ease the last part, but it‚Äôs hectic. For token-gated meetings, you just need to let users mint a specific token as they become a part of your exclusive organization. That token becomes an identifier for your attendees during meetings.\\n    \\n3. **Hard to track exclusive events:** Your inboxes are always full of invites, and your calendar always has some pending approval to set up a meeting. It also becomes difficult to hunt for specific links in email for those meetings.  \\n    With tokens, everything is abstracted! Just share the link on public channels. Only the folks with a token can enter, so no worries about maintaining secrecy around links.\\n    \\n4. **Difficulty in repeating events:** Once you set up an exclusive event, there is always a threat that if someone external gets the link, the exclusivity of the event is instantly lost. You‚Äôll need to repeat to schedule a new meeting with a new link.\\n    \\n5. **Difficult to maintain anonymity:** The current infrastructure needs you to reveal your identity in some or the other way. With so many layers of verification and authentication involved, it is really hard to maintain an anonymous identity. At Token-gated events, you can be either completely anonymous or pseudo-anonymous as only your wallet and token are required for the verification.\\n    \\n\\n### ‚úÖ¬†Advantages of Token-gated meetings\\n\\nToken-gated meetings are helpful in a lot of specific use cases. Let's see how:\\n\\n1. **Influencer events:** Influencers can add layer of connection with their fans. People who want to get in touch with a lot of folks but want to filter out the crowd in tiers to give them access to specific content based on the token they hold.\\n    \\n2. **Easy setup:** Unlike the tiresome web2 setup, web3 token-gated meetings take just 2 quick steps to be scheduled. You first have to set up a process to mint certain tokens for the call, or you can use already existing ones to filter out the attendees. The second step is to just schedule a meeting and share the link on public channels. And it‚Äôs done! You‚Äôve successfully hosted your first-token gated meeting.\\n    \\n3. **Reusability:** The links for exclusive meetings can be reused for recurring events. The same tokens and links can be used to host regular community calls.\\n    \\n4. **Organisation-friendly:** The good part about token-gated meetings is that they work with all kinds of organizations. People in hierarchal organizations can be given links to different token mints so that they get access to different tiers of meetings, which provides every user with variable access to the organization. Just a basic subdomain and landing pages would do the trick instead of setting up the entire organization on Microsoft Teams or Google Suite or any other tool.\\n    \\n\\n## ü™ô¬†Huddle01 and Token gating\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1674198609736/b6cd5b59-f947-4d93-b7df-c0f515261051.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\nIf you are wondering if Token gated meetings are awesome, we have good news for you - you can now host Token-gated calls for your organisation or community using the Huddle01 platform. Here are the tokens we currently support:\\n\\n1. **POAPs:** We support token-gating using POAPs (Proof of Attention Protocol) tokens, ensuring that only users who have the required tokens can access the calls.\\n    \\n2. **Token:**\\n    \\n    a. Ethereum: We support ERC20 and ERC721 tokens for token-gating an event on the Ethereum chain.\\n    \\n    b. Polygon: Similarly, we yet again support ERC20 and ERC721 for token-gating on the Polygon chain.\\n    \\n3. **NFTs:** You can token-gate Huddle01 meeting for your community with NFTs live on Ethereum and Polygon\\n    \\n\\nLooking at the impressive growth of the Lens Community in the previous year, we‚Äôve also introduced Lens Social Graph support on the platform, you can now token-gate your meetings and soon live streaming, using Lens Handle üåø and attributes like:\\n\\n1. Followed a particular profile\\n    \\n2. Collected a particular post\\n    \\n3. Mirrored a particular post\\n    \\n\\nWe are also working on adding more chains so that you can invite diverse attendees to your meetings or calls.\\n\\n### **That's a wrap! ‚ú®**\\n\\nNow that you know how easy it is to host token-gated meetings, go ahead and [schedule one for your community](https://twitter.com/huddle01com/status/1565709946742009856?s=20\u0026t=-zMSoOVWLpPS3vOHazpXjA). In case you have some doubts or need help setting that up, feel free to reach out to us on [**Discord**](http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ) or [**Twitter**](https://twitter.com/huddle01com), and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\\n\\n[**Try out Huddle01**](https://huddle01.com/) for a quick meeting üé•\",\"brief\":\"The communication toolkit for web3, Huddle01 enables open \u0026 seamless cross-chain a/v calls and messaging for wallets, dApps, DAOs, NFT Communities and users. How does token-gating work?\"}],[{\"id\":\"21a64cc2-8786-4fca-8aed-ef11c08298e2\",\"level\":3,\"previousLevel\":3,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"issues-with-current-infrastructure\",\"title\":\"üö® Issues with current Token-gated meetings\"}],[{\"id\":\"3805251b-db64-48bb-bf26-44af893813d6\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":3,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"huddle01-and-token-gating\",\"title\":\"ü™ô Huddle01 and Token gating\"}],[{\"id\":\"10eceaa3-33a2-433d-a35d-54e3b7854874\",\"level\":3,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":\"3805251b-db64-48bb-bf26-44af893813d6\",\"slug\":\"thats-a-wrap\",\"title\":\"That's a wrap! ‚ú®\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eThe communication toolkit for web3, Huddle01 enables open \u0026amp; seamless cross-chain a/v calls and messaging for wallets, dApps, DAOs, NFT Communities and users. The toolkit includes a feature-rich sufficiently decentralised meeting platform, plug-n-play video conferencing SDK for dApps and dRTC protocol to power the future of real-time communication.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOne of the exciting features that our Video Conferencing Platform includes is the ability for organisations, DAOs and NFT Communities to host token-gated meetings. This gives you the ability to conduct invite-only virtual events/calls on the Huddle01 Platform for your web3 fam.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow let‚Äôs deep dive into the details of how you can token-gate your meetings using POAPs, NFTs, Tokens and Lens ‚§µÔ∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-first-what-is-a-token-gated-meeting\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eüîê First, what is a token-gated meeting?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet's understand what ‚Äòtoken-gated meetings‚Äô are by first deconstructing the word:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eToken-gated:\u003c/strong\u003e A mechanism where an event is accessed by only tokens. Here, ‚Äòtoken‚Äô means tokens in your crypto wallet.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMeetings:\u003c/strong\u003e A video conference between users.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eToken-gated meetings solve a crucial problem in organisations, guilds, and communities that want to connect and collaborate virtually with complete privacy.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-how-does-token-gating-work\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e‚öíÔ∏è How does token-gating work?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eToken-gated meetings are an upgraded version of the usual meetings when it comes to utility. In terms of how things work in the backend, it is similar to how any authentication tool works.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe differentiating factor here is that verification is less painful on the user side as compared to web2 meetings. Also, the host doesn‚Äôt need to privately share links and go through a complicated procedure to just set up one call.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow let‚Äôs first understand the problems with the web2 workflow to know the current landscape and why we need token-gated meetings.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-issues-with-current-infrastructure\\\"\u003eüö® Issues with current infrastructure\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFundamentally both web2 and web3 work in a similar fashion to authenticate identities, but the variables used are different, and that is a key differentiator. Let‚Äôs dive into what the exact issues are in the web2 space:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCredentials for verification:\u003c/strong\u003e Web2 uses different credentials for verification. That usually involves setting up an email. That email has a verification method once it is set up. You need to set up passwords for the video conferencing service that is going to be used, and so on. This also creates an issue where you have to remember many passwords, and then your mailbox looks like a mess. Token-gated meetings just need their wallet to be connected to verify the existence of the existing tokens. If you have them, then you can enter; or else not. No need to create accounts on third-party services and plague your inbox with spam mail.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSetting up meetings:\u003c/strong\u003e It is tough to set up exclusive meetings. You either collect everyone‚Äôs email addresses to create a meeting in everyone‚Äôs calendar, or you can use tools like Luma that ease the last part, but it‚Äôs hectic. For token-gated meetings, you just need to let users mint a specific token as they become a part of your exclusive organization. That token becomes an identifier for your attendees during meetings.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHard to track exclusive events:\u003c/strong\u003e Your inboxes are always full of invites, and your calendar always has some pending approval to set up a meeting. It also becomes difficult to hunt for specific links in email for those meetings.\u003cbr /\u003e With tokens, everything is abstracted! Just share the link on public channels. Only the folks with a token can enter, so no worries about maintaining secrecy around links.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDifficulty in repeating events:\u003c/strong\u003e Once you set up an exclusive event, there is always a threat that if someone external gets the link, the exclusivity of the event is instantly lost. You‚Äôll need to repeat to schedule a new meeting with a new link.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDifficult to maintain anonymity:\u003c/strong\u003e The current infrastructure needs you to reveal your identity in some or the other way. With so many layers of verification and authentication involved, it is really hard to maintain an anonymous identity. At Token-gated events, you can be either completely anonymous or pseudo-anonymous as only your wallet and token are required for the verification.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-advantages-of-token-gated-meetings\\\"\u003e‚úÖ Advantages of Token-gated meetings\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eToken-gated meetings are helpful in a lot of specific use cases. Let's see how:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInfluencer events:\u003c/strong\u003e Influencers can add layer of connection with their fans. People who want to get in touch with a lot of folks but want to filter out the crowd in tiers to give them access to specific content based on the token they hold.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEasy setup:\u003c/strong\u003e Unlike the tiresome web2 setup, web3 token-gated meetings take just 2 quick steps to be scheduled. You first have to set up a process to mint certain tokens for the call, or you can use already existing ones to filter out the attendees. The second step is to just schedule a meeting and share the link on public channels. And it‚Äôs done! You‚Äôve successfully hosted your first-token gated meeting.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eReusability:\u003c/strong\u003e The links for exclusive meetings can be reused for recurring events. The same tokens and links can be used to host regular community calls.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOrganisation-friendly:\u003c/strong\u003e The good part about token-gated meetings is that they work with all kinds of organizations. People in hierarchal organizations can be given links to different token mints so that they get access to different tiers of meetings, which provides every user with variable access to the organization. Just a basic subdomain and landing pages would do the trick instead of setting up the entire organization on Microsoft Teams or Google Suite or any other tool.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01-and-token-gating\\\"\u003eü™ô Huddle01 and Token gating\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1674198609736/b6cd5b59-f947-4d93-b7df-c0f515261051.png\\\" alt class=\\\"image--center mx-auto\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are wondering if Token gated meetings are awesome, we have good news for you - you can now host Token-gated calls for your organisation or community using the Huddle01 platform. Here are the tokens we currently support:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePOAPs:\u003c/strong\u003e We support token-gating using POAPs (Proof of Attention Protocol) tokens, ensuring that only users who have the required tokens can access the calls.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eToken:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e a. Ethereum: We support ERC20 and ERC721 tokens for token-gating an event on the Ethereum chain.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e b. Polygon: Similarly, we yet again support ERC20 and ERC721 for token-gating on the Polygon chain.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNFTs:\u003c/strong\u003e You can token-gate Huddle01 meeting for your community with NFTs live on Ethereum and Polygon\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLooking at the impressive growth of the Lens Community in the previous year, we‚Äôve also introduced Lens Social Graph support on the platform, you can now token-gate your meetings and soon live streaming, using Lens Handle üåø and attributes like:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eFollowed a particular profile\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eCollected a particular post\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eMirrored a particular post\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are also working on adding more chains so that you can invite diverse attendees to your meetings or calls.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-thats-a-wrap\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThat's a wrap! ‚ú®\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow that you know how easy it is to host token-gated meetings, go ahead and \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com/status/1565709946742009856?s=20\u0026amp;t=-zMSoOVWLpPS3vOHazpXjA\\\"\u003eschedule one for your community\u003c/a\u003e. In case you have some doubts or need help setting that up, feel free to reach out to us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDiscord\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTwitter\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/\\\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTry out Huddle01\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e for a quick meeting üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"The communication toolkit for web3, Huddle01 enables open \u0026 seamless cross-chain a/v calls and messaging for wallets, dApps, DAOs, NFT Communities and users. The toolkit includes a feature-rich sufficiently decentralised meeting platform, plug-n-play video conferencing SDK for dApps and dRTC protocol to power the future of real-time communication.\\n\\nOne of the exciting features that our Video Conferencing Platform includes is the ability for organisations, DAOs and NFT Communities to host token-gated meetings. This gives you the ability to conduct invite-only virtual events/calls on the Huddle01 Platform for your web3 fam.\\n\\nNow let‚Äôs deep dive into the details of how you can token-gate your meetings using POAPs, NFTs, Tokens and Lens ‚§µÔ∏è\\n\\n### **üîê¬†First, what is a token-gated meeting?**\\n\\nLet's understand what ‚Äòtoken-gated meetings‚Äô are by first deconstructing the word:\\n\\n* **Token-gated:** A mechanism where an event is accessed by only tokens. Here, ‚Äòtoken‚Äô means tokens in your crypto wallet.\\n    \\n* **Meetings:** A video conference between users.\\n    \\n\\nToken-gated meetings solve a crucial problem in organisations, guilds, and communities that want to connect and collaborate virtually with complete privacy.\\n\\n### **‚öíÔ∏è¬†How does token-gating work?**\\n\\nToken-gated meetings are an upgraded version of the usual meetings when it comes to utility. In terms of how things work in the backend, it is similar to how any authentication tool works.\\n\\nThe differentiating factor here is that verification is less painful on the user side as compared to web2 meetings. Also, the host doesn‚Äôt need to privately share links and go through a complicated procedure to just set up one call.\\n\\nNow let‚Äôs first understand the problems with the web2 workflow to know the current landscape and why we need token-gated meetings.\\n\\n### üö®¬†Issues with current infrastructure\\n\\nFundamentally both web2 and web3 work in a similar fashion to authenticate identities, but the variables used are different, and that is a key differentiator. Let‚Äôs dive into what the exact issues are in the web2 space:\\n\\n1. **Credentials for verification:** Web2 uses different credentials for verification. That usually involves setting up an email. That email has a verification method once it is set up. You need to set up passwords for the video conferencing service that is going to be used, and so on. This also creates an issue where you have to remember many passwords, and then your mailbox looks like a mess. Token-gated meetings just need their wallet to be connected to verify the existence of the existing tokens. If you have them, then you can enter; or else not. No need to create accounts on third-party services and plague your inbox with spam mail.\\n    \\n2. **Setting up meetings:** It is tough to set up exclusive meetings. You either collect everyone‚Äôs email addresses to create a meeting in everyone‚Äôs calendar, or you can use tools like Luma that ease the last part, but it‚Äôs hectic. For token-gated meetings, you just need to let users mint a specific token as they become a part of your exclusive organization. That token becomes an identifier for your attendees during meetings.\\n    \\n3. **Hard to track exclusive events:** Your inboxes are always full of invites, and your calendar always has some pending approval to set up a meeting. It also becomes difficult to hunt for specific links in email for those meetings.  \\n    With tokens, everything is abstracted! Just share the link on public channels. Only the folks with a token can enter, so no worries about maintaining secrecy around links.\\n    \\n4. **Difficulty in repeating events:** Once you set up an exclusive event, there is always a threat that if someone external gets the link, the exclusivity of the event is instantly lost. You‚Äôll need to repeat to schedule a new meeting with a new link.\\n    \\n5. **Difficult to maintain anonymity:** The current infrastructure needs you to reveal your identity in some or the other way. With so many layers of verification and authentication involved, it is really hard to maintain an anonymous identity. At Token-gated events, you can be either completely anonymous or pseudo-anonymous as only your wallet and token are required for the verification.\\n    \\n\\n### ‚úÖ¬†Advantages of Token-gated meetings\\n\\nToken-gated meetings are helpful in a lot of specific use cases. Let's see how:\\n\\n1. **Influencer events:** Influencers can add layer of connection with their fans. People who want to get in touch with a lot of folks but want to filter out the crowd in tiers to give them access to specific content based on the token they hold.\\n    \\n2. **Easy setup:** Unlike the tiresome web2 setup, web3 token-gated meetings take just 2 quick steps to be scheduled. You first have to set up a process to mint certain tokens for the call, or you can use already existing ones to filter out the attendees. The second step is to just schedule a meeting and share the link on public channels. And it‚Äôs done! You‚Äôve successfully hosted your first-token gated meeting.\\n    \\n3. **Reusability:** The links for exclusive meetings can be reused for recurring events. The same tokens and links can be used to host regular community calls.\\n    \\n4. **Organisation-friendly:** The good part about token-gated meetings is that they work with all kinds of organizations. People in hierarchal organizations can be given links to different token mints so that they get access to different tiers of meetings, which provides every user with variable access to the organization. Just a basic subdomain and landing pages would do the trick instead of setting up the entire organization on Microsoft Teams or Google Suite or any other tool.\\n    \\n\\n## ü™ô¬†Huddle01 and Token gating\\n\\n![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1674198609736/b6cd5b59-f947-4d93-b7df-c0f515261051.png align=\\\"center\\\")\\n\\nIf you are wondering if Token gated meetings are awesome, we have good news for you - you can now host Token-gated calls for your organisation or community using the Huddle01 platform. Here are the tokens we currently support:\\n\\n1. **POAPs:** We support token-gating using POAPs (Proof of Attention Protocol) tokens, ensuring that only users who have the required tokens can access the calls.\\n    \\n2. **Token:**\\n    \\n    a. Ethereum: We support ERC20 and ERC721 tokens for token-gating an event on the Ethereum chain.\\n    \\n    b. Polygon: Similarly, we yet again support ERC20 and ERC721 for token-gating on the Polygon chain.\\n    \\n3. **NFTs:** You can token-gate Huddle01 meeting for your community with NFTs live on Ethereum and Polygon\\n    \\n\\nLooking at the impressive growth of the Lens Community in the previous year, we‚Äôve also introduced Lens Social Graph support on the platform, you can now token-gate your meetings and soon live streaming, using Lens Handle üåø and attributes like:\\n\\n1. Followed a particular profile\\n    \\n2. Collected a particular post\\n    \\n3. Mirrored a particular post\\n    \\n\\nWe are also working on adding more chains so that you can invite diverse attendees to your meetings or calls.\\n\\n### **That's a wrap! ‚ú®**\\n\\nNow that you know how easy it is to host token-gated meetings, go ahead and [schedule one for your community](https://twitter.com/huddle01com/status/1565709946742009856?s=20\u0026t=-zMSoOVWLpPS3vOHazpXjA). In case you have some doubts or need help setting that up, feel free to reach out to us on [**Discord**](http://discord.gg/ur2vDK7eNJ) or [**Twitter**](https://twitter.com/huddle01com), and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\\n\\n[**Try out Huddle01**](https://huddle01.com/) for a quick meeting üé•\",\"brief\":\"The communication toolkit for web3, Huddle01 enables open \u0026 seamless cross-chain a/v calls and messaging for wallets, dApps, DAOs, NFT Communities and users. li):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0.4em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(ul > li):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0.4em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ul > li p):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0.8em;margin-bottom:0.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ul > li > *:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ul > li > *:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ol > li > *:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > ol > li > *:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0px;}.css-1xzox7c :where(ul ul, ul ol, ol ul, ol ol):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0.8em;margin-bottom:0.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:2.8em;margin-bottom:2.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h2 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h3 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h4 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(table):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){font-size:0.9em;line-height:1.5555556;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td, tfoot td):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-top:0.8888889em;padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:first-child, tfoot td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}
Huddle01 is developing the next generation of communication systems while simultaneously taking a progressive and decentralized approach to the process. We believe the future is decentralized and power is back to the community and not centralized servers or organizations.
In this blog, we are discussing P2P communications, but you might be wondering what is P2P and why are we talking about it. So, without wasting any time, let‚Äôs see what are we going to discuss in this blog.
What is P2P? ü§î

That seems cool, how does it work? üò§

Okay, why did you call it terrible? üò†

Huddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ

As this is out of the way, let‚Äôs put on our thinking hats and dive into this!
What is P2P? ü§î

P2P is an acronym for Peer-to-peer technology that is also sometimes called a Mesh network. This is because of how each computer in a file-sharing system or a node in communication is connected to different elements of the network. This technology was originally developed in the late 1970s for file sharing among computers.
Okay, but what is P2P? üòµ‚Äçüí´

P2P is an architecture or a network in which every element is connected to every other element essentially giving equal power to each element. I know this sounds complicated! But this is how it is defined. Let‚Äôs take a sweet example to understand this.

You are having lunch with your friends. It‚Äôs the good old days of school. Everyone is bringing some or other homemade delight and everyone share with each other. You have fruits, one of your friends has Pizza and one of your friends has brought some cookies. In the end, everyone gets a piece of everyone‚Äôs lunch ü•™
Everyone is having everything and is basically in a way connected with everyone. That‚Äôs pretty much how P2P works. Everyone is connected with everyone üòÅ
This is a great technology that is used in many industries and tech-based startups to this day. P2P has massive adoption and is considered the standard in many fields of innovation, but as we are building the future of communications, let‚Äôs focus on WebRTC, the P2P version of Real-time communications.
That seems cool, how does it work? üò§

WebRTC is an open-source technology that enables people with video conferencing that can be easily integrated into their applications. We already wrote a blog on the subject and you can find it here.
If you don‚Äôt wish to open links and dive deeper, here is a TLDR, There are 3 steps for any connections to get established, and it is a P2P model, so everyone is connected to everyone and shares their amazing lunch.
WebRTC is amazing, it is

Cheap üòâ

As there are no media servers, the media directly flows through users. This means a lesser need for external servers and the cost of operation stays low.

Free to use üí∞

WebRTC is open-source, which means it is free for anyone to integrate into their apps and can change a few things accordingly to the need of your application.

Private üîí

You as the service provider can‚Äôt see the media because it doesn‚Äôt go through your servers. This means more privacy for end users.
This just enforces that P2P is amazing, WebRTC is the best thing ever, but, as each coin has 2 sides, this tech also has some major flaws. Let‚Äôs understand what are these problems when it comes to WebRTC or P2P architecture in communications.
What are the issues? üò†

Without wasting any time, these are major issues:

Centralized Signalling Server üè¶

Signaling server? What is that?
To understand it simply, the signaling server is responsible for identifying and connecting two parties who want to connect. Too technical, I know. You want to send a mail to your friend. You‚Äôll need to put down the address of your friend and also your own address so that it can be traced back to you. 
The mailing company is responsible for safely delivering your mail. In this case, a signaling server is just like a mailing company that can cancel your connection requests, and collect data about your devices and how often you call someone.

CPU processing üíª

Real-Time Communications need constant encoding, decoding, and data processing for a seamless experience. If you got lost in those words, picture this. You are in a video call with your friend, your video is constantly captured and sent across the internet to your friend, now for security and efficiency the video information is compressed and encrypted. 
This requires some processing on both ends as this compressed information once received is decrypted and reconstructed for your friend in real time.

Higher bandwidth üìà

WebRTC doesn‚Äôt use any media servers. This then forces users to have a higher bandwidth on their end as each connection is directly made with each peer. Bandwidth is the amount of information that can be sent in a certain period of time. This means, how fast can you send huge chunks of information? The bandwidth eventually increases with each new person introduced to the call.

Limited connections ‚ùå

Okay, this is pretty simple to understand for the above two reasons. As more people join in, more processing and bandwidth are required, which means as more folks join the call, it becomes heavy for each individual to maintain the processing and bandwidth. This is the prime reason why webRTC isn‚Äôt used in applications that have more than 10 people on a call.

Client-heavy architecture ‚õì

This is a bit technical so stay with me. There are two parties in any architecture. A server, and a client. A server is usually one that processes a massive chunk of data for the client so that more people can use the application at once. In P2P there is no server to process, so it is also called client-heavy architecture.
Huddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ

We are building the future of how we would communicate, so we are building something that would solve this. As of now, we are building solutions for WebRTC that would enable Video conferencing technology to scale for the next generation of internet users üòâ
That‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on Twitter or land on our discord! See you at the next one üëã

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }
