This means a lesser need for external servers and the cost of operation stays low.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eFree to use üí∞\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is open-source, which means it is free for anyone to integrate into their apps and can change a few things accordingly to the need of your application.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003ePrivate üîí\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou as the service provider can‚Äôt see the media because it doesn‚Äôt go through your servers. This means more privacy for end users.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis just enforces that P2P is amazing, WebRTC is the best thing ever, but, as each coin has 2 sides, this tech also has some major flaws. Let‚Äôs understand what are these problems when it comes to WebRTC or P2P architecture in communications.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-are-the-issues\\\"\u003eWhat are the issues? üò†\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114775177/NJsCwSmIG.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWithout wasting any time, these are major issues:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCentralized Signalling Server üè¶\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSignaling server? What is that?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo understand it simply, the signaling server is responsible for identifying and connecting two parties who want to connect. Too technical, I know. You want to send a mail to your friend. You‚Äôll need to put down the address of your friend and also your own address so that it can be traced back to you. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe mailing company is responsible for safely delivering your mail. In this case, a signaling server is just like a mailing company that can cancel your connection requests, and collect data about your devices and how often you call someone.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCPU processing üíª\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eReal-Time Communications need constant encoding, decoding, and data processing for a seamless experience. If you got lost in those words, picture this. You are in a video call with your friend, your video is constantly captured and sent across the internet to your friend, now for security and efficiency the video information is compressed and encrypted. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis requires some processing on both ends as this compressed information once received is decrypted and reconstructed for your friend in real time.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eHigher bandwidth üìà\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC doesn‚Äôt use any media servers. This then forces users to have a higher bandwidth on their end as each connection is directly made with each peer. Bandwidth is the amount of information that can be sent in a certain period of time. This means, how fast can you send huge chunks of information? The bandwidth eventually increases with each new person introduced to the call.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eLimited connections ‚ùå\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, this is pretty simple to understand for the above two reasons. As more people join in, more processing and bandwidth are required, which means as more folks join the call, it becomes heavy for each individual to maintain the processing and bandwidth. This is the prime reason why webRTC isn‚Äôt used in applications that have more than 10 people on a call.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eClient-heavy architecture ‚õì\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is a bit technical so stay with me. There are two parties in any architecture. A server, and a client. A server is usually one that processes a massive chunk of data for the client so that more people can use the application at once. In P2P there is no server to process, so it is also called client-heavy architecture.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01s-take-on-this\\\"\u003eHuddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114895259/Idvq6wpfR.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are building the future of how we would communicate, so we are building something that would solve this. As of now, we are building solutions for WebRTC that would enable Video conferencing technology to scale for the next generation of internet users üòâ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e! See you at the next one üëã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114384336/Y26mkvxBO.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is developing the next generation of communication systems while simultaneously taking a progressive and decentralized approach to the process. We believe the future is decentralized and power is back to the community and not centralized servers or organizations.\\n\\nIn this blog, we are discussing P2P communications, but you might be wondering what is P2P and why are we talking about it. So, without wasting any time, let‚Äôs see what are we going to discuss in this blog.\\n\\n**What is P2P? ü§î\\n**\\n\\n**That seems cool, how does it work? üò§\\n**\\n\\n**Okay, why did you call it terrible? üò†\\n**\\n\\n**Huddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\\n**\\n\\nAs this is out of the way, let‚Äôs put on our thinking hats and dive into this!\\n\\n## What is P2P? ü§î\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114527902/lZw8dThsF.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nP2P is an acronym for Peer-to-peer technology that is also sometimes called a Mesh network. This is because of how each computer in a file-sharing system or a node in communication is connected to different elements of the network. This technology was originally developed in the late 1970s for file sharing among computers.\\n\\n**Okay, but what is P2P? üòµ‚Äçüí´\\n**\\n\\nP2P is an architecture or a network in which every element is connected to every other element essentially giving equal power to each element. I know this sounds complicated! But this is how it is defined. Let‚Äôs take a sweet example to understand this.\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114562446/MQHPBItLT.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nYou are having lunch with your friends. It‚Äôs the good old days of school. Everyone is bringing some or other homemade delight and everyone share with each other. You have fruits, one of your friends has Pizza and one of your friends has brought some cookies. In the end, everyone gets a piece of everyone‚Äôs lunch ü•™\\n\\nEveryone is having everything and is basically in a way connected with everyone. That‚Äôs pretty much how P2P works. Everyone is connected with everyone üòÅ\\n\\nThis is a great technology that is used in many industries and tech-based startups to this day. P2P has massive adoption and is considered the standard in many fields of innovation, but as we are building the future of communications, let‚Äôs focus on WebRTC, the P2P version of Real-time communications.\\n\\n## That seems cool, how does it work? üò§\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114604075/FHpKm-s78.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWebRTC is an open-source technology that enables people with video conferencing that can be easily integrated into their applications. We already wrote a blog on the subject and you can find it [here](https://medium.com/@huddle01/what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it-8580d29f74d4).\\n\\nIf you don‚Äôt wish to open links and dive deeper, here is a TLDR, There are 3 steps for any connections to get established, and it is a P2P model, so everyone is connected to everyone and shares their amazing lunch.\\n\\nWebRTC is amazing, it is\\n\\n- Cheap üòâ\\n\\nAs there are no media servers, the media directly flows through users. This means a lesser need for external servers and the cost of operation stays low.\\n\\n- Free to use üí∞\\n\\nWebRTC is open-source, which means it is free for anyone to integrate into their apps and can change a few things accordingly to the need of your application.\\n\\n- Private üîí\\n\\nYou as the service provider can‚Äôt see the media because it doesn‚Äôt go through your servers. This means more privacy for end users.\\n\\nThis just enforces that P2P is amazing, WebRTC is the best thing ever, but, as each coin has 2 sides, this tech also has some major flaws. Let‚Äôs understand what are these problems when it comes to WebRTC or P2P architecture in communications.\\n\\n## What are the issues? üò†\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114775177/NJsCwSmIG.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWithout wasting any time, these are major issues:\\n\\n- Centralized Signalling Server üè¶\\n\\nSignaling server? What is that?\\n\\nTo understand it simply, the signaling server is responsible for identifying and connecting two parties who want to connect. Too technical, I know. You want to send a mail to your friend. You‚Äôll need to put down the address of your friend and also your own address so that it can be traced back to you. \\n\\nThe mailing company is responsible for safely delivering your mail. In this case, a signaling server is just like a mailing company that can cancel your connection requests, and collect data about your devices and how often you call someone.\\n\\n- CPU processing üíª\\n\\nReal-Time Communications need constant encoding, decoding, and data processing for a seamless experience. If you got lost in those words, picture this. You are in a video call with your friend, your video is constantly captured and sent across the internet to your friend, now for security and efficiency the video information is compressed and encrypted. \\n\\nThis requires some processing on both ends as this compressed information once received is decrypted and reconstructed for your friend in real time.\\n\\n- Higher bandwidth üìà\\n\\nWebRTC doesn‚Äôt use any media servers. This then forces users to have a higher bandwidth on their end as each connection is directly made with each peer. Bandwidth is the amount of information that can be sent in a certain period of time. This means, how fast can you send huge chunks of information? The bandwidth eventually increases with each new person introduced to the call.\\n\\n- Limited connections ‚ùå\\n\\nOkay, this is pretty simple to understand for the above two reasons. As more people join in, more processing and bandwidth are required, which means as more folks join the call, it becomes heavy for each individual to maintain the processing and bandwidth. This is the prime reason why webRTC isn‚Äôt used in applications that have more than 10 people on a call.\\n\\n- Client-heavy architecture ‚õì\\n\\nThis is a bit technical so stay with me. There are two parties in any architecture. A server, and a client. A server is usually one that processes a massive chunk of data for the client so that more people can use the application at once. In P2P there is no server to process, so it is also called client-heavy architecture.\\n\\n## Huddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114895259/Idvq6wpfR.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe are building the future of how we would communicate, so we are building something that would solve this. As of now, we are building solutions for WebRTC that would enable Video conferencing technology to scale for the next generation of internet users üòâ\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! Huddle01 powers decentralised a/v calls \u0026 chat for wallets, dApps, DAOs, Communities \u0026 users üìû üí¨\",\"metaHTML\":\"\u003cp\u003eThe Communication Toolkit for web3. üò§\"}],[{\"id\":\"a6a74ea5-b92a-49dc-bc93-a3a9d323d32b\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-are-the-issues\",\"title\":\"What are the issues? üò†\"}],[{\"id\":\"c0da281c-f2be-4c23-8f58-9d6a7ba23353\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"huddle01s-take-on-this\",\"title\":\"Huddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114384336/Y26mkvxBO.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is developing the next generation of communication systems while simultaneously taking a progressive and decentralized approach to the process. We believe the future is decentralized and power is back to the community and not centralized servers or organizations.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn this blog, we are discussing P2P communications, but you might be wondering what is P2P and why are we talking about it. So, without wasting any time, let‚Äôs see what are we going to discuss in this blog.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is P2P? ü§î\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThat seems cool, how does it work? üò§\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOkay, why did you call it terrible? üò†\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHuddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs this is out of the way, let‚Äôs put on our thinking hats and dive into this!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-p2p\\\"\u003eWhat is P2P? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114527902/lZw8dThsF.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eP2P is an acronym for Peer-to-peer technology that is also sometimes called a Mesh network. This is because of how each computer in a file-sharing system or a node in communication is connected to different elements of the network. This technology was originally developed in the late 1970s for file sharing among computers.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOkay, but what is P2P? üòµ‚Äçüí´\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eP2P is an architecture or a network in which every element is connected to every other element essentially giving equal power to each element. I know this sounds complicated! But this is how it is defined. Let‚Äôs take a sweet example to understand this.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114562446/MQHPBItLT.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou are having lunch with your friends. It‚Äôs the good old days of school. Everyone is bringing some or other homemade delight and everyone share with each other. You have fruits, one of your friends has Pizza and one of your friends has brought some cookies. In the end, everyone gets a piece of everyone‚Äôs lunch ü•™\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eEveryone is having everything and is basically in a way connected with everyone. That‚Äôs pretty much how P2P works. Everyone is connected with everyone üòÅ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is a great technology that is used in many industries and tech-based startups to this day. P2P has massive adoption and is considered the standard in many fields of innovation, but as we are building the future of communications, let‚Äôs focus on WebRTC, the P2P version of Real-time communications.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-that-seems-cool-how-does-it-work\\\"\u003eThat seems cool, how does it work? üò§\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114604075/FHpKm-s78.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is an open-source technology that enables people with video conferencing that can be easily integrated into their applications. We already wrote a blog on the subject and you can find it \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://medium.com/@huddle01/what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it-8580d29f74d4\\\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you don‚Äôt wish to open links and dive deeper, here is a TLDR, There are 3 steps for any connections to get established, and it is a P2P model, so everyone is connected to everyone and shares their amazing lunch.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is amazing, it is\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCheap üòâ\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs there are no media servers, the media directly flows through users. This means a lesser need for external servers and the cost of operation stays low.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eFree to use üí∞\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is open-source, which means it is free for anyone to integrate into their apps and can change a few things accordingly to the need of your application.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003ePrivate üîí\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou as the service provider can‚Äôt see the media because it doesn‚Äôt go through your servers. This means more privacy for end users.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis just enforces that P2P is amazing, WebRTC is the best thing ever, but, as each coin has 2 sides, this tech also has some major flaws. Let‚Äôs understand what are these problems when it comes to WebRTC or P2P architecture in communications.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-are-the-issues\\\"\u003eWhat are the issues? üò†\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114775177/NJsCwSmIG.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWithout wasting any time, these are major issues:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCentralized Signalling Server üè¶\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSignaling server? What is that?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo understand it simply, the signaling server is responsible for identifying and connecting two parties who want to connect. Too technical, I know. You want to send a mail to your friend. You‚Äôll need to put down the address of your friend and also your own address so that it can be traced back to you. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe mailing company is responsible for safely delivering your mail. In this case, a signaling server is just like a mailing company that can cancel your connection requests, and collect data about your devices and how often you call someone.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCPU processing üíª\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eReal-Time Communications need constant encoding, decoding, and data processing for a seamless experience. If you got lost in those words, picture this. You are in a video call with your friend, your video is constantly captured and sent across the internet to your friend, now for security and efficiency the video information is compressed and encrypted. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis requires some processing on both ends as this compressed information once received is decrypted and reconstructed for your friend in real time.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eHigher bandwidth üìà\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC doesn‚Äôt use any media servers. This then forces users to have a higher bandwidth on their end as each connection is directly made with each peer. Bandwidth is the amount of information that can be sent in a certain period of time. This means, how fast can you send huge chunks of information? The bandwidth eventually increases with each new person introduced to the call.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eLimited connections ‚ùå\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, this is pretty simple to understand for the above two reasons. As more people join in, more processing and bandwidth are required, which means as more folks join the call, it becomes heavy for each individual to maintain the processing and bandwidth. This is the prime reason why webRTC isn‚Äôt used in applications that have more than 10 people on a call.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eClient-heavy architecture ‚õì\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is a bit technical so stay with me. There are two parties in any architecture. A server, and a client. A server is usually one that processes a massive chunk of data for the client so that more people can use the application at once. In P2P there is no server to process, so it is also called client-heavy architecture.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-huddle01s-take-on-this\\\"\u003eHuddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114895259/Idvq6wpfR.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are building the future of how we would communicate, so we are building something that would solve this. As of now, we are building solutions for WebRTC that would enable Video conferencing technology to scale for the next generation of internet users üòâ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e! See you at the next one üëã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114384336/Y26mkvxBO.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is developing the next generation of communication systems while simultaneously taking a progressive and decentralized approach to the process. We believe the future is decentralized and power is back to the community and not centralized servers or organizations.\\n\\nIn this blog, we are discussing P2P communications, but you might be wondering what is P2P and why are we talking about it. So, without wasting any time, let‚Äôs see what are we going to discuss in this blog.\\n\\n**What is P2P? ü§î\\n**\\n\\n**That seems cool, how does it work? üò§\\n**\\n\\n**Okay, why did you call it terrible? üò†\\n**\\n\\n**Huddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\\n**\\n\\nAs this is out of the way, let‚Äôs put on our thinking hats and dive into this!\\n\\n## What is P2P? ü§î\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114527902/lZw8dThsF.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nP2P is an acronym for Peer-to-peer technology that is also sometimes called a Mesh network. This is because of how each computer in a file-sharing system or a node in communication is connected to different elements of the network. This technology was originally developed in the late 1970s for file sharing among computers.\\n\\n**Okay, but what is P2P? üòµ‚Äçüí´\\n**\\n\\nP2P is an architecture or a network in which every element is connected to every other element essentially giving equal power to each element. I know this sounds complicated! But this is how it is defined. Let‚Äôs take a sweet example to understand this.\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114562446/MQHPBItLT.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nYou are having lunch with your friends. It‚Äôs the good old days of school. Everyone is bringing some or other homemade delight and everyone share with each other. You have fruits, one of your friends has Pizza and one of your friends has brought some cookies. In the end, everyone gets a piece of everyone‚Äôs lunch ü•™\\n\\nEveryone is having everything and is basically in a way connected with everyone. That‚Äôs pretty much how P2P works. Everyone is connected with everyone üòÅ\\n\\nThis is a great technology that is used in many industries and tech-based startups to this day. P2P has massive adoption and is considered the standard in many fields of innovation, but as we are building the future of communications, let‚Äôs focus on WebRTC, the P2P version of Real-time communications.\\n\\n## That seems cool, how does it work? üò§\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114604075/FHpKm-s78.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWebRTC is an open-source technology that enables people with video conferencing that can be easily integrated into their applications. We already wrote a blog on the subject and you can find it [here](https://medium.com/@huddle01/what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it-8580d29f74d4).\\n\\nIf you don‚Äôt wish to open links and dive deeper, here is a TLDR, There are 3 steps for any connections to get established, and it is a P2P model, so everyone is connected to everyone and shares their amazing lunch.\\n\\nWebRTC is amazing, it is\\n\\n- Cheap üòâ\\n\\nAs there are no media servers, the media directly flows through users. This means a lesser need for external servers and the cost of operation stays low.\\n\\n- Free to use üí∞\\n\\nWebRTC is open-source, which means it is free for anyone to integrate into their apps and can change a few things accordingly to the need of your application.\\n\\n- Private üîí\\n\\nYou as the service provider can‚Äôt see the media because it doesn‚Äôt go through your servers. This means more privacy for end users.\\n\\nThis just enforces that P2P is amazing, WebRTC is the best thing ever, but, as each coin has 2 sides, this tech also has some major flaws. Let‚Äôs understand what are these problems when it comes to WebRTC or P2P architecture in communications.\\n\\n## What are the issues? üò†\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114775177/NJsCwSmIG.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWithout wasting any time, these are major issues:\\n\\n- Centralized Signalling Server üè¶\\n\\nSignaling server? What is that?\\n\\nTo understand it simply, the signaling server is responsible for identifying and connecting two parties who want to connect. Too technical, I know. You want to send a mail to your friend. You‚Äôll need to put down the address of your friend and also your own address so that it can be traced back to you. \\n\\nThe mailing company is responsible for safely delivering your mail. In this case, a signaling server is just like a mailing company that can cancel your connection requests, and collect data about your devices and how often you call someone.\\n\\n- CPU processing üíª\\n\\nReal-Time Communications need constant encoding, decoding, and data processing for a seamless experience. If you got lost in those words, picture this. You are in a video call with your friend, your video is constantly captured and sent across the internet to your friend, now for security and efficiency the video information is compressed and encrypted. \\n\\nThis requires some processing on both ends as this compressed information once received is decrypted and reconstructed for your friend in real time.\\n\\n- Higher bandwidth üìà\\n\\nWebRTC doesn‚Äôt use any media servers. This then forces users to have a higher bandwidth on their end as each connection is directly made with each peer. Bandwidth is the amount of information that can be sent in a certain period of time. This means, how fast can you send huge chunks of information? The bandwidth eventually increases with each new person introduced to the call.\\n\\n- Limited connections ‚ùå\\n\\nOkay, this is pretty simple to understand for the above two reasons. As more people join in, more processing and bandwidth are required, which means as more folks join the call, it becomes heavy for each individual to maintain the processing and bandwidth. This is the prime reason why webRTC isn‚Äôt used in applications that have more than 10 people on a call.\\n\\n- Client-heavy architecture ‚õì\\n\\nThis is a bit technical so stay with me. There are two parties in any architecture. A server, and a client. A server is usually one that processes a massive chunk of data for the client so that more people can use the application at once. In P2P there is no server to process, so it is also called client-heavy architecture.\\n\\n## Huddle01‚Äôs take on this ‚úÖ\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666114895259/Idvq6wpfR.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe are building the future of how we would communicate, so we are building something that would solve this. As of now, we are building solutions for WebRTC that would enable Video conferencing technology to scale for the next generation of internet users üòâ\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! provides web3 video infrastructure that enables users to build efficient and accessible tools to power the next generation of real-time communication. We believe web3 communication should be a public good and our decentralised, product-first approach makes sure we provide better support to every builder/organisation/community looking for a quick and powerful a/v communication plug-in for their website.
What are iFrames? ü§î
iFrames or Inline Frames are used to embed an external HTML document within the current document. It's like having a subpage inside the main one. Advertisements, embedded videos, web analytics, and dynamic content - all make use of them. The best example for this would be how YouTube videos are embedded on websites. That's an iFrame üèó
Why do you need Huddle01 iFrames?
With web apps getting more innovative and collaborative by the day, applications need quick and efficient a/v support to facilitate seamless real-time communication. Creating your own infra requires a lot of time and research. Those resources can be spent building and optimising your core features.
To enable a/v communication on your website just plug n‚Äô play Huddle01 iFrames with a few lines of code and you‚Äôre good to go.
How to use the Huddle01 iFrames? üë©‚Äçüíª
Some pre-requisites for playing around with Huddle01 iFrames:

NodeJS

npm/npx (Installed automatically with node)


Once you have these installed on your local system, there are 2 ways of spinning up a Huddle01 iFrame-powered dApp:
1. Using CLI (Creating a project from scratch)
Just run the single-line command either using yarn or npm
NPM
# Javascript
npx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app
# Typescript
npx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts

YARN
# Javascript 
yarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app

# Typescript 
yarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts

This command will spin up an iFrame sample app in no time. After this you can just navigate into the generated directory and install the dependencies as shown below:
cd my-iframe-app  
npm i # using npm  
#or  
yarn # using yarn

Once the dependencies are installed just run yarn dev or npm run dev to spin up the local server, and you‚Äôll be greeted with the following web page:

Enter the meeting, and all the buttons outside the frame can be used to control the bits inside the Huddle01 App iFrame. That‚Äôs It!
Build all you want on top of this ‚öíÔ∏è
2. Using huddle01-iframe npm pkg (Adding iFrame to a pre-existing application)
To power your pre-existing application with Huddle01 iFrames all you need to do is, navigate into your project directory and run the following command:

# Using NPM  
npm i @huddle01/huddle01-iframe 

#or   
# Using YARN  
yarn add @huddle01/huddle01-iframe

Once this is installed, you need to create a config object similar to the one below:
const iframeConfig = {   
    roomUrl: 'https://iframe.huddle01.com/iframe-test', 
// URL may differ according to subdomain assigned   
    height: '600px',   
    width: '80%',   
    noBorder: false, 
// false by default 
};

The setup is done! Now you can just import the component and render it in your jsx as shown below:
import { HuddleIframe } from '@huddle01/huddle01-iframe';  
const MyApp = () => {   
return <HuddleIframe config={iframeConfig}/> 
}

And you‚Äôre good to go üöÄ
If you want to control the room programmatically, you can do that using the instance methods. For more details check out the docs: https://huddle01.com/docs
All set, time to build üèó
Now that you know easy it is to embed Huddle01 iFrames, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with those. They are super easy to use and integrate.
Looking for some inspiration? Checkout hq.orbits.live to see what successful iframe integration looks like.
Want to get in touch?
Have some doubts or facing an issue with the integration?
Or want us to customise Huddle01 iFrames as per your needs?
Feel free to reach out to us on our Discord or Twitter, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•

              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);

              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

We believe web3 communication should be a public good and our decentralised, product-first approach makes sure we provide better support to every builder/organisation/community looking for a quick and powerful a/v communication plug-in for their website.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-are-iframes\\\"\u003eWhat are iFrames? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eiFrames or Inline Frames are used to embed an external HTML document within the current document. It's like having a subpage inside the main one. Advertisements, embedded videos, web analytics, and dynamic content - all make use of them. The best example for this would be how YouTube videos are embedded on websites. That's an iFrame üèó\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-why-do-you-need-huddle01-iframes\\\"\u003eWhy do you need Huddle01 iFrames?\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith web apps getting more innovative and collaborative by the day, applications need quick and efficient a/v support to facilitate seamless real-time communication. We believe web3 communication should be a public good and our decentralised, product-first approach makes sure we provide better support to every builder/organisation/community looking for a quick and powerful a/v communication plug-in for their website.\\n\\n## What are iFrames? ü§î\\n\\niFrames or Inline Frames are used to embed an external HTML document within the current document. It's like having a subpage inside the main one. Advertisements, embedded videos, web analytics, and dynamic content - all make use of them. The best example for this would be how YouTube videos are embedded on websites. That's an iFrame üèó\\n\\n## Why do you need Huddle01 iFrames?\\n\\nWith web apps getting more innovative and collaborative by the day, applications need quick and efficient a/v support to facilitate seamless real-time communication. Creating your own infra requires a lot of time and research. Those resources can be spent building and optimising your core features.\\n\\nTo enable a/v communication on your website just plug n‚Äô play Huddle01 iFrames with a few lines of code and you‚Äôre good to go.\\n\\n## How to use the Huddle01 iFrames? üë©‚Äçüíª\\n\\nSome pre-requisites for playing around with Huddle01 iFrames:\\n\\n*   [NodeJS](https://nodejs.dev/)\\n    \\n*   npm/npx (Installed automatically with node)\\n    \\n\\nOnce you have these installed on your local system, there are 2 ways of spinning up a Huddle01 iFrame-powered dApp:\\n\\n### 1\\\\. Using CLI (Creating a project from scratch)\\n\\nJust run the single-line command either using yarn or npm\\n\\n### NPM\\n\\n```plaintext\\n# Javascript\\nnpx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app\\n# Typescript\\nnpx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts\\n```\\n\\n### YARN\\n\\n```plaintext\\n# Javascript \\nyarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app\\n  \\n# Typescript \\nyarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts\\n```\\n\\nThis command will spin up an iFrame sample app in no time. After this you can just navigate into the generated directory and install the dependencies as shown below:\\n\\n```plaintext\\ncd my-iframe-app  \\nnpm i # using npm  \\n#or  \\nyarn # using yarn\\n```\\n\\nOnce the dependencies are installed just run yarn dev or npm run dev to spin up the local server, and you‚Äôll be greeted with the following web page:\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666115940991/xvUpgfyPv.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nEnter the meeting, and all the buttons outside the frame can be used to control the bits inside the **Huddle01 App iFrame**. That‚Äôs It!\\n\\nBuild all you want on top of this ‚öíÔ∏è\\n\\n### 2\\\\. Using huddle01-iframe npm pkg (Adding iFrame to a pre-existing application)\\n\\nTo power your pre-existing application with Huddle01 iFrames all you need to do is, navigate into your project directory and run the following command:\\n\\n```plaintext\\n\\n# Using NPM  \\nnpm i @huddle01/huddle01-iframe \\n  \\n#or   \\n# Using YARN  \\nyarn add @huddle01/huddle01-iframe\\n```\\n\\nOnce this is installed, you need to create a config object similar to the one below:\\n\\n```plaintext\\nconst iframeConfig = {   \\n    roomUrl: 'https://iframe.huddle01.com/iframe-test', \\n// URL may differ according to subdomain assigned   \\n    height: '600px',   \\n    width: '80%',   \\n    noBorder: false, \\n// false by default \\n};\\n```\\n\\nThe setup is done! Now you can just import the component and render it in your jsx as shown below:\\n\\n```plaintext\\nimport { HuddleIframe } from '@huddle01/huddle01-iframe';  \\nconst MyApp = () =\u003e {   \\nreturn \u003cHuddleIframe config={iframeConfig}/\u003e \\n}\\n```\\n\\nAnd you‚Äôre good to go üöÄ\\n\\nIf you want to control the room programmatically, you can do that using the instance methods. For more details check out the docs: [https://huddle01.com/docs](https://huddle01.com/docs)\\n\\n## All set, time to build üèó\\n\\nNow that you know easy it is to embed Huddle01 iFrames, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with those. They are super easy to use and integrate.\\n\\nLooking for some inspiration? Checkout [hq.orbits.live](http://hq.orbits.live) to see what successful iframe integration looks like.\\n\\n## Want to get in touch?\\n\\nHave some doubts or facing an issue with the integration?\\n\\nOr want us to customise Huddle01 iFrames as per your needs?\\n\\nFeel free to reach out to us on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com), and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 provides web3 video infrastructure that enables users to build efficient and accessible tools to power the next generation of real-time communication. We believe web3 communication should be a public good and our decentralised, product-first approach makes sure we provide better support to every builder/organisation/community looking for a quick and powerful a/v communication plug-in for their website.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-are-iframes\\\"\u003eWhat are iFrames? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eiFrames or Inline Frames are used to embed an external HTML document within the current document. It's like having a subpage inside the main one. Advertisements, embedded videos, web analytics, and dynamic content - all make use of them. The best example for this would be how YouTube videos are embedded on websites. That's an iFrame üèó\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-why-do-you-need-huddle01-iframes\\\"\u003eWhy do you need Huddle01 iFrames?\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith web apps getting more innovative and collaborative by the day, applications need quick and efficient a/v support to facilitate seamless real-time communication. Creating your own infra requires a lot of time and research. Those resources can be spent building and optimising your core features.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo enable a/v communication on your website just plug n‚Äô play Huddle01 iFrames with a few lines of code and you‚Äôre good to go.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-to-use-the-huddle01-iframes\\\"\u003eHow to use the Huddle01 iFrames? üë©‚Äçüíª\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSome pre-requisites for playing around with Huddle01 iFrames:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://nodejs.dev/\\\"\u003eNodeJS\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003enpm/npx (Installed automatically with node)\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOnce you have these installed on your local system, there are 2 ways of spinning up a Huddle01 iFrame-powered dApp:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-1-using-cli-creating-a-project-from-scratch\\\"\u003e1. Using CLI (Creating a project from scratch)\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eJust run the single-line command either using yarn or npm\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-npm\\\"\u003eNPM\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-plaintext\\\"\u003e# Javascript\\nnpx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app\\n# Typescript\\nnpx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-yarn\\\"\u003eYARN\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-plaintext\\\"\u003e# Javascript \\nyarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app\\n\\n# Typescript \\nyarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis command will spin up an iFrame sample app in no time. After this you can just navigate into the generated directory and install the dependencies as shown below:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-plaintext\\\"\u003ecd my-iframe-app  \\nnpm i # using npm  \\n#or  \\nyarn # using yarn\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOnce the dependencies are installed just run yarn dev or npm run dev to spin up the local server, and you‚Äôll be greeted with the following web page:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666115940991/xvUpgfyPv.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eEnter the meeting, and all the buttons outside the frame can be used to control the bits inside the \u003cstrong\u003eHuddle01 App iFrame\u003c/strong\u003e. That‚Äôs It!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBuild all you want on top of this ‚öíÔ∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-2-using-huddle01-iframe-npm-pkg-adding-iframe-to-a-pre-existing-application\\\"\u003e2. Using huddle01-iframe npm pkg (Adding iFrame to a pre-existing application)\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo power your pre-existing application with Huddle01 iFrames all you need to do is, navigate into your project directory and run the following command:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-plaintext\\\"\u003e\\n# Using NPM  \\nnpm i @huddle01/huddle01-iframe \\n\\n#or   \\n# Using YARN  \\nyarn add @huddle01/huddle01-iframe\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOnce this is installed, you need to create a config object similar to the one below:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-plaintext\\\"\u003econst iframeConfig = {   \\n    roomUrl: 'https://iframe.huddle01.com/iframe-test', \\n// URL may differ according to subdomain assigned   \\n    height: '600px',   \\n    width: '80%',   \\n    noBorder: false, \\n// false by default \\n};\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe setup is done! Now you can just import the component and render it in your jsx as shown below:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\\\"lang-plaintext\\\"\u003eimport { HuddleIframe } from '@huddle01/huddle01-iframe';  \\nconst MyApp = () =\u0026gt; {   \\nreturn \u0026lt;HuddleIframe config={iframeConfig}/\u0026gt; \\n}\\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAnd you‚Äôre good to go üöÄ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you want to control the room programmatically, you can do that using the instance methods. For more details check out the docs: \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://huddle01.com/docs\\\"\u003ehttps://huddle01.com/docs\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-all-set-time-to-build\\\"\u003eAll set, time to build üèó\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow that you know easy it is to embed Huddle01 iFrames, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with those. They are super easy to use and integrate.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLooking for some inspiration? Checkout \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://hq.orbits.live\\\"\u003ehq.orbits.live\u003c/a\u003e to see what successful iframe integration looks like.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-want-to-get-in-touch\\\"\u003eWant to get in touch?\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHave some doubts or facing an issue with the integration?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOr want us to customise Huddle01 iFrames as per your needs?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFeel free to reach out to us on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"Huddle01 provides web3 video infrastructure that enables users to build efficient and accessible tools to power the next generation of real-time communication. We believe web3 communication should be a public good and our decentralised, product-first approach makes sure we provide better support to every builder/organisation/community looking for a quick and powerful a/v communication plug-in for their website.\\n\\n## What are iFrames? ü§î\\n\\niFrames or Inline Frames are used to embed an external HTML document within the current document. It's like having a subpage inside the main one. Advertisements, embedded videos, web analytics, and dynamic content - all make use of them. The best example for this would be how YouTube videos are embedded on websites. That's an iFrame üèó\\n\\n## Why do you need Huddle01 iFrames?\\n\\nWith web apps getting more innovative and collaborative by the day, applications need quick and efficient a/v support to facilitate seamless real-time communication. Creating your own infra requires a lot of time and research. Those resources can be spent building and optimising your core features.\\n\\nTo enable a/v communication on your website just plug n‚Äô play Huddle01 iFrames with a few lines of code and you‚Äôre good to go.\\n\\n## How to use the Huddle01 iFrames? üë©‚Äçüíª\\n\\nSome pre-requisites for playing around with Huddle01 iFrames:\\n\\n*   [NodeJS](https://nodejs.dev/)\\n    \\n*   npm/npx (Installed automatically with node)\\n    \\n\\nOnce you have these installed on your local system, there are 2 ways of spinning up a Huddle01 iFrame-powered dApp:\\n\\n### 1\\\\. Using CLI (Creating a project from scratch)\\n\\nJust run the single-line command either using yarn or npm\\n\\n### NPM\\n\\n```plaintext\\n# Javascript\\nnpx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app\\n# Typescript\\nnpx create-huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts\\n```\\n\\n### YARN\\n\\n```plaintext\\n# Javascript \\nyarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app\\n  \\n# Typescript \\nyarn create huddle01 --tool iframe --name my-iframe-app -ts\\n```\\n\\nThis command will spin up an iFrame sample app in no time. After this you can just navigate into the generated directory and install the dependencies as shown below:\\n\\n```plaintext\\ncd my-iframe-app  \\nnpm i # using npm  \\n#or  \\nyarn # using yarn\\n```\\n\\nOnce the dependencies are installed just run yarn dev or npm run dev to spin up the local server, and you‚Äôll be greeted with the following web page:\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666115940991/xvUpgfyPv.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nEnter the meeting, and all the buttons outside the frame can be used to control the bits inside the **Huddle01 App iFrame**. That‚Äôs It!\\n\\nBuild all you want on top of this ‚öíÔ∏è\\n\\n### 2\\\\. Using huddle01-iframe npm pkg (Adding iFrame to a pre-existing application)\\n\\nTo power your pre-existing application with Huddle01 iFrames all you need to do is, navigate into your project directory and run the following command:\\n\\n```plaintext\\n\\n# Using NPM  \\nnpm i @huddle01/huddle01-iframe \\n  \\n#or   \\n# Using YARN  \\nyarn add @huddle01/huddle01-iframe\\n```\\n\\nOnce this is installed, you need to create a config object similar to the one below:\\n\\n```plaintext\\nconst iframeConfig = {   \\n    roomUrl: 'https://iframe.huddle01.com/iframe-test', \\n// URL may differ according to subdomain assigned   \\n    height: '600px',   \\n    width: '80%',   \\n    noBorder: false, \\n// false by default \\n};\\n```\\n\\nThe setup is done! Now you can just import the component and render it in your jsx as shown below:\\n\\n```plaintext\\nimport { HuddleIframe } from '@huddle01/huddle01-iframe';  \\nconst MyApp = () =\u003e {   \\nreturn \u003cHuddleIframe config={iframeConfig}/\u003e \\n}\\n```\\n\\nAnd you‚Äôre good to go üöÄ\\n\\nIf you want to control the room programmatically, you can do that using the instance methods. For more details check out the docs: [https://huddle01.com/docs](https://huddle01.com/docs)\\n\\n## All set, time to build üèó\\n\\nNow that you know easy it is to embed Huddle01 iFrames, we leave it to your imagination and creativity to play with those. They are super easy to use and integrate.\\n\\nLooking for some inspiration? Checkout [hq.orbits.live](http://hq.orbits.live) to see what successful iframe integration looks like.\\n\\n## Want to get in touch?\\n\\nHave some doubts or facing an issue with the integration?\\n\\nOr want us to customise Huddle01 iFrames as per your needs?\\n\\nFeel free to reach out to us on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com), and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 provides web3 video infrastructure that enables users to build efficient and accessible tools to power the next generation of real-time communication. *)){margin-top:2.8em;margin-bottom:2.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h2 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] :where(table):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){font-size:0.9em;line-height:1.5555556;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}
Huddle01 is building the next generation of communication systems by taking a decentralized approach to improving the current webRTC architecture. If you are wondering what is WebRTC and why it needs to be efficient, you can read it here and here!
If you are lazy just like me and don‚Äôt want to open links to read another two blogs, here is the TLDR for you üòâ

WebRTC is an open-source technology that enables projects to have RTC (Real-time communication) over the internet (Mostly video conferencing, also specific audio applications can be used).

WebRTC is a P2P technology, which basically means everyone is connected with everyone. This means there are a lot of connections! I mean a lot!

This limits WebRTC for scaling (i.e having a lot of friends in the same video call) so alternate technologies like SFU and MCU are used. We are going to focus more on SFU here.


Like always, take a quick look at what you‚Äôll find here so that if you know something, you can just move ahead!
SFU? what‚Äôs that? ü§î

That‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route! üòâ

Cool, is it the best solution? üòé

Why is Huddle01 talking about this? üëÄ

SFU? What‚Äôs that ü§î

SFU stands for Selective Forwarding Unit and is one of the most popular solutions when it comes to scaling WebRTC. The easiest definition after spending a ton of time on google about SFU is,

‚ÄúIn the SFU architecture, every participant sends his or her media stream to a centralized server (SFU) and receives streams from all other participants via the same central server. The architecture allows the call participant to send multiple media streams to the SFU, where the SFU may decide which of the media streams should be forwarded to the other call participants‚Äù by Call stats

In easy language, SFU chooses which stream you should receive and which you shouldn‚Äôt along with a single uplink to the server.
Before further getting into how it works, let‚Äôs first figure out what uplinks and downlinks are. I got you, don‚Äôt worry!
Uplink is the path for audio-video information that you send to your friend in a video call ‚¨Ü
Downlink is the path for audio-video information you receive from your friend ‚¨á

Single uplink:

SFU enables a single uplink, unlike P2P it reduces total uplinks from the total number of peers in the call to just 1. As there is only 1 outgoing channel, it is easier to maintain a single uplink channel.

Selective downlink:

SFU acts like a filter for certain incoming downlinks. If there are 20 people on call and 19 are on mute, there is no need for you to have downlinks to everyone, instead, you‚Äôll optimize to have the audio of just one person that is speaking and that‚Äôs how an SFU works for video and audio communication.
I know, you might be wondering, what are you talking about? I can‚Äôt understand!
That‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route üòâ

Let us try to break down SFU with an example. Have you ever gone to a barbecue party with your friends where everyone brings different food & ingredients and then you make a variety of dishes from the same ‚ùó
For the sake of example, let‚Äôs say you bring chicken wings, your friend brings barbecue sauce, your crush brings some veggies, etc. Now what you do is process the raw food with everyone but in the end, only pick what you‚Äôd like to eat üòã
If you are a vegetarian, you‚Äôd only pick veggies and some lemonade, if you are a hardcore chicken lover then you‚Äôd opt-in for those saucy chicken wings with some beer üçª
Won‚Äôt the party be better if someone just brought you your choice instead of you talking to everyone and then picking food?
That helper, that filter, is SFU!

Rather than talking to everyone and trying everything, you just talk to one person about what you‚Äôd have, and then they help you pick food!
It brings you your preference and you can then zone out the stuff you don‚Äôt like instead of having a piece of everything that is made!
Cool, is it the best solution üòé

Of course not!

It is one of the most adopted solutions depending on your use case!

Fun fact: There is another type of SFU called Multicast SFU that optimizes SFU to the next level called Simulcast SFU. In Simulcast SFU, each client has access to the highest quality streams that its local network bandwidth can support. Thus it solves the issue of the lowest bandwidth problem.

MCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit) is also o an alternative solution that even further reduces the total number of downlinks to 1, this means all the processing and filtering is done on the Server side.
As more people join in on the call, the load on the server increases due to processing done on the server end.
SFU has its own set of benefits, like:

The incoming connection is made to the media server rather than to each participant.
The client does not require a wide outgoing channel because there is only one outgoing stream.
SFU architecture requires fewer server resources than other video conferencing architectures.

Each solution caters to a different problem statement. If your application doesn‚Äôt require you to optimize for more than 5 peers in a video call, then you can just use webRTC and dust off the project in style!
But here is a small comparison chart for you.


Why is Huddle01 talking about this üëÄ

There are a bunch of different solutions that can be applied to scale WebRTC. But, we think SFU is one of the best solutions as it is cost efficient along with and read this very closely, a small alpha, we are building something in which SFU algorithms will play a vital role üòâ
I won‚Äôt say how and when, but a form of SFU is always easy to adopt.
As we mentioned before, we are building the future of how communications will take place over the internet, so it makes sense that we may be coming up with an innovation. That‚Äôs it from our side!
If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on Twitter or land on our discord! See you at the next one üëã

(min-width: 640px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:640px;}}@media (min-width: 768px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:768px;}}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1024px;}}@media (min-width: 1280px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:2;}}@media (min-width: 1536px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:3;}}
              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

If you are wondering what is WebRTC and why it needs to be efficient, you can read it \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://blog.huddle01.com/what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it-8580d29f74d4\\\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://blog.huddle01.com/why-is-p2p-terrible-e1a577aa1b7d\\\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are lazy just like me and don‚Äôt want to open links to read another two blogs, here is the TLDR for you üòâ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is an open-source technology that enables projects to have RTC (Real-time communication) over the internet (Mostly video conferencing, also specific audio applications can be used).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is a P2P technology, which basically means everyone is connected with everyone. This means there are a lot of connections! I mean a lot!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis limits WebRTC for scaling (i.e having a lot of friends in the same video call) so alternate technologies like SFU and MCU are used. We are going to focus more on SFU here.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLike always, take a quick look at what you‚Äôll find here so that if you know something, you can just move ahead!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSFU? what‚Äôs that? ü§î\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThat‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route! üòâ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCool, is it the best solution? üòé\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy is Huddle01 talking about this? üëÄ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-sfu-whats-that\\\"\u003eSFU? What‚Äôs that ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116449511/MGeTr1M-5.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU stands for Selective Forwarding Unit and is one of the most popular solutions when it comes to scaling WebRTC. The easiest definition after spending a ton of time on google about SFU is,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e‚ÄúIn the SFU architecture, every participant sends his or her media stream to a centralized server (SFU) and receives streams from all other participants via the same central server. The architecture allows the call participant to send multiple media streams to the SFU, where the SFU may decide which of the media streams should be forwarded to the other call participants‚Äù by Call stats\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn easy language, SFU chooses which stream you should receive and which you shouldn‚Äôt along with a single uplink to the server.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBefore further getting into how it works, let‚Äôs first figure out what uplinks and downlinks are. I got you, don‚Äôt worry!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eUplink is the path for audio-video information that you send to your friend in a video call ‚¨Ü\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDownlink is the path for audio-video information you receive from your friend ‚¨á\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSingle uplink:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU enables a single uplink, unlike P2P it reduces total uplinks from the total number of peers in the call to just 1. As there is only 1 outgoing channel, it is easier to maintain a single uplink channel.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSelective downlink:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU acts like a filter for certain incoming downlinks. If there are 20 people on call and 19 are on mute, there is no need for you to have downlinks to everyone, instead, you‚Äôll optimize to have the audio of just one person that is speaking and that‚Äôs how an SFU works for video and audio communication.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eI know, you might be wondering, what are you talking about? I can‚Äôt understand!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-thats-way-too-technical-lets-take-an-easy-route\\\"\u003eThat‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route üòâ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116648425/W5xfh-JAW.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet us try to break down SFU with an example. Have you ever gone to a barbecue party with your friends where everyone brings different food \u0026amp; ingredients and then you make a variety of dishes from the same ‚ùó\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFor the sake of example, let‚Äôs say you bring chicken wings, your friend brings barbecue sauce, your crush brings some veggies, etc. Now what you do is process the raw food with everyone but in the end, only pick what you‚Äôd like to eat üòã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are a vegetarian, you‚Äôd only pick veggies and some lemonade, if you are a hardcore chicken lover then you‚Äôd opt-in for those saucy chicken wings with some beer üçª\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWon‚Äôt the party be better if someone just brought you your choice instead of you talking to everyone and then picking food?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThat helper, that filter, is SFU!\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eRather than talking to everyone and trying everything, you just talk to one person about what you‚Äôd have, and then they help you pick food!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt brings you your preference and you can then zone out the stuff you don‚Äôt like instead of having a piece of everything that is made!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-cool-is-it-the-best-solution\\\"\u003eCool, is it the best solution üòé\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116714670/IuOdvwQ-A.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOf course not!\\n\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt is one of the most adopted solutions depending on your use case!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFun fact: There is another type of SFU called Multicast SFU that optimizes SFU to the next level called Simulcast SFU. In Simulcast SFU, each client has access to the highest quality streams that its local network bandwidth can support. Thus it solves the issue of the lowest bandwidth problem.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eMCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit) is also o an alternative solution that even further reduces the total number of downlinks to 1, this means all the processing and filtering is done on the Server side.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs more people join in on the call, the load on the server increases due to processing done on the server end.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU has its own set of benefits, like:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe incoming connection is made to the media server rather than to each participant.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe client does not require a wide outgoing channel because there is only one outgoing stream.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSFU architecture requires fewer server resources than other video conferencing architectures.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eEach solution caters to a different problem statement. If your application doesn‚Äôt require you to optimize for more than 5 peers in a video call, then you can just use webRTC and dust off the project in style!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBut here is a small comparison chart for you.\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116786661/eXiuNMhtD.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-why-is-huddle01-talking-about-this\\\"\u003eWhy is Huddle01 talking about this üëÄ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116888275/6ycXOb8xZ.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are a bunch of different solutions that can be applied to scale WebRTC. But, we think SFU is one of the best solutions as it is cost efficient along with and read this very closely, a small alpha, we are building something in which SFU algorithms will play a vital role üòâ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eI won‚Äôt say how and when, but a form of SFU is always easy to adopt.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs we mentioned before, we are building the future of how communications will take place over the internet, so it makes sense that we may be coming up with an innovation. That‚Äôs it from our side!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e! See you at the next one üëã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116303542/AerIqlPYE.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is building the next generation of communication systems by taking a decentralized approach to improving the current webRTC architecture. If you are wondering what is WebRTC and why it needs to be efficient, you can read it [here](https://blog.huddle01.com/what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it-8580d29f74d4) and [here](https://blog.huddle01.com/why-is-p2p-terrible-e1a577aa1b7d)!\\n\\nIf you are lazy just like me and don‚Äôt want to open links to read another two blogs, here is the TLDR for you üòâ\\n\\n1. WebRTC is an open-source technology that enables projects to have RTC (Real-time communication) over the internet (Mostly video conferencing, also specific audio applications can be used).\\n\\n2. WebRTC is a P2P technology, which basically means everyone is connected with everyone. This means there are a lot of connections! I mean a lot!\\n\\n3. This limits WebRTC for scaling (i.e having a lot of friends in the same video call) so alternate technologies like SFU and MCU are used. We are going to focus more on SFU here.\\n\\nLike always, take a quick look at what you‚Äôll find here so that if you know something, you can just move ahead!\\n\\n**SFU? what‚Äôs that? ü§î\\n**\\n\\n**That‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route! üòâ\\n**\\n\\n**Cool, is it the best solution? üòé\\n**\\n\\n**Why is Huddle01 talking about this? üëÄ\\n**\\n\\n## SFU? What‚Äôs that ü§î\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116449511/MGeTr1M-5.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nSFU stands for Selective Forwarding Unit and is one of the most popular solutions when it comes to scaling WebRTC. The easiest definition after spending a ton of time on google about SFU is,\\n\\n\u003e ‚ÄúIn the SFU architecture, every participant sends his or her media stream to a centralized server (SFU) and receives streams from all other participants via the same central server. The architecture allows the call participant to send multiple media streams to the SFU, where the SFU may decide which of the media streams should be forwarded to the other call participants‚Äù by Call stats\\n\\nIn easy language, SFU chooses which stream you should receive and which you shouldn‚Äôt along with a single uplink to the server.\\n\\nBefore further getting into how it works, let‚Äôs first figure out what uplinks and downlinks are. I got you, don‚Äôt worry!\\n\\nUplink is the path for audio-video information that you send to your friend in a video call ‚¨Ü\\n\\nDownlink is the path for audio-video information you receive from your friend ‚¨á\\n\\n- Single uplink:\\n\\nSFU enables a single uplink, unlike P2P it reduces total uplinks from the total number of peers in the call to just 1. As there is only 1 outgoing channel, it is easier to maintain a single uplink channel.\\n\\n- Selective downlink:\\n\\nSFU acts like a filter for certain incoming downlinks. If there are 20 people on call and 19 are on mute, there is no need for you to have downlinks to everyone, instead, you‚Äôll optimize to have the audio of just one person that is speaking and that‚Äôs how an SFU works for video and audio communication.\\n\\nI know, you might be wondering, what are you talking about? I can‚Äôt understand!\\n\\n## That‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route üòâ\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116648425/W5xfh-JAW.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLet us try to break down SFU with an example. Have you ever gone to a barbecue party with your friends where everyone brings different food \u0026 ingredients and then you make a variety of dishes from the same ‚ùó\\n\\nFor the sake of example, let‚Äôs say you bring chicken wings, your friend brings barbecue sauce, your crush brings some veggies, etc. Now what you do is process the raw food with everyone but in the end, only pick what you‚Äôd like to eat üòã\\n\\nIf you are a vegetarian, you‚Äôd only pick veggies and some lemonade, if you are a hardcore chicken lover then you‚Äôd opt-in for those saucy chicken wings with some beer üçª\\n\\nWon‚Äôt the party be better if someone just brought you your choice instead of you talking to everyone and then picking food?\\n\\n**That helper, that filter, is SFU!\\n**\\n\\nRather than talking to everyone and trying everything, you just talk to one person about what you‚Äôd have, and then they help you pick food!\\n\\nIt brings you your preference and you can then zone out the stuff you don‚Äôt like instead of having a piece of everything that is made!\\n\\n## Cool, is it the best solution üòé\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116714670/IuOdvwQ-A.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n*Of course not!\\n*\\n\\nIt is one of the most adopted solutions depending on your use case!\\n\\n\u003e Fun fact: There is another type of SFU called Multicast SFU that optimizes SFU to the next level called Simulcast SFU. In Simulcast SFU, each client has access to the highest quality streams that its local network bandwidth can support. Thus it solves the issue of the lowest bandwidth problem.\\n\\nMCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit) is also o an alternative solution that even further reduces the total number of downlinks to 1, this means all the processing and filtering is done on the Server side.\\n\\nAs more people join in on the call, the load on the server increases due to processing done on the server end.\\n\\nSFU has its own set of benefits, like:\\n\\n- The incoming connection is made to the media server rather than to each participant.\\n- The client does not require a wide outgoing channel because there is only one outgoing stream.\\n- SFU architecture requires fewer server resources than other video conferencing architectures.\\n\\nEach solution caters to a different problem statement. If your application doesn‚Äôt require you to optimize for more than 5 peers in a video call, then you can just use webRTC and dust off the project in style!\\n\\n**But here is a small comparison chart for you.\\n**\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116786661/eXiuNMhtD.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n## Why is Huddle01 talking about this üëÄ\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116888275/6ycXOb8xZ.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThere are a bunch of different solutions that can be applied to scale WebRTC. But, we think SFU is one of the best solutions as it is cost efficient along with and read this very closely, a small alpha, we are building something in which SFU algorithms will play a vital role üòâ\\n\\nI won‚Äôt say how and when, but a form of SFU is always easy to adopt.\\n\\nAs we mentioned before, we are building the future of how communications will take place over the internet, so it makes sense that we may be coming up with an innovation. That‚Äôs it from our side!\\n\\nIf you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! See you at the next one üëã\\n\\n\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is building the next generation of communication systems by taking a decentralized approach to improving the current webRTC architecture.
