What‚Äôs that ü§î\"}],[{\"id\":\"ffbd9e7c-9f71-44a1-89d5-912c2a57cf97\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"thats-way-too-technical-lets-take-an-easy-route\",\"title\":\"That‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route üòâ\"}],[{\"id\":\"22cdd560-c838-4769-91f8-848a186d7373\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"cool-is-it-the-best-solution\",\"title\":\"Cool, is it the best solution üòé\"}],[{\"id\":\"55791f33-7273-4f94-868e-515f7c2d40f4\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"why-is-huddle01-talking-about-this\",\"title\":\"Why is Huddle01 talking about this üëÄ\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116303542/AerIqlPYE.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is building the next generation of communication systems by taking a decentralized approach to improving the current webRTC architecture. If you are wondering what is WebRTC and why it needs to be efficient, you can read it \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://blog.huddle01.com/what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it-8580d29f74d4\\\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://blog.huddle01.com/why-is-p2p-terrible-e1a577aa1b7d\\\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are lazy just like me and don‚Äôt want to open links to read another two blogs, here is the TLDR for you üòâ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is an open-source technology that enables projects to have RTC (Real-time communication) over the internet (Mostly video conferencing, also specific audio applications can be used).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is a P2P technology, which basically means everyone is connected with everyone. This means there are a lot of connections! I mean a lot!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis limits WebRTC for scaling (i.e having a lot of friends in the same video call) so alternate technologies like SFU and MCU are used. We are going to focus more on SFU here.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLike always, take a quick look at what you‚Äôll find here so that if you know something, you can just move ahead!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSFU? what‚Äôs that? ü§î\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThat‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route! üòâ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCool, is it the best solution? üòé\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy is Huddle01 talking about this? üëÄ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-sfu-whats-that\\\"\u003eSFU? What‚Äôs that ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116449511/MGeTr1M-5.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU stands for Selective Forwarding Unit and is one of the most popular solutions when it comes to scaling WebRTC. The easiest definition after spending a ton of time on google about SFU is,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e‚ÄúIn the SFU architecture, every participant sends his or her media stream to a centralized server (SFU) and receives streams from all other participants via the same central server. The architecture allows the call participant to send multiple media streams to the SFU, where the SFU may decide which of the media streams should be forwarded to the other call participants‚Äù by Call stats\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn easy language, SFU chooses which stream you should receive and which you shouldn‚Äôt along with a single uplink to the server.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBefore further getting into how it works, let‚Äôs first figure out what uplinks and downlinks are. I got you, don‚Äôt worry!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eUplink is the path for audio-video information that you send to your friend in a video call ‚¨Ü\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDownlink is the path for audio-video information you receive from your friend ‚¨á\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSingle uplink:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU enables a single uplink, unlike P2P it reduces total uplinks from the total number of peers in the call to just 1. As there is only 1 outgoing channel, it is easier to maintain a single uplink channel.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSelective downlink:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU acts like a filter for certain incoming downlinks. If there are 20 people on call and 19 are on mute, there is no need for you to have downlinks to everyone, instead, you‚Äôll optimize to have the audio of just one person that is speaking and that‚Äôs how an SFU works for video and audio communication.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eI know, you might be wondering, what are you talking about? I can‚Äôt understand!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-thats-way-too-technical-lets-take-an-easy-route\\\"\u003eThat‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route üòâ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116648425/W5xfh-JAW.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet us try to break down SFU with an example. Have you ever gone to a barbecue party with your friends where everyone brings different food \u0026amp; ingredients and then you make a variety of dishes from the same ‚ùó\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFor the sake of example, let‚Äôs say you bring chicken wings, your friend brings barbecue sauce, your crush brings some veggies, etc. Now what you do is process the raw food with everyone but in the end, only pick what you‚Äôd like to eat üòã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are a vegetarian, you‚Äôd only pick veggies and some lemonade, if you are a hardcore chicken lover then you‚Äôd opt-in for those saucy chicken wings with some beer üçª\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWon‚Äôt the party be better if someone just brought you your choice instead of you talking to everyone and then picking food?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThat helper, that filter, is SFU!\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eRather than talking to everyone and trying everything, you just talk to one person about what you‚Äôd have, and then they help you pick food!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt brings you your preference and you can then zone out the stuff you don‚Äôt like instead of having a piece of everything that is made!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-cool-is-it-the-best-solution\\\"\u003eCool, is it the best solution üòé\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116714670/IuOdvwQ-A.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOf course not!\\n\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt is one of the most adopted solutions depending on your use case!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFun fact: There is another type of SFU called Multicast SFU that optimizes SFU to the next level called Simulcast SFU. In Simulcast SFU, each client has access to the highest quality streams that its local network bandwidth can support. Thus it solves the issue of the lowest bandwidth problem.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eMCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit) is also o an alternative solution that even further reduces the total number of downlinks to 1, this means all the processing and filtering is done on the Server side.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs more people join in on the call, the load on the server increases due to processing done on the server end.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU has its own set of benefits, like:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe incoming connection is made to the media server rather than to each participant.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe client does not require a wide outgoing channel because there is only one outgoing stream.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSFU architecture requires fewer server resources than other video conferencing architectures.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eEach solution caters to a different problem statement. If your application doesn‚Äôt require you to optimize for more than 5 peers in a video call, then you can just use webRTC and dust off the project in style!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBut here is a small comparison chart for you.\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116786661/eXiuNMhtD.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-why-is-huddle01-talking-about-this\\\"\u003eWhy is Huddle01 talking about this üëÄ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116888275/6ycXOb8xZ.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are a bunch of different solutions that can be applied to scale WebRTC. But, we think SFU is one of the best solutions as it is cost efficient along with and read this very closely, a small alpha, we are building something in which SFU algorithms will play a vital role üòâ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eI won‚Äôt say how and when, but a form of SFU is always easy to adopt.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs we mentioned before, we are building the future of how communications will take place over the internet, so it makes sense that we may be coming up with an innovation. That‚Äôs it from our side!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e! See you at the next one üëã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116303542/AerIqlPYE.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is building the next generation of communication systems by taking a decentralized approach to improving the current webRTC architecture. If you are wondering what is WebRTC and why it needs to be efficient, you can read it [here](https://blog.huddle01.com/what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it-8580d29f74d4) and [here](https://blog.huddle01.com/why-is-p2p-terrible-e1a577aa1b7d)!\\n\\nIf you are lazy just like me and don‚Äôt want to open links to read another two blogs, here is the TLDR for you üòâ\\n\\n1. WebRTC is an open-source technology that enables projects to have RTC (Real-time communication) over the internet (Mostly video conferencing, also specific audio applications can be used).\\n\\n2. WebRTC is a P2P technology, which basically means everyone is connected with everyone. This means there are a lot of connections! I mean a lot!\\n\\n3. This limits WebRTC for scaling (i.e having a lot of friends in the same video call) so alternate technologies like SFU and MCU are used. We are going to focus more on SFU here.\\n\\nLike always, take a quick look at what you‚Äôll find here so that if you know something, you can just move ahead!\\n\\n**SFU? what‚Äôs that? ü§î\\n**\\n\\n**That‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route! üòâ\\n**\\n\\n**Cool, is it the best solution? üòé\\n**\\n\\n**Why is Huddle01 talking about this? üëÄ\\n**\\n\\n## SFU? What‚Äôs that ü§î\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116449511/MGeTr1M-5.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nSFU stands for Selective Forwarding Unit and is one of the most popular solutions when it comes to scaling WebRTC. The easiest definition after spending a ton of time on google about SFU is,\\n\\n\u003e ‚ÄúIn the SFU architecture, every participant sends his or her media stream to a centralized server (SFU) and receives streams from all other participants via the same central server. The architecture allows the call participant to send multiple media streams to the SFU, where the SFU may decide which of the media streams should be forwarded to the other call participants‚Äù by Call stats\\n\\nIn easy language, SFU chooses which stream you should receive and which you shouldn‚Äôt along with a single uplink to the server.\\n\\nBefore further getting into how it works, let‚Äôs first figure out what uplinks and downlinks are. I got you, don‚Äôt worry!\\n\\nUplink is the path for audio-video information that you send to your friend in a video call ‚¨Ü\\n\\nDownlink is the path for audio-video information you receive from your friend ‚¨á\\n\\n- Single uplink:\\n\\nSFU enables a single uplink, unlike P2P it reduces total uplinks from the total number of peers in the call to just 1. As there is only 1 outgoing channel, it is easier to maintain a single uplink channel.\\n\\n- Selective downlink:\\n\\nSFU acts like a filter for certain incoming downlinks. If there are 20 people on call and 19 are on mute, there is no need for you to have downlinks to everyone, instead, you‚Äôll optimize to have the audio of just one person that is speaking and that‚Äôs how an SFU works for video and audio communication.\\n\\nI know, you might be wondering, what are you talking about? I can‚Äôt understand!\\n\\n## That‚Äôs way too technical, let‚Äôs take an easy route üòâ\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116648425/W5xfh-JAW.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLet us try to break down SFU with an example. Have you ever gone to a barbecue party with your friends where everyone brings different food \u0026 ingredients and then you make a variety of dishes from the same ‚ùó\\n\\nFor the sake of example, let‚Äôs say you bring chicken wings, your friend brings barbecue sauce, your crush brings some veggies, etc. Now what you do is process the raw food with everyone but in the end, only pick what you‚Äôd like to eat üòã\\n\\nIf you are a vegetarian, you‚Äôd only pick veggies and some lemonade, if you are a hardcore chicken lover then you‚Äôd opt-in for those saucy chicken wings with some beer üçª\\n\\nWon‚Äôt the party be better if someone just brought you your choice instead of you talking to everyone and then picking food?\\n\\n**That helper, that filter, is SFU!\\n**\\n\\nRather than talking to everyone and trying everything, you just talk to one person about what you‚Äôd have, and then they help you pick food!\\n\\nIt brings you your preference and you can then zone out the stuff you don‚Äôt like instead of having a piece of everything that is made!\\n\\n## Cool, is it the best solution üòé\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116714670/IuOdvwQ-A.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n*Of course not!\\n*\\n\\nIt is one of the most adopted solutions depending on your use case!\\n\\n\u003e Fun fact: There is another type of SFU called Multicast SFU that optimizes SFU to the next level called Simulcast SFU. In Simulcast SFU, each client has access to the highest quality streams that its local network bandwidth can support. Thus it solves the issue of the lowest bandwidth problem.\\n\\nMCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit) is also o an alternative solution that even further reduces the total number of downlinks to 1, this means all the processing and filtering is done on the Server side.\\n\\nAs more people join in on the call, the load on the server increases due to processing done on the server end.\\n\\nSFU has its own set of benefits, like:\\n\\n- The incoming connection is made to the media server rather than to each participant.\\n- The client does not require a wide outgoing channel because there is only one outgoing stream.\\n- SFU architecture requires fewer server resources than other video conferencing architectures.\\n\\nEach solution caters to a different problem statement. If your application doesn‚Äôt require you to optimize for more than 5 peers in a video call, then you can just use webRTC and dust off the project in style!\\n\\n**But here is a small comparison chart for you.\\n**\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116786661/eXiuNMhtD.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n## Why is Huddle01 talking about this üëÄ\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666116888275/6ycXOb8xZ.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThere are a bunch of different solutions that can be applied to scale WebRTC. But, we think SFU is one of the best solutions as it is cost efficient along with and read this very closely, a small alpha, we are building something in which SFU algorithms will play a vital role üòâ\\n\\nI won‚Äôt say how and when, but a form of SFU is always easy to adopt.\\n\\nAs we mentioned before, we are building the future of how communications will take place over the internet, so it makes sense that we may be coming up with an innovation. That‚Äôs it from our side!\\n\\nIf you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}
The pandemic made us sit at home, stuck to movies, series, and in most cases, following a creator who live-streams a game or a reaction to an amazing piece of content.
This actually changed the distribution of how much internet is actually in video format and it makes up about 80% of the Internet. Let that settle in.

80% of the stuff on the Internet is video! üì∫
If we imagine the internet as the World, and the total water mass as video content, then the earth won‚Äôt have its largest continent! üåè

Before getting into streaming, let‚Äôs clarify what I mean by live streaming ‚ÅâÔ∏è
Live streaming is being on either side of a live broadcast, which means, something is seen as it happens with minimum delay over the internet ‚ö°
The best example is, any major sports tournament viewed on the app, creators live-streaming a game and an audience experiencing in real-time (with a minimum delay of course)
Different centralized streaming infrastructure.

One of the biggest contributors to this is live-streaming services like Twitch, Youtube, and many more applications that enable people to have that real-time experience while they watch something. Statistically, the retention of a live viewer is 20% more than a pre-recorded video or a movie.
There are an array of services that enable different people with different needs to live stream stuff. Depending on your need, you can either

Integrate the service into your application
Use the service as a creator
Use the service as a telecasting service

Depending on your need, you get different services that provide a seamless experience. But you might be thinking,
What is your point here? üí¢

The thing is, it is an amazing service but it is problematic in its working, and is often expensive as you scale and try it make yourself.
How does it work? ü§î

Live streaming is an amazing feat of engineering that requires a set of different innovations that work together to provide a user with a live experience with minimum delay. It can be divided into 4 basic steps as

Video capture üìπ
Video encoding and segmentation üè™
CDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è
Decoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è

Here are some words that are difficult to understand, but stay with me as I‚Äôll try to explain this in non-tech terms as much as possible. With that, let‚Äôs understand each of the steps,

Video capture üìπ

As the name suggests, the video is captured from a source. Be it a camera, a game, or a video you are reacting on. This is pretty basic and the video captured is then forwarded to video encoding.

Video encoding and segmentation üè™

Let‚Äôs first understand the meaning of the words ‚ÄòEncoding‚Äô and ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô as they seem like complex things. Encoding means converting a type of information into another type of information so that it is easier to read.
If you want to communicate via text or a letter, you write it down, in a way changing the type of information so that it is easier for the other person to understand it.
Moving onto ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô, this means Dividing a large chunk of information into smaller chunks so that you can move it faster and more efficiently.
Imagine Segmentation as a process where you dismantle a chair so that you can fit it in a box and reassemble it once you reach your destination.
The above two things are performed on the raw audio video file from the first step.

CDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è

The first two steps are easy. The main innovation is here. The CDN is responsible for optimizing the delivery of the small data packets to every viewer who wants to watch the stream.
What is a data packet ‚ùì

In our case, a data packet is a small encoded video, which was segmented for better transportation.
Coming back to our CDN, it is a powerful server, that not only optimizes what data packets go to which device, so that the device gets real-time video, but along with maintaining the integrity of the initial data packets.
CDN is like a super merch store that gives out everyone the same merch, but in different sizes for different people. So, if you are a huge guy with lots of muscle (in our case, a great bandwidth internet) you‚Äôll get your XL size at the same time as our intern, who is a cat with no muscles (in this case, a user with less internet bandwidth), CDN paired with caching improves the efficiency of the CDN as a whole.
Wait, what is caching? üò†

Caching is a simple process of storing some data so that when the same request is made, it is loaded faster.
WHAT? üòï

Imagine you own a cafe and you have a customer who comes every day and drinks the same coffee. After a point, you ready the basic ingredients for the coffee, sometimes even heat the milk before the customer comes, to serve him faster. This is caching.
If you want to know more about CDNs read this blog, it is a really great resource!

Decoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è

The data packets are received at the user‚Äôs device. Now it‚Äôs time read them and start the original video. Here decoding comes into play. Remember we wrote a letter in the second step, now it‚Äôs time to open it and read what it says.
Once you are done decoding, you just play the video from step one and viola! You now know how live streaming works.
You might be thinking, THIS IS AMAZING!
What are the issues you were talking about?
Well, let me list it down for you,

CDNs are extremely expensive as they are sometimes working to optimize for millions of concurrent viewers.
The distance between the nearest server connected to CDN and your device may be large, thus delaying your live stream by a significant margin.
If the live streamer and the audience are in close vicinity, and the server is far away, there would be a delay in the stream as data packets would be traveling a long distance.
These are centralized options, so there would be a concern for privacy.

Let‚Äôs move to the juicy part of the blog, so what is the web3 alternative for this?
It‚Äôs Livepeer üòâ

Livepeer- What‚Äôs that? üì∂

Livepeer is a web3 alternative for streaming services. It is a decentralized protocol that enables people to include Livestream in their applications. Here the catch is, the processing of encoding and decoding is outsourced to miners.
Miners can charge different competitive rates for the use of their hardware. You have a choice to choose from. In their own words,

‚ÄúLivepeer is a protocol for developers who want to add a live or on-demand video to their project. It aims to increase the reliability of video streaming while reducing costs associated with it by up to 50x‚Äù

Livepeer is a protocol that enables all people to be a part of the protocol as it benefits engineers, broadcasters, users, and miners altogether. They also have Tokenomics that help delegators to be a part of their Protocol.
How does Huddle01 work with Livepeer? ü§ù

As Huddle01 is bringing innovation in communication via the internet, it is obvious that we are also upgrading the existing infrastructure with new features like live streaming. We support streaming with Livepeer, Youtube, and Twitch. Thus, it is easier for creators and users to instantly start a live stream for creators across platforms.
Bonus! We got featured in the Livepeer Studios blog, you can find it here.
That‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on Twitter or land on our discord! See you at the next one üëã

(min-width: 640px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:640px;}}@media (min-width: 768px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:768px;}}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1024px;}}@media (min-width:               var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

It can be divided into 4 basic steps as\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo capture üìπ\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo encoding and segmentation üè™\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDecoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some words that are difficult to understand, but stay with me as I‚Äôll try to explain this in non-tech terms as much as possible. With that, let‚Äôs understand each of the steps,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo capture üìπ\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the name suggests, the video is captured from a source. Be it a camera, a game, or a video you are reacting on. This is pretty basic and the video captured is then forwarded to video encoding.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo encoding and segmentation üè™\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs first understand the meaning of the words ‚ÄòEncoding‚Äô and ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô as they seem like complex things. Encoding means converting a type of information into another type of information so that it is easier to read.\\nIf you want to communicate via text or a letter, you write it down, in a way changing the type of information so that it is easier for the other person to understand it.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eMoving onto ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô, this means Dividing a large chunk of information into smaller chunks so that you can move it faster and more efficiently.\\nImagine Segmentation as a process where you dismantle a chair so that you can fit it in a box and reassemble it once you reach your destination.\\nThe above two things are performed on the raw audio video file from the first step.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe first two steps are easy. The main innovation is here. The CDN is responsible for optimizing the delivery of the small data packets to every viewer who wants to watch the stream.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is a data packet ‚ùì\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our case, a data packet is a small encoded video, which was segmented for better transportation.\\nComing back to our CDN, it is a powerful server, that not only optimizes what data packets go to which device, so that the device gets real-time video, but along with maintaining the integrity of the initial data packets.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eCDN is like a super merch store that gives out everyone the same merch, but in different sizes for different people. So, if you are a huge guy with lots of muscle (in our case, a great bandwidth internet) you‚Äôll get your XL size at the same time as our intern, who is a cat with no muscles (in this case, a user with less internet bandwidth), CDN paired with caching improves the efficiency of the CDN as a whole.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWait, what is caching? üò†\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eCaching is a simple process of storing some data so that when the same request is made, it is loaded faster.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWHAT? üòï\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eImagine you own a cafe and you have a customer who comes every day and drinks the same coffee. After a point, you ready the basic ingredients for the coffee, sometimes even heat the milk before the customer comes, to serve him faster. This is caching.\\nIf you want to know more about CDNs read this blog, it is a really great resource!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDecoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe data packets are received at the user‚Äôs device. Now it‚Äôs time read them and start the original video. Here decoding comes into play. Remember we wrote a letter in the second step, now it‚Äôs time to open it and read what it says.\\nOnce you are done decoding, you just play the video from step one and viola! You now know how live streaming works.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou might be thinking, \u003cstrong\u003eTHIS IS AMAZING!\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhat are the issues you were talking about?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWell, let me list it down for you,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCDNs are extremely expensive as they are sometimes working to optimize for millions of concurrent viewers.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe distance between the nearest server connected to CDN and your device may be large, thus delaying your live stream by a significant margin.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIf the live streamer and the audience are in close vicinity, and the server is far away, there would be a delay in the stream as data packets would be traveling a long distance.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThese are \u003cstrong\u003ecentralized\u003c/strong\u003e options, so there would be a concern for privacy.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs move to the juicy part of the blog, so what is the web3 alternative for this?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt‚Äôs Livepeer üòâ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-livepeer-whats-that\\\"\u003eLivepeer- What‚Äôs that? üì∂\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117581649/wwsyG6drr.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLivepeer is a web3 alternative for streaming services. It is a decentralized protocol that enables people to include Livestream in their applications. Here the catch is, the processing of encoding and decoding is outsourced to miners.\\nMiners can charge different competitive rates for the use of their hardware. You have a choice to choose from. In their own words,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e‚ÄúLivepeer is a protocol for developers who want to add a live or on-demand video to their project. It aims to increase the reliability of video streaming while reducing costs associated with it by up to 50x‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLivepeer is a protocol that enables all people to be a part of the protocol as it benefits engineers, broadcasters, users, and miners altogether. They also have Tokenomics that help delegators to be a part of their Protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-does-huddle01-work-with-livepeer\\\"\u003eHow does Huddle01 work with Livepeer? ü§ù\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117614706/Z9PJD8dVD.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs Huddle01 is bringing innovation in communication via the internet, it is obvious that we are also upgrading the existing infrastructure with new features like live streaming. We support streaming with Livepeer, Youtube, and Twitch. Thus, it is easier for creators and users to instantly start a live stream for creators across platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBonus! We got featured in the Livepeer Studios blog, you can find it here.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it from our side! See you at the next one üëã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117168287/X_qXGUx1a.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThe pandemic made us sit at home, stuck to movies, series, and in most cases, following a creator who live-streams a game or a reaction to an amazing piece of content.\\nThis actually changed the distribution of how much internet is actually in video format and it makes up about 80% of the Internet. Let that settle in.\\n\\n\u003e 80% of the stuff on the Internet is video! üì∫\\n\u003e If we imagine the internet as the World, and the total water mass as video content, then the earth won‚Äôt have its largest continent! üåè\\n\\nBefore getting into streaming, let‚Äôs clarify what I mean by live streaming ‚ÅâÔ∏è\\nLive streaming is being on either side of a live broadcast, which means, something is seen as it happens with minimum delay over the internet ‚ö°\\n\\nThe best example is, any major sports tournament viewed on the app, creators live-streaming a game and an audience experiencing in real-time (with a minimum delay of course)\\n\\n## Different centralized streaming infrastructure.\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117257877/0Xl4JS3d5.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nOne of the biggest contributors to this is live-streaming services like Twitch, Youtube, and many more applications that enable people to have that real-time experience while they watch something. Statistically, the retention of a live viewer is 20% more than a pre-recorded video or a movie.\\n\\nThere are an array of services that enable different people with different needs to live stream stuff. Depending on your need, you can either\\n\\n- Integrate the service into your application\\n- Use the service as a creator\\n- Use the service as a telecasting service\\n\\nDepending on your need, you get different services that provide a seamless experience. But you might be thinking,\\n\\n**What is your point here? üí¢\\n**\\n\\nThe thing is, it is an amazing service but it is problematic in its working, and is often expensive as you scale and try it make yourself.\\n\\n## How does it work? ü§î\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117331613/M22tMTXBI.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLive streaming is an amazing feat of engineering that requires a set of different innovations that work together to provide a user with a live experience with minimum delay. It can be divided into 4 basic steps as\\n\\n1. Video capture üìπ\\n2. Video encoding and segmentation üè™\\n3. CDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\\n4. Decoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\\n\\nHere are some words that are difficult to understand, but stay with me as I‚Äôll try to explain this in non-tech terms as much as possible. With that, let‚Äôs understand each of the steps,\\n\\n- Video capture üìπ\\n\\nAs the name suggests, the video is captured from a source. Be it a camera, a game, or a video you are reacting on. This is pretty basic and the video captured is then forwarded to video encoding.\\n\\n- Video encoding and segmentation üè™\\n\\nLet‚Äôs first understand the meaning of the words ‚ÄòEncoding‚Äô and ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô as they seem like complex things. Encoding means converting a type of information into another type of information so that it is easier to read.\\nIf you want to communicate via text or a letter, you write it down, in a way changing the type of information so that it is easier for the other person to understand it.\\n\\nMoving onto ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô, this means Dividing a large chunk of information into smaller chunks so that you can move it faster and more efficiently.\\nImagine Segmentation as a process where you dismantle a chair so that you can fit it in a box and reassemble it once you reach your destination.\\nThe above two things are performed on the raw audio video file from the first step.\\n\\n- CDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\\n\\nThe first two steps are easy. The main innovation is here. The CDN is responsible for optimizing the delivery of the small data packets to every viewer who wants to watch the stream.\\n\\n**What is a data packet ‚ùì\\n**\\n\\nIn our case, a data packet is a small encoded video, which was segmented for better transportation.\\nComing back to our CDN, it is a powerful server, that not only optimizes what data packets go to which device, so that the device gets real-time video, but along with maintaining the integrity of the initial data packets.\\n\\nCDN is like a super merch store that gives out everyone the same merch, but in different sizes for different people. So, if you are a huge guy with lots of muscle (in our case, a great bandwidth internet) you‚Äôll get your XL size at the same time as our intern, who is a cat with no muscles (in this case, a user with less internet bandwidth), CDN paired with caching improves the efficiency of the CDN as a whole.\\n\\n**Wait, what is caching? üò†\\n**\\n\\nCaching is a simple process of storing some data so that when the same request is made, it is loaded faster.\\n\\n**WHAT? üòï\\n**\\n\\nImagine you own a cafe and you have a customer who comes every day and drinks the same coffee. After a point, you ready the basic ingredients for the coffee, sometimes even heat the milk before the customer comes, to serve him faster. This is caching.\\nIf you want to know more about CDNs read this blog, it is a really great resource!\\n\\n- Decoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\\n\\nThe data packets are received at the user‚Äôs device. Now it‚Äôs time read them and start the original video. Here decoding comes into play. Remember we wrote a letter in the second step, now it‚Äôs time to open it and read what it says.\\nOnce you are done decoding, you just play the video from step one and viola! You now know how live streaming works.\\n\\nYou might be thinking, **THIS IS AMAZING!**\\n\\nWhat are the issues you were talking about?\\n\\nWell, let me list it down for you,\\n\\n1. CDNs are extremely expensive as they are sometimes working to optimize for millions of concurrent viewers.\\n2. The distance between the nearest server connected to CDN and your device may be large, thus delaying your live stream by a significant margin.\\n3. If the live streamer and the audience are in close vicinity, and the server is far away, there would be a delay in the stream as data packets would be traveling a long distance.\\n4. These are **centralized** options, so there would be a concern for privacy.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs move to the juicy part of the blog, so what is the web3 alternative for this?\\n\\n**It‚Äôs Livepeer üòâ\\n**\\n\\n## Livepeer- What‚Äôs that? üì∂\\n\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117581649/wwsyG6drr.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLivepeer is a web3 alternative for streaming services. It is a decentralized protocol that enables people to include Livestream in their applications. Here the catch is, the processing of encoding and decoding is outsourced to miners.\\nMiners can charge different competitive rates for the use of their hardware. You have a choice to choose from. In their own words,\\n\\n\u003e ‚ÄúLivepeer is a protocol for developers who want to add a live or on-demand video to their project. It aims to increase the reliability of video streaming while reducing costs associated with it by up to 50x‚Äù\\n\\nLivepeer is a protocol that enables all people to be a part of the protocol as it benefits engineers, broadcasters, users, and miners altogether. They also have Tokenomics that help delegators to be a part of their Protocol.\\n\\n## How does Huddle01 work with Livepeer? ü§ù\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117614706/Z9PJD8dVD.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAs Huddle01 is bringing innovation in communication via the internet, it is obvious that we are also upgrading the existing infrastructure with new features like live streaming. We support streaming with Livepeer, Youtube, and Twitch. Thus, it is easier for creators and users to instantly start a live stream for creators across platforms.\\n\\nBonus! We got featured in the Livepeer Studios blog, you can find it here.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! Let that settle in.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e80% of the stuff on the Internet is video! üì∫\\nIf we imagine the internet as the World, and the total water mass as video content, then the earth won‚Äôt have its largest continent! üåè\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBefore getting into streaming, let‚Äôs clarify what I mean by live streaming ‚ÅâÔ∏è\\nLive streaming is being on either side of a live broadcast, which means, something is seen as it happens with minimum delay over the internet ‚ö°\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe best example is, any major sports tournament viewed on the app, creators live-streaming a game and an audience experiencing in real-time (with a minimum delay of course)\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-different-centralized-streaming-infrastructure\\\"\u003eDifferent centralized streaming infrastructure.\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117257877/0Xl4JS3d5.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOne of the biggest contributors to this is live-streaming services like Twitch, Youtube, and many more applications that enable people to have that real-time experience while they watch something. Statistically, the retention of a live viewer is 20% more than a pre-recorded video or a movie.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are an array of services that enable different people with different needs to live stream stuff. Depending on your need, you can either\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIntegrate the service into your application\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eUse the service as a creator\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eUse the service as a telecasting service\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDepending on your need, you get different services that provide a seamless experience. But you might be thinking,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is your point here? üí¢\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe thing is, it is an amazing service but it is problematic in its working, and is often expensive as you scale and try it make yourself.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-does-it-work\\\"\u003eHow does it work? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117331613/M22tMTXBI.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLive streaming is an amazing feat of engineering that requires a set of different innovations that work together to provide a user with a live experience with minimum delay. It can be divided into 4 basic steps as\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo capture üìπ\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo encoding and segmentation üè™\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDecoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some words that are difficult to understand, but stay with me as I‚Äôll try to explain this in non-tech terms as much as possible. With that, let‚Äôs understand each of the steps,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo capture üìπ\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the name suggests, the video is captured from a source. Be it a camera, a game, or a video you are reacting on. This is pretty basic and the video captured is then forwarded to video encoding.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVideo encoding and segmentation üè™\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs first understand the meaning of the words ‚ÄòEncoding‚Äô and ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô as they seem like complex things. Encoding means converting a type of information into another type of information so that it is easier to read.\\nIf you want to communicate via text or a letter, you write it down, in a way changing the type of information so that it is easier for the other person to understand it.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eMoving onto ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô, this means Dividing a large chunk of information into smaller chunks so that you can move it faster and more efficiently.\\nImagine Segmentation as a process where you dismantle a chair so that you can fit it in a box and reassemble it once you reach your destination.\\nThe above two things are performed on the raw audio video file from the first step.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe first two steps are easy. The main innovation is here. The CDN is responsible for optimizing the delivery of the small data packets to every viewer who wants to watch the stream.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is a data packet ‚ùì\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our case, a data packet is a small encoded video, which was segmented for better transportation.\\nComing back to our CDN, it is a powerful server, that not only optimizes what data packets go to which device, so that the device gets real-time video, but along with maintaining the integrity of the initial data packets.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eCDN is like a super merch store that gives out everyone the same merch, but in different sizes for different people. So, if you are a huge guy with lots of muscle (in our case, a great bandwidth internet) you‚Äôll get your XL size at the same time as our intern, who is a cat with no muscles (in this case, a user with less internet bandwidth), CDN paired with caching improves the efficiency of the CDN as a whole.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWait, what is caching? üò†\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eCaching is a simple process of storing some data so that when the same request is made, it is loaded faster.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWHAT? üòï\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eImagine you own a cafe and you have a customer who comes every day and drinks the same coffee. After a point, you ready the basic ingredients for the coffee, sometimes even heat the milk before the customer comes, to serve him faster. This is caching.\\nIf you want to know more about CDNs read this blog, it is a really great resource!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDecoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe data packets are received at the user‚Äôs device. Now it‚Äôs time read them and start the original video. Here decoding comes into play. Remember we wrote a letter in the second step, now it‚Äôs time to open it and read what it says.\\nOnce you are done decoding, you just play the video from step one and viola! You now know how live streaming works.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou might be thinking, \u003cstrong\u003eTHIS IS AMAZING!\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhat are the issues you were talking about?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWell, let me list it down for you,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCDNs are extremely expensive as they are sometimes working to optimize for millions of concurrent viewers.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThe distance between the nearest server connected to CDN and your device may be large, thus delaying your live stream by a significant margin.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIf the live streamer and the audience are in close vicinity, and the server is far away, there would be a delay in the stream as data packets would be traveling a long distance.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eThese are \u003cstrong\u003ecentralized\u003c/strong\u003e options, so there would be a concern for privacy.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs move to the juicy part of the blog, so what is the web3 alternative for this?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt‚Äôs Livepeer üòâ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-livepeer-whats-that\\\"\u003eLivepeer- What‚Äôs that? üì∂\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117581649/wwsyG6drr.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLivepeer is a web3 alternative for streaming services. It is a decentralized protocol that enables people to include Livestream in their applications. Here the catch is, the processing of encoding and decoding is outsourced to miners.\\nMiners can charge different competitive rates for the use of their hardware. You have a choice to choose from. In their own words,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e‚ÄúLivepeer is a protocol for developers who want to add a live or on-demand video to their project. It aims to increase the reliability of video streaming while reducing costs associated with it by up to 50x‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLivepeer is a protocol that enables all people to be a part of the protocol as it benefits engineers, broadcasters, users, and miners altogether. They also have Tokenomics that help delegators to be a part of their Protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-does-huddle01-work-with-livepeer\\\"\u003eHow does Huddle01 work with Livepeer? ü§ù\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117614706/Z9PJD8dVD.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs Huddle01 is bringing innovation in communication via the internet, it is obvious that we are also upgrading the existing infrastructure with new features like live streaming. We support streaming with Livepeer, Youtube, and Twitch. Thus, it is easier for creators and users to instantly start a live stream for creators across platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBonus! We got featured in the Livepeer Studios blog, you can find it here.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e! See you at the next one üëã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117168287/X_qXGUx1a.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThe pandemic made us sit at home, stuck to movies, series, and in most cases, following a creator who live-streams a game or a reaction to an amazing piece of content.\\nThis actually changed the distribution of how much internet is actually in video format and it makes up about 80% of the Internet. Let that settle in.\\n\\n\u003e 80% of the stuff on the Internet is video! üì∫\\n\u003e If we imagine the internet as the World, and the total water mass as video content, then the earth won‚Äôt have its largest continent! üåè\\n\\nBefore getting into streaming, let‚Äôs clarify what I mean by live streaming ‚ÅâÔ∏è\\nLive streaming is being on either side of a live broadcast, which means, something is seen as it happens with minimum delay over the internet ‚ö°\\n\\nThe best example is, any major sports tournament viewed on the app, creators live-streaming a game and an audience experiencing in real-time (with a minimum delay of course)\\n\\n## Different centralized streaming infrastructure.\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117257877/0Xl4JS3d5.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nOne of the biggest contributors to this is live-streaming services like Twitch, Youtube, and many more applications that enable people to have that real-time experience while they watch something. Statistically, the retention of a live viewer is 20% more than a pre-recorded video or a movie.\\n\\nThere are an array of services that enable different people with different needs to live stream stuff. Depending on your need, you can either\\n\\n- Integrate the service into your application\\n- Use the service as a creator\\n- Use the service as a telecasting service\\n\\nDepending on your need, you get different services that provide a seamless experience. But you might be thinking,\\n\\n**What is your point here? üí¢\\n**\\n\\nThe thing is, it is an amazing service but it is problematic in its working, and is often expensive as you scale and try it make yourself.\\n\\n## How does it work? ü§î\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117331613/M22tMTXBI.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLive streaming is an amazing feat of engineering that requires a set of different innovations that work together to provide a user with a live experience with minimum delay. It can be divided into 4 basic steps as\\n\\n1. Video capture üìπ\\n2. Video encoding and segmentation üè™\\n3. CDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\\n4. Decoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\\n\\nHere are some words that are difficult to understand, but stay with me as I‚Äôll try to explain this in non-tech terms as much as possible. With that, let‚Äôs understand each of the steps,\\n\\n- Video capture üìπ\\n\\nAs the name suggests, the video is captured from a source. Be it a camera, a game, or a video you are reacting on. This is pretty basic and the video captured is then forwarded to video encoding.\\n\\n- Video encoding and segmentation üè™\\n\\nLet‚Äôs first understand the meaning of the words ‚ÄòEncoding‚Äô and ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô as they seem like complex things. Encoding means converting a type of information into another type of information so that it is easier to read.\\nIf you want to communicate via text or a letter, you write it down, in a way changing the type of information so that it is easier for the other person to understand it.\\n\\nMoving onto ‚ÄòSegmentation‚Äô, this means Dividing a large chunk of information into smaller chunks so that you can move it faster and more efficiently.\\nImagine Segmentation as a process where you dismantle a chair so that you can fit it in a box and reassemble it once you reach your destination.\\nThe above two things are performed on the raw audio video file from the first step.\\n\\n- CDN (Content Distribution Network) and caching üèóÔ∏è\\n\\nThe first two steps are easy. The main innovation is here. The CDN is responsible for optimizing the delivery of the small data packets to every viewer who wants to watch the stream.\\n\\n**What is a data packet ‚ùì\\n**\\n\\nIn our case, a data packet is a small encoded video, which was segmented for better transportation.\\nComing back to our CDN, it is a powerful server, that not only optimizes what data packets go to which device, so that the device gets real-time video, but along with maintaining the integrity of the initial data packets.\\n\\nCDN is like a super merch store that gives out everyone the same merch, but in different sizes for different people. So, if you are a huge guy with lots of muscle (in our case, a great bandwidth internet) you‚Äôll get your XL size at the same time as our intern, who is a cat with no muscles (in this case, a user with less internet bandwidth), CDN paired with caching improves the efficiency of the CDN as a whole.\\n\\n**Wait, what is caching? üò†\\n**\\n\\nCaching is a simple process of storing some data so that when the same request is made, it is loaded faster.\\n\\n**WHAT? üòï\\n**\\n\\nImagine you own a cafe and you have a customer who comes every day and drinks the same coffee. After a point, you ready the basic ingredients for the coffee, sometimes even heat the milk before the customer comes, to serve him faster. This is caching.\\nIf you want to know more about CDNs read this blog, it is a really great resource!\\n\\n- Decoding and Playback ‚ñ∂Ô∏è\\n\\nThe data packets are received at the user‚Äôs device. Now it‚Äôs time read them and start the original video. Here decoding comes into play. Remember we wrote a letter in the second step, now it‚Äôs time to open it and read what it says.\\nOnce you are done decoding, you just play the video from step one and viola! You now know how live streaming works.\\n\\nYou might be thinking, **THIS IS AMAZING!**\\n\\nWhat are the issues you were talking about?\\n\\nWell, let me list it down for you,\\n\\n1. CDNs are extremely expensive as they are sometimes working to optimize for millions of concurrent viewers.\\n2. The distance between the nearest server connected to CDN and your device may be large, thus delaying your live stream by a significant margin.\\n3. If the live streamer and the audience are in close vicinity, and the server is far away, there would be a delay in the stream as data packets would be traveling a long distance.\\n4. These are **centralized** options, so there would be a concern for privacy.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs move to the juicy part of the blog, so what is the web3 alternative for this?\\n\\n**It‚Äôs Livepeer üòâ\\n**\\n\\n## Livepeer- What‚Äôs that? üì∂\\n\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117581649/wwsyG6drr.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLivepeer is a web3 alternative for streaming services. It is a decentralized protocol that enables people to include Livestream in their applications. Here the catch is, the processing of encoding and decoding is outsourced to miners.\\nMiners can charge different competitive rates for the use of their hardware. You have a choice to choose from. In their own words,\\n\\n\u003e ‚ÄúLivepeer is a protocol for developers who want to add a live or on-demand video to their project. It aims to increase the reliability of video streaming while reducing costs associated with it by up to 50x‚Äù\\n\\nLivepeer is a protocol that enables all people to be a part of the protocol as it benefits engineers, broadcasters, users, and miners altogether. They also have Tokenomics that help delegators to be a part of their Protocol.\\n\\n## How does Huddle01 work with Livepeer? ü§ù\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666117614706/Z9PJD8dVD.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAs Huddle01 is bringing innovation in communication via the internet, it is obvious that we are also upgrading the existing infrastructure with new features like live streaming. We support streaming with Livepeer, Youtube, and Twitch. Thus, it is easier for creators and users to instantly start a live stream for creators across platforms.\\n\\nBonus! We got featured in the Livepeer Studios blog, you can find it here.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it from our side! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! *)){margin-top:2.8em;margin-bottom:2.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h2 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] :where(table):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){font-size:0.9em;line-height:1.5555556;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td, tfoot td):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-top:0.8888889em;padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:first-child, tfoot td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}The communication toolkit for web3, Huddle01 enables open & seamless cross-chain a/v calls and messaging for wallets, dApps, DAOs, NFT Communities and users. The toolkit includes a feature-rich sufficiently decentralised meeting platform, plug-n-play video conferencing SDK for dApps and dRTC protocol to power the future of real-time communication.
One of the exciting features that our Video Conferencing Platform includes is the ability for organisations, DAOs and NFT Communities to host token-gated meetings. This gives you the ability to conduct invite-only virtual events/calls on the Huddle01 Platform for your web3 fam.
Now let‚Äôs deep dive into the details of how you can token-gate your meetings using POAPs, NFTs, Tokens and Lens ‚§µÔ∏è
üîê First, what is a token-gated meeting?
Let's understand what ‚Äòtoken-gated meetings‚Äô are by first deconstructing the word:

Token-gated: A mechanism where an event is accessed by only tokens. Here, ‚Äòtoken‚Äô means tokens in your crypto wallet.

Meetings: A video conference between users.


Token-gated meetings solve a crucial problem in organisations, guilds, and communities that want to connect and collaborate virtually with complete privacy.
‚öíÔ∏è How does token-gating work?
Token-gated meetings are an upgraded version of the usual meetings when it comes to utility. In terms of how things work in the backend, it is similar to how any authentication tool works.
The differentiating factor here is that verification is less painful on the user side as compared to web2 meetings. Also, the host doesn‚Äôt need to privately share links and go through a complicated procedure to just set up one call.
Now let‚Äôs first understand the problems with the web2 workflow to know the current landscape and why we need token-gated meetings.
üö® Issues with current infrastructure
Fundamentally both web2 and web3 work in a similar fashion to authenticate identities, but the variables used are different, and that is a key differentiator. Let‚Äôs dive into what the exact issues are in the web2 space:

Credentials for verification: Web2 uses different credentials for verification. That usually involves setting up an email. That email has a verification method once it is set up. You need to set up passwords for the video conferencing service that is going to be used, and so on. This also creates an issue where you have to remember many passwords, and then your mailbox looks like a mess. Token-gated meetings just need their wallet to be connected to verify the existence of the existing tokens. If you have them, then you can enter; or else not. No need to create accounts on third-party services and plague your inbox with spam mail.

Setting up meetings: It is tough to set up exclusive meetings. You either collect everyone‚Äôs email addresses to create a meeting in everyone‚Äôs calendar, or you can use tools like Luma that ease the last part, but it‚Äôs hectic. For token-gated meetings, you just need to let users mint a specific token as they become a part of your exclusive organization. That token becomes an identifier for your attendees during meetings.

Hard to track exclusive events: Your inboxes are always full of invites, and your calendar always has some pending approval to set up a meeting. It also becomes difficult to hunt for specific links in email for those meetings. With tokens, everything is abstracted! Just share the link on public channels. Only the folks with a token can enter, so no worries about maintaining secrecy around links.

Difficulty in repeating events: Once you set up an exclusive event, there is always a threat that if someone external gets the link, the exclusivity of the event is instantly lost. You‚Äôll need to repeat to schedule a new meeting with a new link.

Difficult to maintain anonymity: The current infrastructure needs you to reveal your identity in some or the other way. With so many layers of verification and authentication involved, it is really hard to maintain an anonymous identity. At Token-gated events, you can be either completely anonymous or pseudo-anonymous as only your wallet and token are required for the verification.


‚úÖ Advantages of Token-gated meetings
Token-gated meetings are helpful in a lot of specific use cases. Let's see how:

Influencer events: Influencers can add layer of connection with their fans. People who want to get in touch with a lot of folks but want to filter out the crowd in tiers to give them access to specific content based on the token they hold.

Easy setup: Unlike the tiresome web2 setup, web3 token-gated meetings take just 2 quick steps to be scheduled. You first have to set up a process to mint certain tokens for the call, or you can use already existing ones to filter out the attendees. The second step is to just schedule a meeting and share the link on public channels. And it‚Äôs done! You‚Äôve successfully hosted your first-token gated meeting.

Reusability: The links for exclusive meetings can be reused for recurring events. The same tokens and links can be used to host regular community calls.

Organisation-friendly: The good part about token-gated meetings is that they work with all kinds of organizations. People in hierarchal organizations can be given links to different token mints so that they get access to different tiers of meetings, which provides every user with variable access to the organization. Just a basic subdomain and landing pages would do the trick instead of setting up the entire organization on Microsoft Teams or Google Suite or any other tool.


ü™ô Huddle01 and Token gating

If you are wondering if Token gated meetings are awesome, we have good news for you - you can now host Token-gated calls for your organisation or community using the Huddle01 platform. Here are the tokens we currently support:

POAPs: We support token-gating using POAPs (Proof of Attention Protocol) tokens, ensuring that only users who have the required tokens can access the calls.

Token:
 a. Ethereum: We support ERC20 and ERC721 tokens for token-gating an event on the Ethereum chain.
 b. Polygon: Similarly, we yet again support ERC20 and ERC721 for token-gating on the Polygon chain.

NFTs: You can token-gate Huddle01 meeting for your community with NFTs live on Ethereum and Polygon


Looking at the impressive growth of the Lens Community in the previous year, we‚Äôve also introduced Lens Social Graph support on the platform, you can now token-gate your meetings and soon live streaming, using Lens Handle üåø and attributes like:

Followed a particular profile

Collected a particular post

Mirrored a particular post


We are also working on adding more chains so that you can invite diverse attendees to your meetings or calls.
That's a wrap! ‚ú®
Now that you know how easy it is to host token-gated meetings, go ahead and schedule one for your community. In case you have some doubts or need help setting that up, feel free to reach out to us on Discord or Twitter, and keep up with everything at Huddle01 üé•
Try out Huddle01 for a quick meeting üé•

(min-width: 640px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:640px;}}@media (min-width: 768px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:768px;}}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1024px;}}@media (min-width:               var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }
