we fixed Huddle01‚Äôs Re-rendering issues\",\"cuid\":\"cl9ekd418000409l77a7u40k9\",\"dateAdded\":\"2022-10-18T18:53:37.581Z\",\"hasCustomDate\":null,\"isCoverAttributionHidden\":false,\"coverImageAttribution\":\"\",\"coverImagePhotographer\":\"\",\"slug\":\"how-we-fixed-huddle01s-re-rendering-issues\",\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"fb178f62-7474-407f-bb76-8374350168d9\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-re-rendering\",\"title\":\"What is re-rendering ‚öô\"}],[{\"id\":\"6fbe7bc8-b40f-4755-8824-24bdf4eeac04\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-were-the-issues\",\"title\":\"What were the issues ‚ùì\"}],[{\"id\":\"91d91d31-1874-415b-9579-4ed4ecbf20f9\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"how-did-we-fix-it\",\"title\":\"How did we fix it üõ†\"}],[{\"id\":\"1ac400fd-3032-44a6-a659-9aa116acae7e\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"takeaways-for-you\",\"title\":\"Takeaways for you!\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118717150/N9wgoemc4.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e~ Stephen Hawkings\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that are processing and data efficient. With this in mind, we at Huddle01 are constantly working to improve our video conferencing application while developing the deRTC Protocol.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe ran into a re-rendering issue while optimizing our Huddle01 video conferencing platform. This allowed us to deal with the problem of re-rendering with new solutions more efficiently.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBefore diving into what re-rendering is, let‚Äôs talk about,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is rendering ü§î\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou may have heard of rendering from a friend who edits videos or creates crazy 3D art. Rendering has always been thought of as ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù or a better synonym for ‚Äúloading.‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDepending on the context, the word ‚Äúrendering‚Äù can have several different meanings.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eIf you are a video editor or a 3D artist, it refers to the process of generating images or a modal with computers.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eDepending on the context, it can mean to cause something to happen or to help someone.\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our case of web development, it means gathering different data and either processing or directly sending the output to the screen. Simply put, when you click on a website link, it renders as soon as you are directed to it.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-re-rendering\\\"\u003eWhat is re-rendering ‚öô\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118783606/Kv5cbcgCV.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe know that when a component loads on the screen for the first time, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúrendering.‚Äù Similarly, whenever it‚Äôs loaded again, it‚Äôs called re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy does re-rendering happen üëÄ\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhen new information is added to the page, it needs to re-render some parts with further information. For example, when you press various buttons on the website, i.e., interact with it, there are some changes in it. When you press like on a tweet, the number count changes. The specific component which is displaying the like count gets updated.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eGood application architecture refers to minimal re-renders as a part of the design. But re-renders are necessary as many applications have to be interactive.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two types of re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNecessary re-render:\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the name implies, it refers to re-renders that are absolutely necessary. It also means that the re-rendered components are specific, with no effect on a larger scale than that. For example, when you toggle your microphone on and off in the Huddle01 app.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUnnecessary re-rendering:\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs previously discussed, re-rendering is required for an interactive application. However, when unnecessary re-rendering occurs, not only does the specific component re-render, but all other elements that were not involved are also re-rendered. For example, when a keystroke causes the entire page to be re-rendered.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith this background, let‚Äôs see some of the re-rendering issues we faced and how we solved them!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-were-the-issues\\\"\u003eWhat were the issues ‚ùì\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118863431/gsUxcKwsy.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhenever there is a UI update on the screen, a re-render is caused in order to update it for the user. Whenever a button is clicked, a re-render is caused to update the UI. The re-renders are denoted by the green border around the component which is being updated.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn our previous iteration of the meeting product (as shown below), there were a lot of re-renders on the UI, which triggered multiple side effects, causing memory leaks. The major reasons for this were:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhenever a peer (or attendee) entered the meeting room, they got added to the list of peers (array of peers) which triggered a re-render to update the grid of peers to show them on the screen.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhenever a speaker gets active, they get prioritized in the grid and the grid is supposed to be reshuffled which caused even more re-renders.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe used redux in the application and destructured properties from the state object using them in the dependency arrays of useEffects.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThese re-renders over time made the app running in the browser slower and slower exponentially as the meeting progressed.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119002218/_x5j7JZ9e.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-how-did-we-fix-it\\\"\u003eHow did we fix it üõ†\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119022005/cbAznYDfT.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eTo fix these issues, we made some major changes to our front-end architecture :\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe memoized components using React.memo() wherever necessary, to prevent unnecessary re-rendering.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe provided unique keys to every peer viewport in the grid so that even if they shuffled in an array a re-render won‚Äôt be required to change their order. We also had to map the peer's array inside a separate child component to prevent re-renders.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe used a library called zustand instead of redux which is much easier to implement as well as has much more re-rendering optimization built-in.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eRather than destructuring the properties from the state object. We created new variables from the state selectors minimizing re-renders even more.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe minimized the use of useEffects for side effects and avoided putting variables in dependency arrays of useEffects.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-takeaways-for-you\\\"\u003eTakeaways for you!\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt may take some time, but if you try to optimize, you will eventually reach a solution that is both effective and intelligent. It took a significant amount of effort and time on our part to bring the app up to its current state of optimal performance. We stayed focused on our primary goal of improving the application and, over time, figured out ways to do so. This effort assisted aspiring developers in finding easy ways to optimize the re-rendering problem.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"Link\\\"\u003eText\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118717150/N9wgoemc4.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n\u003e We are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \\n\u003e \\n\u003e ~ Stephen Hawkings\\n\\nThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that are processing and data efficient. With this in mind, we at Huddle01 are constantly working to improve our video conferencing application while developing the deRTC Protocol.\\n\\nWe ran into a re-rendering issue while optimizing our Huddle01 video conferencing platform. This allowed us to deal with the problem of re-rendering with new solutions more efficiently.\\n\\nBefore diving into what re-rendering is, let‚Äôs talk about,\\n\\n**What is rendering ü§î\\n**\\n\\nYou may have heard of rendering from a friend who edits videos or creates crazy 3D art. Rendering has always been thought of as ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù or a better synonym for ‚Äúloading.‚Äù\\n\\nDepending on the context, the word ‚Äúrendering‚Äù can have several different meanings.\\n\\n- If you are a video editor or a 3D artist, it refers to the process of generating images or a modal with computers.\\n- Depending on the context, it can mean to cause something to happen or to help someone.\\n\\nIn our case of web development, it means gathering different data and either processing or directly sending the output to the screen. Simply put, when you click on a website link, it renders as soon as you are directed to it.\\n\\n## What is re-rendering ‚öô\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118783606/Kv5cbcgCV.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe know that when a component loads on the screen for the first time, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúrendering.‚Äù Similarly, whenever it‚Äôs loaded again, it‚Äôs called re-rendering.\\n\\n**Why does re-rendering happen üëÄ\\n**\\n\\nWhen new information is added to the page, it needs to re-render some parts with further information. For example, when you press various buttons on the website, i.e., interact with it, there are some changes in it. When you press like on a tweet, the number count changes. The specific component which is displaying the like count gets updated.\\n\\nGood application architecture refers to minimal re-renders as a part of the design. But re-renders are necessary as many applications have to be interactive.\\n\\nThere are two types of re-rendering.\\n\\n**Necessary re-render:\\n**\\n\\nAs the name implies, it refers to re-renders that are absolutely necessary. It also means that the re-rendered components are specific, with no effect on a larger scale than that. For example, when you toggle your microphone on and off in the Huddle01 app.\\n\\n**Unnecessary re-rendering:\\n**\\n\\nAs previously discussed, re-rendering is required for an interactive application. However, when unnecessary re-rendering occurs, not only does the specific component re-render, but all other elements that were not involved are also re-rendered. For example, when a keystroke causes the entire page to be re-rendered.\\n\\nWith this background, let‚Äôs see some of the re-rendering issues we faced and how we solved them!\\n\\n## What were the issues ‚ùì\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666118863431/gsUxcKwsy.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWhenever there is a UI update on the screen, a re-render is caused in order to update it for the user. Whenever a button is clicked, a re-render is caused to update the UI. The re-renders are denoted by the green border around the component which is being updated.\\n\\nIn our previous iteration of the meeting product (as shown below), there were a lot of re-renders on the UI, which triggered multiple side effects, causing memory leaks. The major reasons for this were:\\n\\n1. Whenever a peer (or attendee) entered the meeting room, they got added to the list of peers (array of peers) which triggered a re-render to update the grid of peers to show them on the screen.\\n\\n2. Whenever a speaker gets active, they get prioritized in the grid and the grid is supposed to be reshuffled which caused even more re-renders.\\n\\n3. We used redux in the application and destructured properties from the state object using them in the dependency arrays of useEffects.\\n\\nThese re-renders over time made the app running in the browser slower and slower exponentially as the meeting progressed.\\n\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119002218/_x5j7JZ9e.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n## How did we fix it üõ†\\n\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666119022005/cbAznYDfT.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nTo fix these issues, we made some major changes to our front-end architecture :\\n\\n1. We memoized components using React.memo() wherever necessary, to prevent unnecessary re-rendering.\\n\\n2. We provided unique keys to every peer viewport in the grid so that even if they shuffled in an array a re-render won‚Äôt be required to change their order. We also had to map the peer's array inside a separate child component to prevent re-renders.\\n\\n3. We used a library called zustand instead of redux which is much easier to implement as well as has much more re-rendering optimization built-in.\\n\\n4. Rather than destructuring the properties from the state object. We created new variables from the state selectors minimizing re-renders even more.\\n\\n5. We minimized the use of useEffects for side effects and avoided putting variables in dependency arrays of useEffects.\\n\\n## Takeaways for you!\\nIt may take some time, but if you try to optimize, you will eventually reach a solution that is both effective and intelligent. It took a significant amount of effort and time on our part to bring the app up to its current state of optimal performance. We stayed focused on our primary goal of improving the application and, over time, figured out ways to do so. This effort assisted aspiring developers in finding easy ways to optimize the re-rendering problem.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs all we have to say from our end! If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind, reach out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\n) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)!\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n[Text](Link)\",\"brief\":\"We are all connected to the Internet as neurons are connected to a giant brain. \\n~ Stephen Hawkings\\n\\nThe internet is becoming a necessity for everyone. As a result, there is an increased demand for video conferencing and optimized applications that a...\",\"author\":{\"_id\":\"632f13813a049a0d9db75b4a\",\"socialMedia\":{\"twitter\":\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\",\"instagram\":\"https://www.instagram.com/huddle01com/?hl=en\",\"github\":\"https://github.com/Huddle01\",\"stackoverflow\":\"\",\"facebook\":\"\",\"website\":\"https://huddle01.com/\",\"linkedin\":\"https://www.linkedin.com/company/huddle-01/\",\"youtube\":\"https://www.youtube.com/@huddle0174\"},\"location\":\"\",\"isBanned\":false,\"isDeactivated\":false,\"numFollowers\":4,\"numFollowing\":0,\"storiesCreated\":[],\"totalUpvotesReceived\":0,\"tagManagerOf\":[],\"isEvangelist\":false,\"isAmbassador\":false,\"hasGoldRing\":false,\"name\":\"Huddle01\",\"username\":\"Huddle01com\",\"tagline\":\"The Communication Toolkit for web3. *)){margin-top:2.8em;margin-bottom:2.8em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(hr + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(h2 + *):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] :where(table):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){font-size:0.9em;line-height:1.5555556;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(thead th:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td, tfoot td):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-top:0.8888889em;padding-right:0.6666667em;padding-bottom:0.8888889em;padding-left:0.6666667em;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:first-child, tfoot td:first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-left:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(tbody td:last-child, tfoot td:last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){padding-right:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}Huddle01 is building the future of communication systems by aiming to decentralize the entire communication stack one step at a time. As Messaging eventually got decentralized by Dapps like XMTP, Waku, and Daakiya, it‚Äôs only natural the next step of innovation would be a Wallet-to-Wallet calling system. Before going ahead, here is a guide for you to directly navigate to which part exactly appeals to you!
Okay, let‚Äôs breakdown what we are going to discuss today,
What is a decentralized communication system? üåê
Why is it needed? üìû
AudioX, what‚Äôs that? üîä
AudioX seems great, how does it work? ü§î
Damn! What‚Äôs next? ü§Ø
What is a decentralized communication system? üåê

Any communication system that a centralized institution doesn‚Äôt operate is called a decentralized communication system. To give you an example, the current communication system works similarly to a village being fed by only one farmer. The farmer is the only source of food and his farm is as precious as gold. This gives the farmer immense power and can easily cut-off anyone‚Äôs food supply. 
A decentralized communication system enables everyone to have small farms rather than a single person having a huge farm. Here, both can co-exist, but the farmer has no power over you, also you get a variety to choose from!
Why is it needed? üìû

Okay, you might be wondering, but what if the Centralized organization, I don‚Äôt care if I have to buy from only one farmer as long as I get my food supply. I don‚Äôt care about other things. So let‚Äôs understand the real problems with the current system.
Let‚Äôs break them down into these issues:
1. Centralized control üè¶
It‚Äôs pretty clear that everything related to communications is controlled by a central structure, be it normal voice calling or platforms that provide support for VoIP (Voice Over Internet Protocol) usually control everything. It‚Äôs scary because your services can be cut off & accessed by a centralized entity at any point.
2. No anonymity üé≠
We all know how signups go for any platform that enables voice calling support, you can‚Äôt be anonymous even if you wanted. This creates a problem for the folks native to web3.
3. Single-dependant entity ü§ß
As the name suggests, it is easy to deduce that we are dependent on a single entity, what if something goes wrong and you can‚Äôt communicate properly? 
I know there are many fail-safes in place for servers, but as the saying goes, ‚ÄúNever put all your eggs in one basket‚Äù and with so many fail-safes present, we still know that even Meta has outages. This means we can always design a system with a better approach.
Okay, this sounds like a problem, how do we tackle it ‚ùì

We believe the future lies with decentralized communication, where all problems are addressed. We developed a DApp that actually works for this!
Introducing AudioX, a Wallet to Wallet calling DApp. AudioX is a peer-to-peer communication DApp that currently supports voice, messages, and file sharing over Ethereum addresses, ENS domains, and Lens profiles. You can even call it the web3 equivalent of WhatsApp.
This sounds interesting, how does it work? ü§î

We can understand the entire framework with an example. So, let‚Äôs say there are two people Tony and Steve who want to call each other via AudioX.
For this example, let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs Tony who is starting the call & dive deep into how things work at the backend. To have a call over Audio, both Tony and Steve have to set up a basic profile on AudioX for receiving calls by connecting their wallets that might consist of ENS or a Lens profile. Once set up is done, and both have enabled receiving calling option in the DApp, then comes the crispy part!
So Tony puts down Steve‚Äôs ENS in the search bar and initiates a call. We retrieve Steve‚Äôs wallet address and then this action sends an SDP (Session Description Protocol) message to the Signalling server.

Hold on, what is SDP? What is a Signalling Server? üí¨
The Signalling Server is an integral part of making connections between two clients. A Signalling Server is like a receptionist at a restaurant who checks if you have a reservation or not. Think of SDP as a formal request to the server to make a connection between two calling parties.
SDP consists of Steve‚Äôs wallet address which helps the server to find Steve & once Steve is found, the server then sends an SDP message to Steve about Tony calling. On Steve‚Äôs end, his action defines a new SDP message.

Okay wait a sec, what does Steve‚Äôs action mean? üò´
Steve can either answer the call, ignore or decline the call. This action then creates a new SDP message from Steve‚Äôs end which then goes to the Signalling server.

As Steve and Tony are besties, he obviously answers the call ü§ó

Now, once Steve‚Äôs SDP response reaches the Signalling server, the server opens an RTC connection between Tony and Steve. To put it simply, an RTC connection basically means Steve and Tony are now connected in real time for a voice call via the Internet ü§ù
In terms of security and anonymity, we can say:
Security üîí: Wallets and Lens profiles are non-custodial and no one can actually access them without you. Also, your chats are secured with end-to-end encryption.

Anonymity üé≠ : You are only limited by the number of wallets you can create for anonymity.
Not only this, we won an array of prizes for AudioX in EthOnline, the largest hackathon by EthGlobal, you can get to know more about this here.
Well, that‚Äôs amazing, what‚Äôs next? ü§Ø

Well, the problem is we still have to use a centralized server to make the connection between two addresses, but we plan to create a system where this issue can be addressed. We see a bunch of applications here, that can be:
Integration with DApps üõ†
AudioX SDK can be implemented in other DApps that are currently focusing on innovating the social graphs of decentralized tools of communication.
Future of Twitter spaces üîä
AudioX can also be used as an alternative to Twitter space with a web3 touch of anonymity!
A new social platform üé§
With a proper on-chain discoverability algorithm in place, this can be used as a base to find new web3 degens without actually losing anonymity!
These are just some use cases we could think of! If you have any questions/suggestions or team up in mind, reach us out on Twitteror land on our discord! ‚úå

              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

As Messaging eventually got decentralized by Dapps like XMTP, Waku, and Daakiya, it‚Äôs only natural the next step of innovation would be a Wallet-to-Wallet calling system. Before going ahead, here is a guide for you to directly navigate to which part exactly appeals to you!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, let‚Äôs breakdown what we are going to discuss today,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhat is a decentralized communication system? üåê\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhy is it needed? üìû\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX, what‚Äôs that? üîä\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX seems great, how does it work? ü§î\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDamn! What‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-a-decentralized-communication-system\\\"\u003eWhat is a decentralized communication system? üåê\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035311999/2DtNeU5yT.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAny communication system that a centralized institution doesn‚Äôt operate is called a decentralized communication system. To give you an example, the current communication system works similarly to a village being fed by only one farmer. The farmer is the only source of food and his farm is as precious as gold. This gives the farmer immense power and can easily cut-off anyone‚Äôs food supply. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eA decentralized communication system enables everyone to have small farms rather than a single person having a huge farm. Here, both can co-exist, but the farmer has no power over you, also you get a variety to choose from!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-why-is-it-needed\\\"\u003eWhy is it needed? üìû\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035376312/pJu5s6nji.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, you might be wondering, but what if the Centralized organization, I don‚Äôt care if I have to buy from only one farmer as long as I get my food supply. I don‚Äôt care about other things. So let‚Äôs understand the real problems with the current system.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs break them down into these issues:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1. Centralized control üè¶\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt‚Äôs pretty clear that everything related to communications is controlled by a central structure, be it normal voice calling or platforms that provide support for VoIP (Voice Over Internet Protocol) usually control everything. It‚Äôs scary because your services can be cut off \u0026amp; accessed by a centralized entity at any point.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. No anonymity üé≠\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe all know how signups go for any platform that enables voice calling support, you can‚Äôt be anonymous even if you wanted. This creates a problem for the folks native to web3.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e3. Single-dependant entity ü§ß\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the name suggests, it is easy to deduce that we are dependent on a single entity, what if something goes wrong and you can‚Äôt communicate properly? \\nI know there are many fail-safes in place for servers, but as the saying goes, ‚ÄúNever put all your eggs in one basket‚Äù and with so many fail-safes present, we still know that even Meta has outages. This means we can always design a system with a better approach.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-okay-this-sounds-like-a-problem-how-do-we-tackle-it\\\"\u003eOkay, this sounds like a problem, how do we tackle it ‚ùì\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035490287/gamASm7Pz.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe believe the future lies with decentralized communication, where all problems are addressed. We developed a DApp that actually works for this!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIntroducing AudioX, a Wallet to Wallet calling DApp. AudioX is a peer-to-peer communication DApp that currently supports voice, messages, and file sharing over Ethereum addresses, ENS domains, and Lens profiles. You can even call it the web3 equivalent of WhatsApp.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-this-sounds-interesting-how-does-it-work\\\"\u003eThis sounds interesting, how does it work? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035569873/PaYNj9dly.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe can understand the entire framework with an example. So, let‚Äôs say there are two people Tony and Steve who want to call each other via AudioX.\\nFor this example, let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs Tony who is starting the call \u0026amp; dive deep into how things work at the backend. To have a call over Audio, both Tony and Steve have to set up a basic profile on AudioX for receiving calls by connecting their wallets that might consist of ENS or a Lens profile. Once set up is done, and both have enabled receiving calling option in the DApp, then comes the crispy part!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSo Tony puts down Steve‚Äôs ENS in the search bar and initiates a call. We retrieve Steve‚Äôs wallet address and then this action sends an SDP (Session Description Protocol) message to the Signalling server.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035589597/UqPvHbZJF.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-hold-on-what-is-sdp-what-is-a-signalling-server\\\"\u003eHold on, what is SDP? What is a Signalling Server? üí¨\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe Signalling Server is an integral part of making connections between two clients. A Signalling Server is like a receptionist at a restaurant who checks if you have a reservation or not. Think of SDP as a formal request to the server to make a connection between two calling parties.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSDP consists of Steve‚Äôs wallet address which helps the server to find Steve \u0026amp; once Steve is found, the server then sends an SDP message to Steve about Tony calling. On Steve‚Äôs end, his action defines a new SDP message.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035731374/0mLl-b0MH.png\\\" alt=\\\"7.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-okay-wait-a-sec-what-does-steves-action-mean\\\"\u003eOkay wait a sec, what does Steve‚Äôs action mean? üò´\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSteve can either answer the call, ignore or decline the call. This action then creates a new SDP message from Steve‚Äôs end which then goes to the Signalling server.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035759008/u4ZUvnCM6.png\\\" alt=\\\"8.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs Steve and Tony are besties, he obviously answers the call ü§ó\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035770496/TVfCX_joq.png\\\" alt=\\\"9.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow, once Steve‚Äôs SDP response reaches the Signalling server, the server opens an RTC connection between Tony and Steve. To put it simply, an RTC connection basically means Steve and Tony are now connected in real time for a voice call via the Internet ü§ù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn terms of security and anonymity, we can say:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSecurity üîí\u003c/strong\u003e: Wallets and Lens profiles are non-custodial and no one can actually access them without you. Also, your chats are secured with end-to-end encryption.\\n\u003cstrong\u003e\\nAnonymity üé≠ \u003c/strong\u003e: You are only limited by the number of wallets you can create for anonymity.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNot only this, we won an array of prizes for AudioX in EthOnline, the largest hackathon by EthGlobal, you can get to know more about this here.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-well-thats-amazing-whats-next\\\"\u003eWell, that‚Äôs amazing, what‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035829769/qcjcakwgV.png\\\" alt=\\\"10.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWell, the problem is we still have to use a centralized server to make the connection between two addresses, but we plan to create a system where this issue can be addressed. We see a bunch of applications here, that can be:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIntegration with DApps üõ†\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX SDK can be implemented in other DApps that are currently focusing on innovating the social graphs of decentralized tools of communication.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFuture of Twitter spaces üîä\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX can also be used as an alternative to Twitter space with a web3 touch of anonymity!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA new social platform üé§\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith a proper on-chain discoverability algorithm in place, this can be used as a base to find new web3 degens without actually losing anonymity!\\nThese are just some use cases we could think of! If you have any questions/suggestions or team up in mind, reach us out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003eor land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e! ‚úå\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"Huddle01 is building the future of communication systems by aiming to decentralize the entire communication stack one step at a time. As Messaging eventually got decentralized by Dapps like XMTP, Waku, and Daakiya, it‚Äôs only natural the next step of innovation would be a Wallet-to-Wallet calling system. Before going ahead, here is a guide for you to directly navigate to which part exactly appeals to you!\\n\\nOkay, let‚Äôs breakdown what we are going to discuss today,\\n\\nWhat is a decentralized communication system? üåê\\n\\nWhy is it needed? üìû\\n\\nAudioX, what‚Äôs that? üîä\\n\\nAudioX seems great, how does it work? ü§î\\n\\nDamn! What‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\\n\\n## What is a decentralized communication system? üåê\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035311999/2DtNeU5yT.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAny communication system that a centralized institution doesn‚Äôt operate is called a decentralized communication system. To give you an example, the current communication system works similarly to a village being fed by only one farmer. The farmer is the only source of food and his farm is as precious as gold. This gives the farmer immense power and can easily cut-off anyone‚Äôs food supply. \\n\\nA decentralized communication system enables everyone to have small farms rather than a single person having a huge farm. Here, both can co-exist, but the farmer has no power over you, also you get a variety to choose from!\\n\\n## Why is it needed? üìû\\n\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035376312/pJu5s6nji.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nOkay, you might be wondering, but what if the Centralized organization, I don‚Äôt care if I have to buy from only one farmer as long as I get my food supply. I don‚Äôt care about other things. So let‚Äôs understand the real problems with the current system.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs break them down into these issues:\\n\\n\\n**1. Centralized control üè¶**\\n\\nIt‚Äôs pretty clear that everything related to communications is controlled by a central structure, be it normal voice calling or platforms that provide support for VoIP (Voice Over Internet Protocol) usually control everything. It‚Äôs scary because your services can be cut off \u0026 accessed by a centralized entity at any point.\\n\\n**2. No anonymity üé≠**\\n\\nWe all know how signups go for any platform that enables voice calling support, you can‚Äôt be anonymous even if you wanted. This creates a problem for the folks native to web3.\\n\\n**3. Single-dependant entity ü§ß**\\n\\nAs the name suggests, it is easy to deduce that we are dependent on a single entity, what if something goes wrong and you can‚Äôt communicate properly? \\nI know there are many fail-safes in place for servers, but as the saying goes, ‚ÄúNever put all your eggs in one basket‚Äù and with so many fail-safes present, we still know that even Meta has outages. This means we can always design a system with a better approach.\\n\\n## Okay, this sounds like a problem, how do we tackle it ‚ùì\\n\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035490287/gamASm7Pz.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe believe the future lies with decentralized communication, where all problems are addressed. We developed a DApp that actually works for this!\\n\\nIntroducing AudioX, a Wallet to Wallet calling DApp. AudioX is a peer-to-peer communication DApp that currently supports voice, messages, and file sharing over Ethereum addresses, ENS domains, and Lens profiles. You can even call it the web3 equivalent of WhatsApp.\\n\\n## This sounds interesting, how does it work? ü§î\\n\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035569873/PaYNj9dly.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe can understand the entire framework with an example. So, let‚Äôs say there are two people Tony and Steve who want to call each other via AudioX.\\nFor this example, let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs Tony who is starting the call \u0026 dive deep into how things work at the backend. To have a call over Audio, both Tony and Steve have to set up a basic profile on AudioX for receiving calls by connecting their wallets that might consist of ENS or a Lens profile. Once set up is done, and both have enabled receiving calling option in the DApp, then comes the crispy part!\\n\\nSo Tony puts down Steve‚Äôs ENS in the search bar and initiates a call. We retrieve Steve‚Äôs wallet address and then this action sends an SDP (Session Description Protocol) message to the Signalling server.\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035589597/UqPvHbZJF.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n### Hold on, what is SDP? What is a Signalling Server? üí¨\\n\\nThe Signalling Server is an integral part of making connections between two clients. A Signalling Server is like a receptionist at a restaurant who checks if you have a reservation or not. Think of SDP as a formal request to the server to make a connection between two calling parties.\\n\\nSDP consists of Steve‚Äôs wallet address which helps the server to find Steve \u0026 once Steve is found, the server then sends an SDP message to Steve about Tony calling. On Steve‚Äôs end, his action defines a new SDP message.\\n\\n![7.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035731374/0mLl-b0MH.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n### Okay wait a sec, what does Steve‚Äôs action mean? üò´\\n\\nSteve can either answer the call, ignore or decline the call. This action then creates a new SDP message from Steve‚Äôs end which then goes to the Signalling server.\\n\\n![8.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035759008/u4ZUvnCM6.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAs Steve and Tony are besties, he obviously answers the call ü§ó\\n\\n\\n![9.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035770496/TVfCX_joq.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nNow, once Steve‚Äôs SDP response reaches the Signalling server, the server opens an RTC connection between Tony and Steve. To put it simply, an RTC connection basically means Steve and Tony are now connected in real time for a voice call via the Internet ü§ù\\n\\nIn terms of security and anonymity, we can say:\\n\\n**Security üîí**: Wallets and Lens profiles are non-custodial and no one can actually access them without you. Also, your chats are secured with end-to-end encryption.\\n**\\nAnonymity üé≠ **: You are only limited by the number of wallets you can create for anonymity.\\n\\nNot only this, we won an array of prizes for AudioX in EthOnline, the largest hackathon by EthGlobal, you can get to know more about this here.\\n\\n## Well, that‚Äôs amazing, what‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\\n\\n![10.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035829769/qcjcakwgV.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWell, the problem is we still have to use a centralized server to make the connection between two addresses, but we plan to create a system where this issue can be addressed. We see a bunch of applications here, that can be:\\n\\n**Integration with DApps üõ†**\\n\\nAudioX SDK can be implemented in other DApps that are currently focusing on innovating the social graphs of decentralized tools of communication.\\n\\n**Future of Twitter spaces üîä**\\n\\nAudioX can also be used as an alternative to Twitter space with a web3 touch of anonymity!\\n\\n**A new social platform üé§**\\n\\nWith a proper on-chain discoverability algorithm in place, this can be used as a base to find new web3 degens without actually losing anonymity!\\nThese are just some use cases we could think of! If you have any questions/suggestions or team up in mind, reach us out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com)or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! ‚úå\\n\\n\",\"hasPolls\":false,\"totalPollVotes\":0,\"upvotes\":0,\"downvotes\":0,\"tags\":[],\"untaggedFrom\":[],\"popularity\":5668.2618,\"responseCount\":0,\"replyCount\":0,\"followers\":[],\"isActive\":true,\"isFeatured\":false,\"isEngaging\":false,\"answeredByTarget\":false,\"isDelisted\":false,\"isNotified\":false,\"duplicatePosts\":[],\"numCollapsed\":0,\"hasReward\":false,\"bookmarkedIn\":[],\"reactions\":[\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d35484\"],\"totalReactions\":1,\"reactionsByCurrentUser\":[],\"isPinnedToBlog\":false,\"disableComments\":false,\"commentsPaused\":false,\"hasLatex\":false,\"syncAlgolia\":true,\"enableToc\":true,\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"ae633566-a360-4c5d-9f21-52571edf4e2c\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-a-decentralized-communication-system\",\"title\":\"What is a decentralized communication system? üåê\"}],[{\"id\":\"41afbe3d-ab75-4842-b245-0f4bac34fd5b\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"why-is-it-needed\",\"title\":\"Why is it needed? üìû\"}],[{\"id\":\"b2bdfc59-4d13-4240-b0a0-d527ff2e74f3\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"okay-this-sounds-like-a-problem-how-do-we-tackle-it\",\"title\":\"Okay, this sounds like a problem, how do we tackle it ‚ùì\"}],[{\"id\":\"1f7ab321-7ec9-44c5-a857-40fb5e6c0bcf\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"this-sounds-interesting-how-does-it-work\",\"title\":\"This sounds interesting, how does it work? ü§î\"}],[{\"id\":\"f638b869-89c0-4636-8c19-19aff0f9043d\",\"level\":3,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":\"1f7ab321-7ec9-44c5-a857-40fb5e6c0bcf\",\"slug\":\"hold-on-what-is-sdp-what-is-a-signalling-server\",\"title\":\"Hold on, what is SDP? As Messaging eventually got decentralized by Dapps like XMTP, Waku, and Daakiya, it‚Äôs only natural the next step of ...\",\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is building the future of communication systems by aiming to decentralize the entire communication stack one step at a time. As Messaging eventually got decentralized by Dapps like XMTP, Waku, and Daakiya, it‚Äôs only natural the next step of innovation would be a Wallet-to-Wallet calling system. Before going ahead, here is a guide for you to directly navigate to which part exactly appeals to you!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, let‚Äôs breakdown what we are going to discuss today,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhat is a decentralized communication system? üåê\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhy is it needed? üìû\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX, what‚Äôs that? üîä\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX seems great, how does it work? ü§î\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDamn! What‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-a-decentralized-communication-system\\\"\u003eWhat is a decentralized communication system? üåê\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035311999/2DtNeU5yT.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAny communication system that a centralized institution doesn‚Äôt operate is called a decentralized communication system. To give you an example, the current communication system works similarly to a village being fed by only one farmer. The farmer is the only source of food and his farm is as precious as gold. This gives the farmer immense power and can easily cut-off anyone‚Äôs food supply. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eA decentralized communication system enables everyone to have small farms rather than a single person having a huge farm. Here, both can co-exist, but the farmer has no power over you, also you get a variety to choose from!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-why-is-it-needed\\\"\u003eWhy is it needed? üìû\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035376312/pJu5s6nji.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, you might be wondering, but what if the Centralized organization, I don‚Äôt care if I have to buy from only one farmer as long as I get my food supply. I don‚Äôt care about other things. So let‚Äôs understand the real problems with the current system.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs break them down into these issues:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1. Centralized control üè¶\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt‚Äôs pretty clear that everything related to communications is controlled by a central structure, be it normal voice calling or platforms that provide support for VoIP (Voice Over Internet Protocol) usually control everything. It‚Äôs scary because your services can be cut off \u0026amp; accessed by a centralized entity at any point.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. No anonymity üé≠\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe all know how signups go for any platform that enables voice calling support, you can‚Äôt be anonymous even if you wanted. This creates a problem for the folks native to web3.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e3. Single-dependant entity ü§ß\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the name suggests, it is easy to deduce that we are dependent on a single entity, what if something goes wrong and you can‚Äôt communicate properly? \\nI know there are many fail-safes in place for servers, but as the saying goes, ‚ÄúNever put all your eggs in one basket‚Äù and with so many fail-safes present, we still know that even Meta has outages. This means we can always design a system with a better approach.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-okay-this-sounds-like-a-problem-how-do-we-tackle-it\\\"\u003eOkay, this sounds like a problem, how do we tackle it ‚ùì\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035490287/gamASm7Pz.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe believe the future lies with decentralized communication, where all problems are addressed. We developed a DApp that actually works for this!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIntroducing AudioX, a Wallet to Wallet calling DApp. AudioX is a peer-to-peer communication DApp that currently supports voice, messages, and file sharing over Ethereum addresses, ENS domains, and Lens profiles. You can even call it the web3 equivalent of WhatsApp.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-this-sounds-interesting-how-does-it-work\\\"\u003eThis sounds interesting, how does it work? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035569873/PaYNj9dly.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe can understand the entire framework with an example. So, let‚Äôs say there are two people Tony and Steve who want to call each other via AudioX.\\nFor this example, let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs Tony who is starting the call \u0026amp; dive deep into how things work at the backend. To have a call over Audio, both Tony and Steve have to set up a basic profile on AudioX for receiving calls by connecting their wallets that might consist of ENS or a Lens profile. Once set up is done, and both have enabled receiving calling option in the DApp, then comes the crispy part!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSo Tony puts down Steve‚Äôs ENS in the search bar and initiates a call. We retrieve Steve‚Äôs wallet address and then this action sends an SDP (Session Description Protocol) message to the Signalling server.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035589597/UqPvHbZJF.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-hold-on-what-is-sdp-what-is-a-signalling-server\\\"\u003eHold on, what is SDP? What is a Signalling Server? üí¨\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe Signalling Server is an integral part of making connections between two clients. A Signalling Server is like a receptionist at a restaurant who checks if you have a reservation or not. Think of SDP as a formal request to the server to make a connection between two calling parties.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSDP consists of Steve‚Äôs wallet address which helps the server to find Steve \u0026amp; once Steve is found, the server then sends an SDP message to Steve about Tony calling. On Steve‚Äôs end, his action defines a new SDP message.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035731374/0mLl-b0MH.png\\\" alt=\\\"7.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch3 id=\\\"heading-okay-wait-a-sec-what-does-steves-action-mean\\\"\u003eOkay wait a sec, what does Steve‚Äôs action mean? üò´\u003c/h3\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSteve can either answer the call, ignore or decline the call. This action then creates a new SDP message from Steve‚Äôs end which then goes to the Signalling server.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035759008/u4ZUvnCM6.png\\\" alt=\\\"8.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs Steve and Tony are besties, he obviously answers the call ü§ó\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035770496/TVfCX_joq.png\\\" alt=\\\"9.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow, once Steve‚Äôs SDP response reaches the Signalling server, the server opens an RTC connection between Tony and Steve. To put it simply, an RTC connection basically means Steve and Tony are now connected in real time for a voice call via the Internet ü§ù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIn terms of security and anonymity, we can say:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSecurity üîí\u003c/strong\u003e: Wallets and Lens profiles are non-custodial and no one can actually access them without you. Also, your chats are secured with end-to-end encryption.\\n\u003cstrong\u003e\\nAnonymity üé≠ \u003c/strong\u003e: You are only limited by the number of wallets you can create for anonymity.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNot only this, we won an array of prizes for AudioX in EthOnline, the largest hackathon by EthGlobal, you can get to know more about this here.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-well-thats-amazing-whats-next\\\"\u003eWell, that‚Äôs amazing, what‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035829769/qcjcakwgV.png\\\" alt=\\\"10.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWell, the problem is we still have to use a centralized server to make the connection between two addresses, but we plan to create a system where this issue can be addressed. We see a bunch of applications here, that can be:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIntegration with DApps üõ†\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX SDK can be implemented in other DApps that are currently focusing on innovating the social graphs of decentralized tools of communication.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFuture of Twitter spaces üîä\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAudioX can also be used as an alternative to Twitter space with a web3 touch of anonymity!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA new social platform üé§\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith a proper on-chain discoverability algorithm in place, this can be used as a base to find new web3 degens without actually losing anonymity!\\nThese are just some use cases we could think of! If you have any questions/suggestions or team up in mind, reach us out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003eor land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e! ‚úå\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"Huddle01 is building the future of communication systems by aiming to decentralize the entire communication stack one step at a time. As Messaging eventually got decentralized by Dapps like XMTP, Waku, and Daakiya, it‚Äôs only natural the next step of innovation would be a Wallet-to-Wallet calling system. Before going ahead, here is a guide for you to directly navigate to which part exactly appeals to you!\\n\\nOkay, let‚Äôs breakdown what we are going to discuss today,\\n\\nWhat is a decentralized communication system? üåê\\n\\nWhy is it needed? üìû\\n\\nAudioX, what‚Äôs that? üîä\\n\\nAudioX seems great, how does it work? ü§î\\n\\nDamn! What‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\\n\\n## What is a decentralized communication system? üåê\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035311999/2DtNeU5yT.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAny communication system that a centralized institution doesn‚Äôt operate is called a decentralized communication system. To give you an example, the current communication system works similarly to a village being fed by only one farmer. The farmer is the only source of food and his farm is as precious as gold. This gives the farmer immense power and can easily cut-off anyone‚Äôs food supply. \\n\\nA decentralized communication system enables everyone to have small farms rather than a single person having a huge farm. Here, both can co-exist, but the farmer has no power over you, also you get a variety to choose from!\\n\\n## Why is it needed? üìû\\n\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035376312/pJu5s6nji.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nOkay, you might be wondering, but what if the Centralized organization, I don‚Äôt care if I have to buy from only one farmer as long as I get my food supply. I don‚Äôt care about other things. So let‚Äôs understand the real problems with the current system.\\n\\nLet‚Äôs break them down into these issues:\\n\\n\\n**1. Centralized control üè¶**\\n\\nIt‚Äôs pretty clear that everything related to communications is controlled by a central structure, be it normal voice calling or platforms that provide support for VoIP (Voice Over Internet Protocol) usually control everything. It‚Äôs scary because your services can be cut off \u0026 accessed by a centralized entity at any point.\\n\\n**2. No anonymity üé≠**\\n\\nWe all know how signups go for any platform that enables voice calling support, you can‚Äôt be anonymous even if you wanted. This creates a problem for the folks native to web3.\\n\\n**3. Single-dependant entity ü§ß**\\n\\nAs the name suggests, it is easy to deduce that we are dependent on a single entity, what if something goes wrong and you can‚Äôt communicate properly? \\nI know there are many fail-safes in place for servers, but as the saying goes, ‚ÄúNever put all your eggs in one basket‚Äù and with so many fail-safes present, we still know that even Meta has outages. This means we can always design a system with a better approach.\\n\\n## Okay, this sounds like a problem, how do we tackle it ‚ùì\\n\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035490287/gamASm7Pz.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe believe the future lies with decentralized communication, where all problems are addressed. We developed a DApp that actually works for this!\\n\\nIntroducing AudioX, a Wallet to Wallet calling DApp. AudioX is a peer-to-peer communication DApp that currently supports voice, messages, and file sharing over Ethereum addresses, ENS domains, and Lens profiles. You can even call it the web3 equivalent of WhatsApp.\\n\\n## This sounds interesting, how does it work? ü§î\\n\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035569873/PaYNj9dly.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe can understand the entire framework with an example. So, let‚Äôs say there are two people Tony and Steve who want to call each other via AudioX.\\nFor this example, let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs Tony who is starting the call \u0026 dive deep into how things work at the backend. To have a call over Audio, both Tony and Steve have to set up a basic profile on AudioX for receiving calls by connecting their wallets that might consist of ENS or a Lens profile. Once set up is done, and both have enabled receiving calling option in the DApp, then comes the crispy part!\\n\\nSo Tony puts down Steve‚Äôs ENS in the search bar and initiates a call. We retrieve Steve‚Äôs wallet address and then this action sends an SDP (Session Description Protocol) message to the Signalling server.\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035589597/UqPvHbZJF.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n### Hold on, what is SDP? What is a Signalling Server? üí¨\\n\\nThe Signalling Server is an integral part of making connections between two clients. A Signalling Server is like a receptionist at a restaurant who checks if you have a reservation or not. Think of SDP as a formal request to the server to make a connection between two calling parties.\\n\\nSDP consists of Steve‚Äôs wallet address which helps the server to find Steve \u0026 once Steve is found, the server then sends an SDP message to Steve about Tony calling. On Steve‚Äôs end, his action defines a new SDP message.\\n\\n![7.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035731374/0mLl-b0MH.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n### Okay wait a sec, what does Steve‚Äôs action mean? üò´\\n\\nSteve can either answer the call, ignore or decline the call. This action then creates a new SDP message from Steve‚Äôs end which then goes to the Signalling server.\\n\\n![8.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035759008/u4ZUvnCM6.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAs Steve and Tony are besties, he obviously answers the call ü§ó\\n\\n\\n![9.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035770496/TVfCX_joq.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nNow, once Steve‚Äôs SDP response reaches the Signalling server, the server opens an RTC connection between Tony and Steve. To put it simply, an RTC connection basically means Steve and Tony are now connected in real time for a voice call via the Internet ü§ù\\n\\nIn terms of security and anonymity, we can say:\\n\\n**Security üîí**: Wallets and Lens profiles are non-custodial and no one can actually access them without you. Also, your chats are secured with end-to-end encryption.\\n**\\nAnonymity üé≠ **: You are only limited by the number of wallets you can create for anonymity.\\n\\nNot only this, we won an array of prizes for AudioX in EthOnline, the largest hackathon by EthGlobal, you can get to know more about this here.\\n\\n## Well, that‚Äôs amazing, what‚Äôs next? ü§Ø\\n\\n![10.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664035829769/qcjcakwgV.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWell, the problem is we still have to use a centralized server to make the connection between two addresses, but we plan to create a system where this issue can be addressed. We see a bunch of applications here, that can be:\\n\\n**Integration with DApps üõ†**\\n\\nAudioX SDK can be implemented in other DApps that are currently focusing on innovating the social graphs of decentralized tools of communication.\\n\\n**Future of Twitter spaces üîä**\\n\\nAudioX can also be used as an alternative to Twitter space with a web3 touch of anonymity!\\n\\n**A new social platform üé§**\\n\\nWith a proper on-chain discoverability algorithm in place, this can be used as a base to find new web3 degens without actually losing anonymity!\\nThese are just some use cases we could think of! If you have any questions/suggestions or team up in mind, reach us out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com)or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)! ‚úå\\n\\n\",\"hasPolls\":false,\"totalPollVotes\":0,\"upvotes\":0,\"downvotes\":0,\"tags\":[],\"untaggedFrom\":[],\"popularity\":5668.2618,\"responseCount\":0,\"replyCount\":0,\"followers\":[],\"isActive\":true,\"isFeatured\":false,\"isEngaging\":false,\"answeredByTarget\":false,\"isDelisted\":false,\"isNotified\":false,\"duplicatePosts\":[],\"numCollapsed\":0,\"hasReward\":false,\"bookmarkedIn\":[],\"reactions\":[\"5c090d96c2a9c2a674d35484\"],\"totalReactions\":1,\"reactionsByCurrentUser\":[],\"isPinnedToBlog\":false,\"disableComments\":false,\"commentsPaused\":false,\"hasLatex\":false,\"syncAlgolia\":true,\"enableToc\":true,\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"ae633566-a360-4c5d-9f21-52571edf4e2c\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-a-decentralized-communication-system\",\"title\":\"What is a decentralized communication system? üåê\"}],[{\"id\":\"41afbe3d-ab75-4842-b245-0f4bac34fd5b\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"why-is-it-needed\",\"title\":\"Why is it needed? üìû\"}],[{\"id\":\"b2bdfc59-4d13-4240-b0a0-d527ff2e74f3\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"okay-this-sounds-like-a-problem-how-do-we-tackle-it\",\"title\":\"Okay, this sounds like a problem, how do we tackle it ‚ùì\"}],[{\"id\":\"1f7ab321-7ec9-44c5-a857-40fb5e6c0bcf\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"this-sounds-interesting-how-does-it-work\",\"title\":\"This sounds interesting, how does it work? ü§î\"}],[{\"id\":\"f638b869-89c0-4636-8c19-19aff0f9043d\",\"level\":3,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":\"1f7ab321-7ec9-44c5-a857-40fb5e6c0bcf\",\"slug\":\"hold-on-what-is-sdp-what-is-a-signalling-server\",\"title\":\"Hold on, what is SDP? :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}
Huddle01 is building the next generation of internet communication by aiming to improve the current tech stack by keeping the decentralizing approach in mind. Not only this, we plan to revolutionize the current internet communication landscape!
Coming to WebRTC, it was originally designed by Global IP Solutions (or GIPS), a company founded around 1999 in Sweden. Google acquired GIPS in 2011 and open-sourced the WebRTC technology. Since then, different browsers like Mozilla, Chrome, and Opera show great support for WebRTC.
What is webRTC? ü§î

Without wasting any time, let‚Äôs start with what webRTC is. WebRTC is an acronym for Web Real-Time Communication. According to Wikipedia, ‚ÄúWebRTC is a free and open-source project providing web browsers and mobile applications with real-time communication via application programming interfaces.‚Äù
Breaking it down in layman‚Äôs terms, WebRTC is an open-source program that enables Peer-to-Peer communication between two separate devices via the Internet. These can be mobiles, tablets, and PCs. It is helping projects integrate audio/video services into their Applications. Imagine webRTC as the hard work in making a pickle, once it is made, everyone who has it can use it in their recipes as they please.
WebRTC working ‚öôÔ∏è

WebRTC working is quite complicated, but to very simply break it down to you, we can say WebRTC has 4 steps in establishing a connection and these are followed strictly in the given order:
Signaling üì°

This is pretty intuitive for understanding how this works. You need to find someone to connect with, you‚Äôll send a signal to search and notify if the recipient is present. Think of it as ordering your favorite shoes from Amazon, first amazon check if they are available and if they are they send you the shoes!
Connecting ü§ù

The two WebRTC Agents now know enough details to attempt to connect to each other. WebRTC then uses another established technology called ICE (Interactive Connectivity Establishment).
Securing üîí

We have two sides that are connected and are communicating in real-time. As we don‚Äôt like anyone else to listen to our gossip with our best friends, these connections must be secured by a third-party attacker. This is done by DTLS (Datagram Transport Layer Protocol) and SRTP(Secure Real-time Transport Protocol) which predates WebRTC!
Communicating üó®Ô∏è

Now the connection is established and secured, the only thing is to share data in real-time. This is again done by pre-existing protocols like RTP and SCTP. I know this is a bit vague but think of it as you are playing cards with your friend, real-time data sharing essentially means you can see what cards your friend is playing without delays. Thus just connection establishment isn‚Äôt enough, real-time data sharing is the key alpha here!
Problems with WebRTC üò¢

WebRTC is truly a great piece of innovation, but as there are 2 sides to each coin, WebRTC also has some significant issues! WebRTC isn‚Äôt actually scalable!
Wait, what? WebRTC isn‚Äôt scalable? üò≤

Yup, WebRTC is great for peer-to-peer communication, but when it comes to more than 10 people trying to communicate in real time, the system can‚Äôt be used.
Why? üòû

WebRTC needs bidirectional connections to each client and as we increase the number of clients, the communication complexes maintaining so many connections are in place. Well, the problem is each node or client is connected with each of the other clients present, thus creating intensive and resource-heavy connections from one client.

Let me explain this with an example, It‚Äôs a fare! You are out with your friends and playing a game. The rules of the games are simple, anyone who is playing has to bring their own sweet and has to exchange it for the sweet of the other person. 
Let‚Äôs say there are 3 friends who have Oreo, Candy, and a lollipop. So, you‚Äôll have 2 of each to share and you‚Äôll receive one of the other sweets each. Let‚Äôs say you are the one with Oreo then the problem arises when,

You can only afford a certain number of Oreos to give away.

As, the number of players increases, each would bring in a new sweet, & after a point, you can‚Äôt receive any more sweets as your bag is already full.


Here, Oreos refer to uplink and all other sweets refer to downlinks for the client connections for you.
Solution for scaling üõ†

Selective Forwarding Unit (SFU)

The most popular solution for the scalability problem. SFU reduces the total number of links by a large factor as it uses a pass-through routing system to offload streaming. Coming back to our game example, now the rules are changed. Rather than giving Oreos and receiving sweets individually from other players you give them to a newly appointed helper.
This helps in two ways,
A. You‚Äôll need fewer Oreos for playing the game üç™
B. The helper can also speed up the game by taking up the physical work going and exchanging the sweets üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

2. MCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit)

This is similar to SFU, but by offloading CPU-intensive work on the server. This essentially is similar to SFU but the major processing is done by the Server rather than the clients. Going back to our game, we saw SFU introducing a helper for ease of players. In the case of MCU, we can say that we get a helper which is a robot who comes to the players for sweet exchange thus even speeding up the process of exchange and enabling even more players to join in on the fun! Helper combines the sweets and then gives out an Icecream rather than you processing the candy!
The issue is,
A. Depending on the helper this much would also mean that the Helper should be at 100% efficiency all the time or it might slow down the sweet exchange üîã
B. Any changes to the game in the later stage will be expensive üí∏

There are various solutions that are being used for the scaling issues for WebRTC, but we feel these two are some of the easier to implement and maintain.
What are we using? üòé

We created our own customized SFU solution by using some open-source libraries. We developed smart algorithms that would scale the meetings and eventually optimize the server resources. The main reason for using SFU is simple, the architecture is less complicated than other solutions also it has some perks like,
Streams are separate, so each can be rendered individually ‚Äî allowing full control of the layout of streams on the client side.
Since there is only one outgoing stream, the client does not need a wide outgoing channel.
When we talk about decentralizing the communication system, we can implement SFU rather than MCU as servers need not be having high processing powers, rather normal or above-average hosts can just do the trick.
SFU architecture is less demanding to the server as compared to other video conferencing architecture.
That‚Äôs it, folks, these are some of the basics of WebRTC and how we plan to scale it! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach us out on Twitter or land on our discord!
