65 85 / var(--tw-text-opacity));padding-left:0.5rem;padding-right:0.5rem;font-size:0.875rem;line-height:1.25rem;}.css-1akpj8f:hover{--tw-bg-opacity:1;background-color:rgb(226 232 240 / var(--tw-bg-opacity));}.css-1akpj8f:focus{outline:2px solid transparent;outline-offset:2px;}.css-1akpj8f:disabled{opacity:0.5;}.dark .css-1akpj8f{--tw-text-opacity:1;color:rgb(226 232 240 / var(--tw-text-opacity));}.dark .css-1akpj8f:hover{--tw-bg-opacity:1;background-color:rgb(51 65 85 / var(--tw-bg-opacity));}.css-oyfwdt{width:100%;position:relative;z-index:20;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;display:grid;grid-auto-flow:row;grid-template-columns:repeat(8, minmax(0, 1fr));}@media (min-width: 640px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:640px;}}@media (min-width: 768px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:768px;}}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1024px;}}@media (min-width: 1280px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1280px;gap:1.5rem;}}@media (min-width: 1536px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1536px;grid-template-columns:repeat(10, minmax(0, 1fr));}}.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 8/span 8;padding-left:1rem;padding-right:1rem;}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:2;padding-left:0px;padding-right:0px;}}@media (min-width: 1280px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:2;}}@media (min-width: 1536px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:3;}}
              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }
            {"props":{"pageProps":{"post":"{\"_id\":\"63353e42697c5665ab7e3ecb\",\"createdAt\":\"2022-09-29T06:42:10.494Z\",\"updatedAt\":\"2022-09-29T06:42:10.494Z\",\"views\":33,\"isActive\":true,\"sourcedFromGithub\":false,\"hasLatex\":false,\"popularity\":5676.0562,\"enableToc\":true,\"type\":\"story\",\"partOfPublication\":true,\"responseCount\":0,\"replyCount\":0,\"isFeatured\":false,\"isEngaging\":false,\"isDelisted\":false,\"isNotified\":false,\"numCollapsed\":0,\"reactions\":[],\"totalReactions\":0,\"isPinnedToBlog\":false,\"disableComments\":false,\"commentsPaused\":false,\"syncAlgolia\":false,\"numUniqueUsersWhoReacted\":0,\"slugOverridden\":false,\"title\":\"What is WebRTC and how are we scaling it?\",\"cuid\":\"cl8mov9vg001c09l5hvxt0qnq\",\"dateAdded\":\"2022-09-29T06:42:10.492Z\",\"hasCustomDate\":null,\"isCoverAttributionHidden\":false,\"coverImageAttribution\":\"\",\"coverImagePhotographer\":\"\",\"slug\":\"what-is-webrtc-and-how-are-we-scaling-it\",\"toc\":[[{\"id\":\"bfb96c0d-3f0f-4c77-9ca7-732300cd5e21\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":null,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-is-webrtc\",\"title\":\"What is webRTC? ü§î\"}],[{\"id\":\"85baa609-cd6f-441b-9385-bc67d36400e4\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"webrtc-working\",\"title\":\"WebRTC working ‚öôÔ∏è\"}],[{\"id\":\"c62f2640-29f4-4311-91d7-e0d4c9cf05ce\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"problems-with-webrtc\",\"title\":\"Problems with WebRTC üò¢\"}],[{\"id\":\"6e08c872-c8a3-4b44-a0b8-60ce89a4d9d4\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"solution-for-scaling\",\"title\":\"Solution for scaling üõ†\"}],[{\"id\":\"1053d805-37cb-46d6-9936-4155f305ed03\",\"level\":2,\"previousLevel\":2,\"parentId\":null,\"slug\":\"what-are-we-using\",\"title\":\"What are we using? üòé\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432727555/0GfwYaj8X.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is building the next generation of internet communication by aiming to improve the current tech stack by keeping the decentralizing approach in mind. Not only this, we plan to revolutionize the current internet communication landscape!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eComing to WebRTC, it was originally designed by Global IP Solutions (or GIPS), a company founded around 1999 in Sweden. Google acquired GIPS in 2011 and open-sourced the WebRTC technology. Since then, different browsers like Mozilla, Chrome, and Opera show great support for WebRTC.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-webrtc\\\"\u003eWhat is webRTC? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432745894/y4zsSHdfj.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWithout wasting any time, let‚Äôs start with what webRTC is. WebRTC is an acronym for Web Real-Time Communication. According to Wikipedia, ‚ÄúWebRTC is a free and open-source project providing web browsers and mobile applications with real-time communication via application programming interfaces.‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBreaking it down in layman‚Äôs terms, WebRTC is an open-source program that enables Peer-to-Peer communication between two separate devices via the Internet. These can be mobiles, tablets, and PCs. It is helping projects integrate audio/video services into their Applications. Imagine webRTC as the hard work in making a pickle, once it is made, everyone who has it can use it in their recipes as they please.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-webrtc-working\\\"\u003eWebRTC working ‚öôÔ∏è\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432816593/1D1At1k3o.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC working is quite complicated, but to very simply break it down to you, we can say WebRTC has 4 steps in establishing a connection and these are followed strictly in the given order:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSignaling üì°\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is pretty intuitive for understanding how this works. You need to find someone to connect with, you‚Äôll send a signal to search and notify if the recipient is present. Think of it as ordering your favorite shoes from Amazon, first amazon check if they are available and if they are they send you the shoes!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConnecting ü§ù\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe two WebRTC Agents now know enough details to attempt to connect to each other. WebRTC then uses another established technology called ICE (Interactive Connectivity Establishment).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSecuring üîí\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe have two sides that are connected and are communicating in real-time. As we don‚Äôt like anyone else to listen to our gossip with our best friends, these connections must be secured by a third-party attacker. This is done by DTLS (Datagram Transport Layer Protocol) and SRTP(Secure Real-time Transport Protocol) which predates WebRTC!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCommunicating üó®Ô∏è\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow the connection is established and secured, the only thing is to share data in real-time. This is again done by pre-existing protocols like RTP and SCTP. I know this is a bit vague but think of it as you are playing cards with your friend, real-time data sharing essentially means you can see what cards your friend is playing without delays. Thus just connection establishment isn‚Äôt enough, real-time data sharing is the key alpha here!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-problems-with-webrtc\\\"\u003eProblems with WebRTC üò¢\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432936562/gYXSGWhVn.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is truly a great piece of innovation, but as there are 2 sides to each coin, WebRTC also has some significant issues! WebRTC isn‚Äôt actually scalable!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWait, what? WebRTC isn‚Äôt scalable? üò≤\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYup, WebRTC is great for peer-to-peer communication, but when it comes to more than 10 people trying to communicate in real time, the system can‚Äôt be used.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy? üòû\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC needs bidirectional connections to each client and as we increase the number of clients, the communication complexes maintaining so many connections are in place. Well, the problem is each node or client is connected with each of the other clients present, thus creating intensive and resource-heavy connections from one client.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432978480/FsejQfgYo.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet me explain this with an example, It‚Äôs a fare! You are out with your friends and playing a game. The rules of the games are simple, anyone who is playing has to bring their own sweet and has to exchange it for the sweet of the other person. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs say there are 3 friends who have Oreo, Candy, and a lollipop. So, you‚Äôll have 2 of each to share and you‚Äôll receive one of the other sweets each. Let‚Äôs say you are the one with Oreo then the problem arises when,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eYou can only afford a certain number of Oreos to give away.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs, the number of players increases, each would bring in a new sweet, \u0026amp; after a point, you can‚Äôt receive any more sweets as your bag is already full.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHere, Oreos refer to uplink and all other sweets refer to downlinks for the client connections for you.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-solution-for-scaling\\\"\u003eSolution for scaling üõ†\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433065535/Q2iZ7AIIj.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSelective Forwarding Unit (SFU)\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe most popular solution for the scalability problem. SFU reduces the total number of links by a large factor as it uses a pass-through routing system to offload streaming. Coming back to our game example, now the rules are changed. Rather than giving Oreos and receiving sweets individually from other players you give them to a newly appointed helper.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis helps in two ways,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eA. You‚Äôll need fewer Oreos for playing the game üç™\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eB. The helper can also speed up the game by taking up the physical work going and exchanging the sweets üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433105706/hdFLLiSah.png\\\" alt=\\\"7.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. MCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit)\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is similar to SFU, but by offloading CPU-intensive work on the server. This essentially is similar to SFU but the major processing is done by the Server rather than the clients. Going back to our game, we saw SFU introducing a helper for ease of players. In the case of MCU, we can say that we get a helper which is a robot who comes to the players for sweet exchange thus even speeding up the process of exchange and enabling even more players to join in on the fun! Helper combines the sweets and then gives out an Icecream rather than you processing the candy!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe issue is,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eA. Depending on the helper this much would also mean that the Helper should be at 100% efficiency all the time or it might slow down the sweet exchange üîã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eB. Any changes to the game in the later stage will be expensive üí∏\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433155394/ymZ5soxCO.png\\\" alt=\\\"8.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are various solutions that are being used for the scaling issues for WebRTC, but we feel these two are some of the easier to implement and maintain.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-are-we-using\\\"\u003eWhat are we using? üòé\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433180981/AdXstYM_x.png\\\" alt=\\\"9.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe created our own customized SFU solution by using some open-source libraries. We developed smart algorithms that would scale the meetings and eventually optimize the server resources. The main reason for using SFU is simple, the architecture is less complicated than other solutions also it has some perks like,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eStreams are separate, so each can be rendered individually ‚Äî allowing full control of the layout of streams on the client side.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSince there is only one outgoing stream, the client does not need a wide outgoing channel.\\nWhen we talk about decentralizing the communication system, we can implement SFU rather than MCU as servers need not be having high processing powers, rather normal or above-average hosts can just do the trick.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU architecture is less demanding to the server as compared to other video conferencing architecture.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it, folks, these are some of the basics of WebRTC and how we plan to scale it! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach us out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/preetham_eth\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432727555/0GfwYaj8X.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is building the next generation of internet communication by aiming to improve the current tech stack by keeping the decentralizing approach in mind. Not only this, we plan to revolutionize the current internet communication landscape!\\n\\nComing to WebRTC, it was originally designed by Global IP Solutions (or GIPS), a company founded around 1999 in Sweden. Google acquired GIPS in 2011 and open-sourced the WebRTC technology. Since then, different browsers like Mozilla, Chrome, and Opera show great support for WebRTC.\\n\\n## What is webRTC? ü§î\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432745894/y4zsSHdfj.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWithout wasting any time, let‚Äôs start with what webRTC is. WebRTC is an acronym for Web Real-Time Communication. According to Wikipedia, ‚ÄúWebRTC is a free and open-source project providing web browsers and mobile applications with real-time communication via application programming interfaces.‚Äù\\n\\nBreaking it down in layman‚Äôs terms, WebRTC is an open-source program that enables Peer-to-Peer communication between two separate devices via the Internet. These can be mobiles, tablets, and PCs. It is helping projects integrate audio/video services into their Applications. Imagine webRTC as the hard work in making a pickle, once it is made, everyone who has it can use it in their recipes as they please.\\n\\n## WebRTC working ‚öôÔ∏è\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432816593/1D1At1k3o.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWebRTC working is quite complicated, but to very simply break it down to you, we can say WebRTC has 4 steps in establishing a connection and these are followed strictly in the given order:\\n\\n**Signaling üì°\\n**\\n\\nThis is pretty intuitive for understanding how this works. You need to find someone to connect with, you‚Äôll send a signal to search and notify if the recipient is present. Think of it as ordering your favorite shoes from Amazon, first amazon check if they are available and if they are they send you the shoes!\\n\\n**Connecting ü§ù\\n**\\n\\nThe two WebRTC Agents now know enough details to attempt to connect to each other. WebRTC then uses another established technology called ICE (Interactive Connectivity Establishment).\\n\\n**Securing üîí\\n**\\n\\nWe have two sides that are connected and are communicating in real-time. As we don‚Äôt like anyone else to listen to our gossip with our best friends, these connections must be secured by a third-party attacker. This is done by DTLS (Datagram Transport Layer Protocol) and SRTP(Secure Real-time Transport Protocol) which predates WebRTC!\\n\\n**Communicating üó®Ô∏è\\n**\\n\\nNow the connection is established and secured, the only thing is to share data in real-time. This is again done by pre-existing protocols like RTP and SCTP. I know this is a bit vague but think of it as you are playing cards with your friend, real-time data sharing essentially means you can see what cards your friend is playing without delays. Thus just connection establishment isn‚Äôt enough, real-time data sharing is the key alpha here!\\n\\n## Problems with WebRTC üò¢\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432936562/gYXSGWhVn.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWebRTC is truly a great piece of innovation, but as there are 2 sides to each coin, WebRTC also has some significant issues! WebRTC isn‚Äôt actually scalable!\\n\\n**Wait, what? WebRTC isn‚Äôt scalable? üò≤\\n**\\n\\nYup, WebRTC is great for peer-to-peer communication, but when it comes to more than 10 people trying to communicate in real time, the system can‚Äôt be used.\\n\\n**Why? üòû\\n**\\n\\nWebRTC needs bidirectional connections to each client and as we increase the number of clients, the communication complexes maintaining so many connections are in place. Well, the problem is each node or client is connected with each of the other clients present, thus creating intensive and resource-heavy connections from one client.\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432978480/FsejQfgYo.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLet me explain this with an example, It‚Äôs a fare! You are out with your friends and playing a game. The rules of the games are simple, anyone who is playing has to bring their own sweet and has to exchange it for the sweet of the other person. \\n\\nLet‚Äôs say there are 3 friends who have Oreo, Candy, and a lollipop. So, you‚Äôll have 2 of each to share and you‚Äôll receive one of the other sweets each. Let‚Äôs say you are the one with Oreo then the problem arises when,\\n\\n1. You can only afford a certain number of Oreos to give away.\\n\\n2. As, the number of players increases, each would bring in a new sweet, \u0026 after a point, you can‚Äôt receive any more sweets as your bag is already full.\\n\\nHere, Oreos refer to uplink and all other sweets refer to downlinks for the client connections for you.\\n\\n## Solution for scaling üõ†\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433065535/Q2iZ7AIIj.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n**Selective Forwarding Unit (SFU)\\n**\\n\\nThe most popular solution for the scalability problem. SFU reduces the total number of links by a large factor as it uses a pass-through routing system to offload streaming. Coming back to our game example, now the rules are changed. Rather than giving Oreos and receiving sweets individually from other players you give them to a newly appointed helper.\\n\\nThis helps in two ways,\\n\\nA. You‚Äôll need fewer Oreos for playing the game üç™\\n\\nB. The helper can also speed up the game by taking up the physical work going and exchanging the sweets üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è\\n\\n![7.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433105706/hdFLLiSah.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n**2. MCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit)\\n**\\n\\nThis is similar to SFU, but by offloading CPU-intensive work on the server. This essentially is similar to SFU but the major processing is done by the Server rather than the clients. Going back to our game, we saw SFU introducing a helper for ease of players. In the case of MCU, we can say that we get a helper which is a robot who comes to the players for sweet exchange thus even speeding up the process of exchange and enabling even more players to join in on the fun! Helper combines the sweets and then gives out an Icecream rather than you processing the candy!\\n\\nThe issue is,\\n\\nA. Depending on the helper this much would also mean that the Helper should be at 100% efficiency all the time or it might slow down the sweet exchange üîã\\n\\nB. Any changes to the game in the later stage will be expensive üí∏\\n\\n![8.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433155394/ymZ5soxCO.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThere are various solutions that are being used for the scaling issues for WebRTC, but we feel these two are some of the easier to implement and maintain.\\n\\n## What are we using? üòé\\n\\n![9.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433180981/AdXstYM_x.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe created our own customized SFU solution by using some open-source libraries. We developed smart algorithms that would scale the meetings and eventually optimize the server resources. The main reason for using SFU is simple, the architecture is less complicated than other solutions also it has some perks like,\\n\\nStreams are separate, so each can be rendered individually ‚Äî allowing full control of the layout of streams on the client side.\\n\\nSince there is only one outgoing stream, the client does not need a wide outgoing channel.\\nWhen we talk about decentralizing the communication system, we can implement SFU rather than MCU as servers need not be having high processing powers, rather normal or above-average hosts can just do the trick.\\n\\nSFU architecture is less demanding to the server as compared to other video conferencing architecture.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it, folks, these are some of the basics of WebRTC and how we plan to scale it! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach us out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/preetham_eth) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)!\\n\\n\\n\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is building the next generation of internet communication by aiming to improve the current tech stack by keeping the decentralizing approach in mind. üòé\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432727555/0GfwYaj8X.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is building the next generation of internet communication by aiming to improve the current tech stack by keeping the decentralizing approach in mind. Not only this, we plan to revolutionize the current internet communication landscape!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eComing to WebRTC, it was originally designed by Global IP Solutions (or GIPS), a company founded around 1999 in Sweden. Google acquired GIPS in 2011 and open-sourced the WebRTC technology. Since then, different browsers like Mozilla, Chrome, and Opera show great support for WebRTC.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-webrtc\\\"\u003eWhat is webRTC? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432745894/y4zsSHdfj.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWithout wasting any time, let‚Äôs start with what webRTC is. WebRTC is an acronym for Web Real-Time Communication. According to Wikipedia, ‚ÄúWebRTC is a free and open-source project providing web browsers and mobile applications with real-time communication via application programming interfaces.‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eBreaking it down in layman‚Äôs terms, WebRTC is an open-source program that enables Peer-to-Peer communication between two separate devices via the Internet. These can be mobiles, tablets, and PCs. It is helping projects integrate audio/video services into their Applications. Imagine webRTC as the hard work in making a pickle, once it is made, everyone who has it can use it in their recipes as they please.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-webrtc-working\\\"\u003eWebRTC working ‚öôÔ∏è\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432816593/1D1At1k3o.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC working is quite complicated, but to very simply break it down to you, we can say WebRTC has 4 steps in establishing a connection and these are followed strictly in the given order:\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSignaling üì°\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is pretty intuitive for understanding how this works. You need to find someone to connect with, you‚Äôll send a signal to search and notify if the recipient is present. Think of it as ordering your favorite shoes from Amazon, first amazon check if they are available and if they are they send you the shoes!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConnecting ü§ù\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe two WebRTC Agents now know enough details to attempt to connect to each other. WebRTC then uses another established technology called ICE (Interactive Connectivity Establishment).\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSecuring üîí\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe have two sides that are connected and are communicating in real-time. As we don‚Äôt like anyone else to listen to our gossip with our best friends, these connections must be secured by a third-party attacker. This is done by DTLS (Datagram Transport Layer Protocol) and SRTP(Secure Real-time Transport Protocol) which predates WebRTC!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCommunicating üó®Ô∏è\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eNow the connection is established and secured, the only thing is to share data in real-time. This is again done by pre-existing protocols like RTP and SCTP. I know this is a bit vague but think of it as you are playing cards with your friend, real-time data sharing essentially means you can see what cards your friend is playing without delays. Thus just connection establishment isn‚Äôt enough, real-time data sharing is the key alpha here!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-problems-with-webrtc\\\"\u003eProblems with WebRTC üò¢\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432936562/gYXSGWhVn.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC is truly a great piece of innovation, but as there are 2 sides to each coin, WebRTC also has some significant issues! WebRTC isn‚Äôt actually scalable!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWait, what? WebRTC isn‚Äôt scalable? üò≤\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYup, WebRTC is great for peer-to-peer communication, but when it comes to more than 10 people trying to communicate in real time, the system can‚Äôt be used.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy? üòû\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWebRTC needs bidirectional connections to each client and as we increase the number of clients, the communication complexes maintaining so many connections are in place. Well, the problem is each node or client is connected with each of the other clients present, thus creating intensive and resource-heavy connections from one client.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432978480/FsejQfgYo.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet me explain this with an example, It‚Äôs a fare! You are out with your friends and playing a game. The rules of the games are simple, anyone who is playing has to bring their own sweet and has to exchange it for the sweet of the other person. \u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs say there are 3 friends who have Oreo, Candy, and a lollipop. So, you‚Äôll have 2 of each to share and you‚Äôll receive one of the other sweets each. Let‚Äôs say you are the one with Oreo then the problem arises when,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003col\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eYou can only afford a certain number of Oreos to give away.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cp\u003eAs, the number of players increases, each would bring in a new sweet, \u0026amp; after a point, you can‚Äôt receive any more sweets as your bag is already full.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ol\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHere, Oreos refer to uplink and all other sweets refer to downlinks for the client connections for you.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-solution-for-scaling\\\"\u003eSolution for scaling üõ†\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433065535/Q2iZ7AIIj.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSelective Forwarding Unit (SFU)\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe most popular solution for the scalability problem. SFU reduces the total number of links by a large factor as it uses a pass-through routing system to offload streaming. Coming back to our game example, now the rules are changed. Rather than giving Oreos and receiving sweets individually from other players you give them to a newly appointed helper.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis helps in two ways,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eA. You‚Äôll need fewer Oreos for playing the game üç™\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eB. The helper can also speed up the game by taking up the physical work going and exchanging the sweets üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433105706/hdFLLiSah.png\\\" alt=\\\"7.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. MCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit)\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is similar to SFU, but by offloading CPU-intensive work on the server. This essentially is similar to SFU but the major processing is done by the Server rather than the clients. Going back to our game, we saw SFU introducing a helper for ease of players. In the case of MCU, we can say that we get a helper which is a robot who comes to the players for sweet exchange thus even speeding up the process of exchange and enabling even more players to join in on the fun! Helper combines the sweets and then gives out an Icecream rather than you processing the candy!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe issue is,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eA. Depending on the helper this much would also mean that the Helper should be at 100% efficiency all the time or it might slow down the sweet exchange üîã\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eB. Any changes to the game in the later stage will be expensive üí∏\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433155394/ymZ5soxCO.png\\\" alt=\\\"8.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThere are various solutions that are being used for the scaling issues for WebRTC, but we feel these two are some of the easier to implement and maintain.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-are-we-using\\\"\u003eWhat are we using? üòé\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433180981/AdXstYM_x.png\\\" alt=\\\"9.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWe created our own customized SFU solution by using some open-source libraries. We developed smart algorithms that would scale the meetings and eventually optimize the server resources. The main reason for using SFU is simple, the architecture is less complicated than other solutions also it has some perks like,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eStreams are separate, so each can be rendered individually ‚Äî allowing full control of the layout of streams on the client side.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSince there is only one outgoing stream, the client does not need a wide outgoing channel.\\nWhen we talk about decentralizing the communication system, we can implement SFU rather than MCU as servers need not be having high processing powers, rather normal or above-average hosts can just do the trick.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSFU architecture is less demanding to the server as compared to other video conferencing architecture.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThat‚Äôs it, folks, these are some of the basics of WebRTC and how we plan to scale it! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach us out on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/preetham_eth\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e or land on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003ediscord\u003c/a\u003e!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432727555/0GfwYaj8X.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is building the next generation of internet communication by aiming to improve the current tech stack by keeping the decentralizing approach in mind. Not only this, we plan to revolutionize the current internet communication landscape!\\n\\nComing to WebRTC, it was originally designed by Global IP Solutions (or GIPS), a company founded around 1999 in Sweden. Google acquired GIPS in 2011 and open-sourced the WebRTC technology. Since then, different browsers like Mozilla, Chrome, and Opera show great support for WebRTC.\\n\\n## What is webRTC? ü§î\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432745894/y4zsSHdfj.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWithout wasting any time, let‚Äôs start with what webRTC is. WebRTC is an acronym for Web Real-Time Communication. According to Wikipedia, ‚ÄúWebRTC is a free and open-source project providing web browsers and mobile applications with real-time communication via application programming interfaces.‚Äù\\n\\nBreaking it down in layman‚Äôs terms, WebRTC is an open-source program that enables Peer-to-Peer communication between two separate devices via the Internet. These can be mobiles, tablets, and PCs. It is helping projects integrate audio/video services into their Applications. Imagine webRTC as the hard work in making a pickle, once it is made, everyone who has it can use it in their recipes as they please.\\n\\n## WebRTC working ‚öôÔ∏è\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432816593/1D1At1k3o.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWebRTC working is quite complicated, but to very simply break it down to you, we can say WebRTC has 4 steps in establishing a connection and these are followed strictly in the given order:\\n\\n**Signaling üì°\\n**\\n\\nThis is pretty intuitive for understanding how this works. You need to find someone to connect with, you‚Äôll send a signal to search and notify if the recipient is present. Think of it as ordering your favorite shoes from Amazon, first amazon check if they are available and if they are they send you the shoes!\\n\\n**Connecting ü§ù\\n**\\n\\nThe two WebRTC Agents now know enough details to attempt to connect to each other. WebRTC then uses another established technology called ICE (Interactive Connectivity Establishment).\\n\\n**Securing üîí\\n**\\n\\nWe have two sides that are connected and are communicating in real-time. As we don‚Äôt like anyone else to listen to our gossip with our best friends, these connections must be secured by a third-party attacker. This is done by DTLS (Datagram Transport Layer Protocol) and SRTP(Secure Real-time Transport Protocol) which predates WebRTC!\\n\\n**Communicating üó®Ô∏è\\n**\\n\\nNow the connection is established and secured, the only thing is to share data in real-time. This is again done by pre-existing protocols like RTP and SCTP. I know this is a bit vague but think of it as you are playing cards with your friend, real-time data sharing essentially means you can see what cards your friend is playing without delays. Thus just connection establishment isn‚Äôt enough, real-time data sharing is the key alpha here!\\n\\n## Problems with WebRTC üò¢\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432936562/gYXSGWhVn.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWebRTC is truly a great piece of innovation, but as there are 2 sides to each coin, WebRTC also has some significant issues! WebRTC isn‚Äôt actually scalable!\\n\\n**Wait, what? WebRTC isn‚Äôt scalable? üò≤\\n**\\n\\nYup, WebRTC is great for peer-to-peer communication, but when it comes to more than 10 people trying to communicate in real time, the system can‚Äôt be used.\\n\\n**Why? üòû\\n**\\n\\nWebRTC needs bidirectional connections to each client and as we increase the number of clients, the communication complexes maintaining so many connections are in place. Well, the problem is each node or client is connected with each of the other clients present, thus creating intensive and resource-heavy connections from one client.\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664432978480/FsejQfgYo.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLet me explain this with an example, It‚Äôs a fare! You are out with your friends and playing a game. The rules of the games are simple, anyone who is playing has to bring their own sweet and has to exchange it for the sweet of the other person. \\n\\nLet‚Äôs say there are 3 friends who have Oreo, Candy, and a lollipop. So, you‚Äôll have 2 of each to share and you‚Äôll receive one of the other sweets each. Let‚Äôs say you are the one with Oreo then the problem arises when,\\n\\n1. You can only afford a certain number of Oreos to give away.\\n\\n2. As, the number of players increases, each would bring in a new sweet, \u0026 after a point, you can‚Äôt receive any more sweets as your bag is already full.\\n\\nHere, Oreos refer to uplink and all other sweets refer to downlinks for the client connections for you.\\n\\n## Solution for scaling üõ†\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433065535/Q2iZ7AIIj.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n**Selective Forwarding Unit (SFU)\\n**\\n\\nThe most popular solution for the scalability problem. SFU reduces the total number of links by a large factor as it uses a pass-through routing system to offload streaming. Coming back to our game example, now the rules are changed. Rather than giving Oreos and receiving sweets individually from other players you give them to a newly appointed helper.\\n\\nThis helps in two ways,\\n\\nA. You‚Äôll need fewer Oreos for playing the game üç™\\n\\nB. The helper can also speed up the game by taking up the physical work going and exchanging the sweets üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è\\n\\n![7.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433105706/hdFLLiSah.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\n**2. MCU (Multipoint Conferencing Unit)\\n**\\n\\nThis is similar to SFU, but by offloading CPU-intensive work on the server. This essentially is similar to SFU but the major processing is done by the Server rather than the clients. Going back to our game, we saw SFU introducing a helper for ease of players. In the case of MCU, we can say that we get a helper which is a robot who comes to the players for sweet exchange thus even speeding up the process of exchange and enabling even more players to join in on the fun! Helper combines the sweets and then gives out an Icecream rather than you processing the candy!\\n\\nThe issue is,\\n\\nA. Depending on the helper this much would also mean that the Helper should be at 100% efficiency all the time or it might slow down the sweet exchange üîã\\n\\nB. Any changes to the game in the later stage will be expensive üí∏\\n\\n![8.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433155394/ymZ5soxCO.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThere are various solutions that are being used for the scaling issues for WebRTC, but we feel these two are some of the easier to implement and maintain.\\n\\n## What are we using? üòé\\n\\n![9.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1664433180981/AdXstYM_x.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nWe created our own customized SFU solution by using some open-source libraries. We developed smart algorithms that would scale the meetings and eventually optimize the server resources. The main reason for using SFU is simple, the architecture is less complicated than other solutions also it has some perks like,\\n\\nStreams are separate, so each can be rendered individually ‚Äî allowing full control of the layout of streams on the client side.\\n\\nSince there is only one outgoing stream, the client does not need a wide outgoing channel.\\nWhen we talk about decentralizing the communication system, we can implement SFU rather than MCU as servers need not be having high processing powers, rather normal or above-average hosts can just do the trick.\\n\\nSFU architecture is less demanding to the server as compared to other video conferencing architecture.\\n\\nThat‚Äôs it, folks, these are some of the basics of WebRTC and how we plan to scale it! If you have any questions/suggestions or team-ups in mind, reach us out on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/preetham_eth) or land on our [discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt)!\\n\\n\\n\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is building the next generation of internet communication by aiming to improve the current tech stack by keeping the decentralizing approach in mind. :where(.xl:prose-xl > :first-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-top:0;}.css-1xzox7c :where(.xl:prose-xl > :last-child):not(:where([class~="not-prose"] *)){margin-bottom:0;}}
Huddle01 is making the future of communication systems by aiming to replace the current infrastructure with a better and more efficient tech stack keeping the decentralized aspect in mind. Today we‚Äôll talk briefly about Verifiable computation and exactly the buzz around this. Why is there a race around this?
Okay, wear your thinking caps, as we are going to discuss some concepts that are a bit difficult to understand! These are things that we are going to discuss in this blog,
What is computation? ü§î

Need to outsource this computation? ü§ß

Okay, that‚Äôs great but what‚Äôs the problem? üò¶

Zero Knowledge Proof, what‚Äôs that? üòî

Can we combine both? Zero-knowledge Proof and outsourcing computation! ü§Ø

What is Huddle01 doing? üòé

What is computation? ü§î

According to Oxford Dictionary and the first google search, Computation means ‚Äúthe action of mathematical calculation‚Äù. But, when we discuss the word computation, it primarily refers to a computer performing some heavy tasks. It can be anything from loading a game screen to mining bitcoins.
Depending on the configuration of the hardware, we can predict how many tasks or ‚Äòcomputations‚Äô a computer can perform in a certain given time. We measure most of this called processing power. The unit is usually in GHz. The higher this number, the faster the machine!
With time, we developed complex programs and software that require faster processors or machines to complete a task in the shortest time possible.
Need to outsource this computation? ü§ß

The hardware of the computer has significantly shrunk over time. But, the programs that are run on this hardware have also become complex. After a certain point, offloading heavy computations from Personal computers, Tablets, and mobiles was a solution that was accepted! The best reasons can be listed as,

Size üí™

As the devices got shorter, and the programs got complex there was innovation with processors and graphic cards. But, only a certain amount of storage and size can be offered to smaller devices. The Apps got bigger, more complex, and overall ‚ÄòComputationally heavy‚Äô this would tamper with the health of the device and limit the applications that can be run on the device.

Speed üöò

Processing heavy data would eventually take more time on a smaller chip than on a server. Also, this would slow down the device, so taking the major processing away from the device would enable the device to be faster and free to perform tasks that are not heavy.

Cost üí∞

It is cheap to rent a server than to get actual hardware to process it, also it helps to scale any early-stage product!
If you are still here and don‚Äôt get a word of what you just read, stay with me. Let‚Äôs take a simple example.
You are a farmer who doesn‚Äôt have a tractor to plow the field. You are a lucky chad and have lots and lots of land! But, the problem is, to plow this huge land you need a tractor, but you can‚Äôt afford one as of now. Also, the rainy season is just around the corner for plantations. The best thing you do is rent a tractor and kick-start your farming journey. Here,
The Farm is the computation üåΩ
Farmer is the product/service üßëüèº‚Äçüåæ
The tractor is the computation outsourced üöú
Okay, that‚Äôs great but what‚Äôs the problem üôÑ

So, you offload your computation to an external server and the server sends you the processed output, and it‚Äôs the end of the story. Right?No! Let‚Äôs see the problems with this!

Security üîí

When you send your data to offload computation, how do you verify it is not being recorded and monitored? Also, how do you ensure that this data isn‚Äôt stored after it is processed? Going back to our farm example, how do you verify that the tractor you used to plow the field isn‚Äôt stealing soil samples from your farm?

Verification ‚úÖ

Okay, security is something that can always be figured out, but how do you verify that the data you received is correct? You can verify by processing it locally, but then what is the point of offloading it to an external source?
To solve this, there are multiple solutions, but for now, we would stick to the security aspect of the problem. There is a concept called zero-knowledge Proof that comes into play here!
Zero Knowledge Proof, what‚Äôs that ü§î

Let‚Äôs ask Google, what zero-knowledge means, google responded, ‚ÄúIn cryptography, a zero-knowledge proof or zero-knowledge protocol is a method by which one party can prove to another party that a given statement is true while the prover avoids conveying any additional information apart from the fact that the statement is indeed true.‚Äù
Don‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs not as complicated as it looks! So let me tell you in an easy way. Zero-knowledge means asking someone to do something without telling what it is and why is it being done. This also means that the work done by them is proven to be correct.
Still fuzzy? üòû

Okay, let‚Äôs take an example.
I have a superpower, I can count leaves on any tree with just one look üçÉPretty awesome, right?
You don‚Äôt have the same powers as me so how do you make sure I am not making this up?
Easy, we do something that can verify and prove that I am not making this up. I‚Äôll close my eyes, and I‚Äôll tell you to pluck some leaves from a tree.
It‚Äôs entirely your choice to either pluck some leaves or not pluck any leaves at all.
Then you‚Äôll ask me how many leaves you plucked, and if I give a correct answer, you have your zero-knowledge proof! ü§Ø
Credits to Rahil Arora for the leaf example!
Combining Zero Knowledge Proof and Computation ü§Ø

Let‚Äôs take it a step further, we want to make a system where computation can have a ZKP. This is essentially called verifiable computation and there are two ways to do it. Unfortunately, both of them require some crazy mathematical skills to understand. Either way, let‚Äôs see the two types.

Proof-based Protocol:

Proof-based Protocols use back-and-forth communication with the client(farmer) to process and give ZKP. This is not efficient and is not preferred in many scenarios.

Argument-based Protocol:

Argument-based Protocol just communicates once with the client(sometimes it can be interactive) and you can have your computation offloaded.
This is something we will explore in future blogs but for today enough computation for you.
What is Huddle01 doing? üòé

You are probably wondering what Huddle01 has to do with all of this. Well, to give an early alpha, we are working to change the way current RTC communications are done. So, this is something closely related to what we are aiming to achieve. That is the best we can share for now.
If you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind. Hit us on Twitter and be friends with us on our Discord. That would be it for today.

var(--tw-bg-opacity));}.css-oyfwdt{width:100%;position:relative;z-index:20;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;display:grid;grid-auto-flow:row;grid-template-columns:repeat(8, minmax(0, 1fr));}@media (min-width: 640px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:640px;}}@media (min-width: 768px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:768px;}}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1024px;}}@media (min-width: 1280px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1280px;gap:1.5rem;}}@media (min-width: 1536px){.css-oyfwdt{max-width:1536px;grid-template-columns:repeat(10, minmax(0, 1fr));}}.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 8/span 8;padding-left:1rem;padding-right:1rem;}@media (min-width: 1024px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:2;padding-left:0px;padding-right:0px;}}@media (min-width: 1280px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:2;}}@media (min-width: 1536px){.css-4zpucl{grid-column:span 6/span 6;grid-column-start:3;}}
              var SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = false;
              try {
                var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', {
                  get: function() {
                    SUPPORTS_PASSIVE = true;
                  }
                });
                window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
                window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts);
              } catch (e) {}
            
              // Array.prototype.flat polyfill
              if (!Array.prototype.flat) {
                // eslint-disable-next-line no-extend-native
                Object.defineProperty(Array.prototype, 'flat', {
                  configurable: true,
                  writable: true,
                  value() {
                    // eslint-disable-next-line prefer-rest-params
                    const depth = typeof arguments[0] === 'undefined' ? 1 : Number(arguments[0]) || 0;
                    const result = [];
                    const { forEach } = result;
          
                    // eslint-disable-next-line no-var
                    var flatDeep = function (arr, depth) {
                      forEach.call(arr, (val) => {
                        if (depth > 0 && Array.isArray(val)) {
                          flatDeep(val, depth - 1);
                        } else {
                          result.push(val);
                        }
                      });
                    };
          
                    flatDeep(this, depth);
                    return result;
                  },
                });
              }

üòé\"}]],\"content\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666112821516/UAKaLQRjU.png\\\" alt=\\\"1.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eHuddle01 is making the future of communication systems by aiming to replace the current infrastructure with a better and more efficient tech stack keeping the decentralized aspect in mind. Today we‚Äôll talk briefly about Verifiable computation and exactly the buzz around this. Why is there a race around this?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, wear your thinking caps, as we are going to discuss some concepts that are a bit difficult to understand! These are things that we are going to discuss in this blog,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is computation? ü§î\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNeed to outsource this computation? ü§ß\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOkay, that‚Äôs great but what‚Äôs the problem? üò¶\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eZero Knowledge Proof, what‚Äôs that? üòî\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCan we combine both? Zero-knowledge Proof and outsourcing computation! ü§Ø\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is Huddle01 doing? üòé\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-computation\\\"\u003eWhat is computation? ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666112886368/NDAO7o4ho.png\\\" alt=\\\"2.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to Oxford Dictionary and the first google search, Computation means ‚Äúthe action of mathematical calculation‚Äù. But, when we discuss the word computation, it primarily refers to a computer performing some heavy tasks. It can be anything from loading a game screen to mining bitcoins.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDepending on the configuration of the hardware, we can predict how many tasks or ‚Äòcomputations‚Äô a computer can perform in a certain given time. We measure most of this called processing power. The unit is usually in GHz. The higher this number, the faster the machine!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWith time, we developed complex programs and software that require faster processors or machines to complete a task in the shortest time possible.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-need-to-outsource-this-computation\\\"\u003eNeed to outsource this computation? ü§ß\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113032192/Skd8sdWwr.png\\\" alt=\\\"3.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe hardware of the computer has significantly shrunk over time. But, the programs that are run on this hardware have also become complex. After a certain point, offloading heavy computations from Personal computers, Tablets, and mobiles was a solution that was accepted! The best reasons can be listed as,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSize üí™\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eAs the devices got shorter, and the programs got complex there was innovation with processors and graphic cards. But, only a certain amount of storage and size can be offered to smaller devices. The Apps got bigger, more complex, and overall ‚ÄòComputationally heavy‚Äô this would tamper with the health of the device and limit the applications that can be run on the device.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSpeed üöò\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eProcessing heavy data would eventually take more time on a smaller chip than on a server. Also, this would slow down the device, so taking the major processing away from the device would enable the device to be faster and free to perform tasks that are not heavy.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eCost üí∞\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt is cheap to rent a server than to get actual hardware to process it, also it helps to scale any early-stage product!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are still here and don‚Äôt get a word of what you just read, stay with me. Let‚Äôs take a simple example.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou are a farmer who doesn‚Äôt have a tractor to plow the field. You are a lucky chad and have lots and lots of land! But, the problem is, to plow this huge land you need a tractor, but you can‚Äôt afford one as of now. Also, the rainy season is just around the corner for plantations. The best thing you do is rent a tractor and kick-start your farming journey. Here,\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe Farm is the computation üåΩ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eFarmer is the product/service üßëüèº‚Äçüåæ\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThe tractor is the computation outsourced üöú\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-okay-thats-great-but-whats-the-problem\\\"\u003eOkay, that‚Äôs great but what‚Äôs the problem üôÑ\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113108844/S8z-qa_4mv.png\\\" alt=\\\"4.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eSo, you offload your computation to an external server and the server sends you the processed output, and it‚Äôs the end of the story. Right?No! Let‚Äôs see the problems with this!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eSecurity üîí\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eWhen you send your data to offload computation, how do you verify it is not being recorded and monitored? Also, how do you ensure that this data isn‚Äôt stored after it is processed? Going back to our farm example, how do you verify that the tractor you used to plow the field isn‚Äôt stealing soil samples from your farm?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eVerification ‚úÖ\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, security is something that can always be figured out, but how do you verify that the data you received is correct? You can verify by processing it locally, but then what is the point of offloading it to an external source?\\nTo solve this, there are multiple solutions, but for now, we would stick to the security aspect of the problem. There is a concept called zero-knowledge Proof that comes into play here!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-zero-knowledge-proof-whats-that\\\"\u003eZero Knowledge Proof, what‚Äôs that ü§î\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113166015/n_xIa8nXN.png\\\" alt=\\\"5.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs ask Google, what zero-knowledge means, google responded, ‚ÄúIn cryptography, a zero-knowledge proof or zero-knowledge protocol is a method by which one party can prove to another party that a given statement is true while the prover avoids conveying any additional information apart from the fact that the statement is indeed true.‚Äù\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eDon‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs not as complicated as it looks! So let me tell you in an easy way. Zero-knowledge means asking someone to do something without telling what it is and why is it being done. This also means that the work done by them is proven to be correct.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStill fuzzy? üòû\\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, let‚Äôs take an example.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eI have a superpower, I can count leaves on any tree with just one look üçÉPretty awesome, right?\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou don‚Äôt have the same powers as me so how do you make sure I am not making this up?\\nEasy, we do something that can verify and prove that I am not making this up. I‚Äôll close my eyes, and I‚Äôll tell you to pluck some leaves from a tree.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIt‚Äôs entirely your choice to either pluck some leaves or not pluck any leaves at all.\\nThen you‚Äôll ask me how many leaves you plucked, and if I give a correct answer, you have your zero-knowledge proof! ü§Ø\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eCredits to \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://security.stackexchange.com/users/22401/rahil-arora\\\"\u003eRahil Arora\u003c/a\u003e for the leaf example!\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-combining-zero-knowledge-proof-and-computation\\\"\u003eCombining Zero Knowledge Proof and Computation ü§Ø\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113349878/xyqUepBB8.png\\\" alt=\\\"6.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eLet‚Äôs take it a step further, we want to make a system where computation can have a ZKP. This is essentially called verifiable computation and there are two ways to do it. Unfortunately, both of them require some crazy mathematical skills to understand. Either way, let‚Äôs see the two types.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eProof-based Protocol:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eProof-based Protocols use back-and-forth communication with the client(farmer) to process and give ZKP. This is not efficient and is not preferred in many scenarios.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cul\u003e\\n\u003cli\u003eArgument-based Protocol:\u003c/li\u003e\\n\u003c/ul\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eArgument-based Protocol just communicates once with the client(sometimes it can be interactive) and you can have your computation offloaded.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eThis is something we will explore in future blogs but for today enough computation for you.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003ch2 id=\\\"heading-what-is-huddle01-doing\\\"\u003eWhat is Huddle01 doing? üòé\u003c/h2\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113398209/7NzLyRkQq.png\\\" alt=\\\"7.png\\\" /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eYou are probably wondering what Huddle01 has to do with all of this. Well, to give an early alpha, we are working to change the way current RTC communications are done. So, this is something closely related to what we are aiming to achieve. That is the best we can share for now.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind. Hit us on \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://twitter.com/huddle01com\\\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e and be friends with us on our \u003ca target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt\\\"\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e. That would be it for today.\u003c/p\u003e\\n\",\"contentMarkdown\":\"\\n![1.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666112821516/UAKaLQRjU.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nHuddle01 is making the future of communication systems by aiming to replace the current infrastructure with a better and more efficient tech stack keeping the decentralized aspect in mind. Today we‚Äôll talk briefly about Verifiable computation and exactly the buzz around this. Why is there a race around this?\\n\\nOkay, wear your thinking caps, as we are going to discuss some concepts that are a bit difficult to understand! These are things that we are going to discuss in this blog,\\n\\n**What is computation? ü§î\\n**\\n\\n**Need to outsource this computation? ü§ß\\n**\\n\\n**Okay, that‚Äôs great but what‚Äôs the problem? üò¶\\n**\\n\\n**Zero Knowledge Proof, what‚Äôs that? üòî\\n**\\n\\n**Can we combine both? Zero-knowledge Proof and outsourcing computation! ü§Ø\\n**\\n\\n**What is Huddle01 doing? üòé\\n**\\n\\n## What is computation? ü§î\\n\\n![2.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666112886368/NDAO7o4ho.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nAccording to Oxford Dictionary and the first google search, Computation means ‚Äúthe action of mathematical calculation‚Äù. But, when we discuss the word computation, it primarily refers to a computer performing some heavy tasks. It can be anything from loading a game screen to mining bitcoins.\\n\\nDepending on the configuration of the hardware, we can predict how many tasks or ‚Äòcomputations‚Äô a computer can perform in a certain given time. We measure most of this called processing power. The unit is usually in GHz. The higher this number, the faster the machine!\\n\\nWith time, we developed complex programs and software that require faster processors or machines to complete a task in the shortest time possible.\\n\\n## Need to outsource this computation? ü§ß\\n\\n![3.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113032192/Skd8sdWwr.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nThe hardware of the computer has significantly shrunk over time. But, the programs that are run on this hardware have also become complex. After a certain point, offloading heavy computations from Personal computers, Tablets, and mobiles was a solution that was accepted! The best reasons can be listed as,\\n\\n- Size üí™\\n\\nAs the devices got shorter, and the programs got complex there was innovation with processors and graphic cards. But, only a certain amount of storage and size can be offered to smaller devices. The Apps got bigger, more complex, and overall ‚ÄòComputationally heavy‚Äô this would tamper with the health of the device and limit the applications that can be run on the device.\\n\\n- Speed üöò\\n\\nProcessing heavy data would eventually take more time on a smaller chip than on a server. Also, this would slow down the device, so taking the major processing away from the device would enable the device to be faster and free to perform tasks that are not heavy.\\n\\n- Cost üí∞\\n\\nIt is cheap to rent a server than to get actual hardware to process it, also it helps to scale any early-stage product!\\n\\nIf you are still here and don‚Äôt get a word of what you just read, stay with me. Let‚Äôs take a simple example.\\n\\nYou are a farmer who doesn‚Äôt have a tractor to plow the field. You are a lucky chad and have lots and lots of land! But, the problem is, to plow this huge land you need a tractor, but you can‚Äôt afford one as of now. Also, the rainy season is just around the corner for plantations. The best thing you do is rent a tractor and kick-start your farming journey. Here,\\n\\nThe Farm is the computation üåΩ\\n\\nFarmer is the product/service üßëüèº‚Äçüåæ\\n\\nThe tractor is the computation outsourced üöú\\n\\n## Okay, that‚Äôs great but what‚Äôs the problem üôÑ\\n\\n![4.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113108844/S8z-qa_4mv.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nSo, you offload your computation to an external server and the server sends you the processed output, and it‚Äôs the end of the story. Right?No! Let‚Äôs see the problems with this!\\n\\n- Security üîí\\n\\nWhen you send your data to offload computation, how do you verify it is not being recorded and monitored? Also, how do you ensure that this data isn‚Äôt stored after it is processed? Going back to our farm example, how do you verify that the tractor you used to plow the field isn‚Äôt stealing soil samples from your farm?\\n\\n- Verification ‚úÖ\\n\\nOkay, security is something that can always be figured out, but how do you verify that the data you received is correct? You can verify by processing it locally, but then what is the point of offloading it to an external source?\\nTo solve this, there are multiple solutions, but for now, we would stick to the security aspect of the problem. There is a concept called zero-knowledge Proof that comes into play here!\\n\\n## Zero Knowledge Proof, what‚Äôs that ü§î\\n\\n![5.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113166015/n_xIa8nXN.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLet‚Äôs ask Google, what zero-knowledge means, google responded, ‚ÄúIn cryptography, a zero-knowledge proof or zero-knowledge protocol is a method by which one party can prove to another party that a given statement is true while the prover avoids conveying any additional information apart from the fact that the statement is indeed true.‚Äù\\n\\nDon‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs not as complicated as it looks! So let me tell you in an easy way. Zero-knowledge means asking someone to do something without telling what it is and why is it being done. This also means that the work done by them is proven to be correct.\\n\\n**Still fuzzy? üòû\\n**\\n\\nOkay, let‚Äôs take an example.\\n\\nI have a superpower, I can count leaves on any tree with just one look üçÉPretty awesome, right?\\n\\nYou don‚Äôt have the same powers as me so how do you make sure I am not making this up?\\nEasy, we do something that can verify and prove that I am not making this up. I‚Äôll close my eyes, and I‚Äôll tell you to pluck some leaves from a tree.\\n\\nIt‚Äôs entirely your choice to either pluck some leaves or not pluck any leaves at all.\\nThen you‚Äôll ask me how many leaves you plucked, and if I give a correct answer, you have your zero-knowledge proof! ü§Ø\\n\\nCredits to [Rahil Arora](https://security.stackexchange.com/users/22401/rahil-arora) for the leaf example!\\n\\n## Combining Zero Knowledge Proof and Computation ü§Ø\\n\\n![6.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113349878/xyqUepBB8.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nLet‚Äôs take it a step further, we want to make a system where computation can have a ZKP. This is essentially called verifiable computation and there are two ways to do it. Unfortunately, both of them require some crazy mathematical skills to understand. Either way, let‚Äôs see the two types.\\n\\n- Proof-based Protocol:\\n\\nProof-based Protocols use back-and-forth communication with the client(farmer) to process and give ZKP. This is not efficient and is not preferred in many scenarios.\\n\\n- Argument-based Protocol:\\n\\nArgument-based Protocol just communicates once with the client(sometimes it can be interactive) and you can have your computation offloaded.\\n\\nThis is something we will explore in future blogs but for today enough computation for you.\\n\\n## What is Huddle01 doing? üòé\\n\\n![7.png](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1666113398209/7NzLyRkQq.png align=\\\"left\\\")\\n\\nYou are probably wondering what Huddle01 has to do with all of this. Well, to give an early alpha, we are working to change the way current RTC communications are done. So, this is something closely related to what we are aiming to achieve. That is the best we can share for now.\\n\\nIf you have any questions, suggestions, or team-ups in mind. Hit us on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/huddle01com) and be friends with us on our [Discord](https://discord.gg/4HBd3mTwqt). That would be it for today.\\n\\n\\n\",\"brief\":\"Huddle01 is making the future of communication systems by aiming to replace the current infrastructure with a better and more efficient tech stack keeping the decentralized aspect in mind.
